PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 will implement the major part of the Budget announcements in the social security area. The most significant changes are a proposed assets test on the family allowance, changes to the existing family allowance supplement assets test, and a new hardship provision on the family allowance supplement. I shall address all of these matters later in more detail.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill introduces new child bereavement payments, with the start-up date backdated to 17 August this year. This initiative is a result of promises made after the family of a child killed in the Strathfield shootings received a letter from the Department of Social Security two weeks after the child's death advising the parents that they were no longer entitled to receive the family allowance for that child. A parent or guardian whose child dies and who was receiving family allowance, child disability allowance or a double orphan pension for that child will continue to receive payment for four weeks after the child's death.

The principal Act also embodies this principle, but in a limited form. For instance, these limitations meant that the family of the child killed at Strathfield had its family allowance entitlement stopped immediately because there were no other children in respect of whom family allowance was already being paid. The coalition gives its support to this initiative.

The Bill establishes an education entry payment of $200 for sole parent pensioners as from 1 January 1992 to encourage them to undertake study. To receive the payment, the sole parent pensioner must have enrolled in a course of study and be eligible to receive the Austudy education supplement--a payment made to some pensioners and beneficiaries who, because of the Austudy income test, are ineligible for Austudy. No more than one education entry payment will be made in each calendar year. This payment will assist in alleviating the poverty traps faced by sole parent pensioners when they take steps to get themselves off the pension. The payment will make the transition to education easier and act as a reward for doing so.

The Bill's explanatory memorandum states that payment of the EEP will be made in respect of either full or part time study. However, the pensioner must also be eligible to receive the Austudy education supplement paid by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, but this is paid only to full time students, suggesting that sole parent pensioners choosing to study part time will be ineligible for the EEP after all. Nevertheless, we support the proposal and trust that the Government will correct what looks like an obvious error.

Also introduced in the Bill is a reduction in rent assistance waiting periods. Under this amendment, the rent assistance waiting period for recipients of Job Search allowance, Newstart allowance, sickness allowance or special benefit who have no children and are aged between 18 and 60 years, and for disability support pensioners aged between 18 and 20 years, will be reduced from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. For beneficiaries with children there is no waiting period. It is proposed that this measure will commence on 20 March 1992.

The amount of rent assistance paid depends on the person's income, the rent paid and the number of dependent children, if any. We see this initiative as nothing more than a backdoor increase in benefit rates for persons without children, which seems unnecessary, given that rent assistance is already tax-free and indexed and that property prices and rentals are currently in a depressed state. The coalition will not be supporting this particular proposal.

We welcome the proposals to increase the child disability allowance and to pay this increase to recipients of the new youth disability supplement. The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill, due to come into effect next month, linked payments for 16- to 20-year-olds with disabilities to the common youth allowance, but added a new youth disability supplement. Although we are still very concerned about the overall drop in payments for this group, we believe the introduction of a youth disability supplement to be very important as, for the first time, it recognises the additional cost of disability faced by young people and their families. We now urge the Government to go further, to honour the commitment given when this Bill was discussed by a Senate legislative and general purpose standing committee, and to pursue a carefully constructed disability allowance which recognises the extra cost of disability faced by all people with disabilities and their carers.

Whilst on the subject of disability, I should like to comment on some of the remarks made last Thursday in this House by the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) during the debate on a motion relating to disability services that I had laid before the House. I prefaced my remarks in that debate by saying that the motion did not seek to condemn the Government, nor did it seek confrontation. I also said that the Coalition would like to work with the Government in a bipartisan manner on setting the objectives for the future on disability services.

Unfortunately, the honourable member for Forde obviously was not so disposed, and perhaps that was her brief from the Department. If that were the case, she was badly briefed. The honourable member for Forde labelled the Endeavour Foundation of Queensland as `a monster private provider', with `megalithic structures' that has failed to move down the same path as the rest of the community for the past 40 years and has `an enormous amount of money power and control over people's lives'. My own personal involvement in Endeavour allows me to say categorically that her comments about the Endeavour Foundation are absolutely wrong.

The Executive Director of Endeavour, Mr Tom Barry, says that the claims of the honourable member for Forde were untrue, outrageous and worked contrary to the best interest of people with intellectual handicaps in Queensland. He stated that `her whole speech was crass political grandstanding in the worst taste'. He also asked whether the Federal Government had a clear plan in mind for its Disability Services Act. He said:
Perhaps it wants to dismantle all community based care providers in Australia and push all people with an intellectual disability into the mainstream community and workforce.

If so, their idea fails to take into account the individual nature of the intellectual handicap and blatantly refuses to recognise the undisputable fact that there are a large number of people with an intellectual handicap for whom full time mainstream or open employment is both a physical and intellectual impossibility.
Mr Barry commented further:

Endeavour is not a monolithic private structure, it's a community based care organisation, founded by and directed by the parents and friends of people with intellectual handicaps and largely run by individual Queenslanders who give their time and effort free of charge.

Endeavour receives from the Government less than 25 per cent of the $40m of its Budget it needs each year. So, in fact, the attack by the honourable member for Forde on the Foundation amounts to an attack on the integrity and dedication of literally hundreds of thousands of Queenslanders over four decades and the denigration of an organisation that has provided an outstanding service without being a burden on the financial resources of any government.

I want to give my experience with the Endeavour Foundation. I have been a member for 30 years. I am presently a Vice-Patron of the Mackay organisation. I can reflect on the earliest endeavours of Endeavour in Mackay and the changes that have been brought about under Endeavour. These changes were not insisted upon by the DSA and in fact were well before the Disability Services Act was introduced.

I think Mackay is typical. Having started in a pioneering fashion those 30 years ago, it now provides most of those services mentioned by Mr Barry with a limited input from the government of the day. Mackay is fairly typical of most of the Endeavour Foundation groups around Queensland. It started a school activity centre which has now been taken over by the State government; it has provided accommodation in a larger style--12 persons per unit; it has been buying, building and providing units of a lesser number, about five accommodation units, and it is doing that with its own funds without any help from the Commonwealth whatsoever; it has a sheltered workshop, a farming activity and an activity centre, and it also has a shopping arrangement where bits and pieces can be brought in and farmed out within the community. I have inspected those facilities; I have gone to the games which are encouraged by Endeavour throughout north Queensland; and I have attended its Christmas party.

I raise this matter as one of great concern. Many Queensland Federal members on both sides of the House are proud to be members of the Endeavour Foundation. The disgraceful comments made by the honourable member for Forde do not represent my views about Endeavour, those of my coalition colleagues--the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) is in the chamber, and I am sure he would agree with me--or the views of other Government members in this chamber. The honourable member for Forde, in her speech, also referred to the service provider, Keystone, as proof that the philosophy and practice of the Disability Services Act was the ideal for the future.
Yet in a letter dated 7 October 1991 to the Courier-Mail and to some of my colleagues, the Keystone Executive Director, Mr Lyall Cowell, had this to say:

No doubt you have become aware of Australia's national scandal, the heartless disregard for the intellectually disabled. Parents of the intellectually disabled are devastated at the policies developed by the Commonwealth Government and instituted by its department which sees the intellectually disabled literally thrown out into the street. Keystone along with similar organisations believe such policies to be based on unworkable theories. Indeed, Keystone views such policies as social engineering on a grand scale.

Comments by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services that all intellectually disabled people can be successfully integrated into either the workplace or TAFE training schemes is incorrect. In reality, only 10 per cent of the intellectually disabled people can achieve such a status. The honourable member for Forde, in whose electorate I believe this particular establishment is, did not even know the attitude of her own organisation--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Lyall Cowell is a fine man.

—-He is. He has written to me and I have agreed to go and visit his workshop whenever I can get to Brisbane. I suggest that the honourable member for Forde should also visit his workshop. It is time that departmental bureaucrats opened their eyes to the reality instead of basing their policies on unworkable theories. I was appalled and saddened by the speech of the honourable member for Forde. As I have said on many occasions, there is no room in politics for matters concerning people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I say once again that the Disability Services Act has opened up new options for people with disabilities, which the Opposition applauds and approves. However, we believe that there is still a need for services such as sheltered workshops, hostels, nursing homes and activity therapy centres to be able to co-exist along with the new services. The Government must recognise the facts and provide support for care providers who have quality services in place for those individuals who cannot be fully integrated into the community. In Mr Barry's words, the Government should be working on realistic solutions to the problems faced by people with intellectual handicaps, such as the lack of community understanding and the acceptance of disability in all its forms.

I return to the Bill before us and to the proposed changes in Job Search and Newstart allowance. Job Search and Newstart allowance will not be paid to a person who is receiving income from a group or community which, in turn, derives that income from funds provided by a Commonwealth funded employment program. Similarly, a Job Search or Newstart allowance recipient will no longer be able to claim an additional amount in respect of his or her partner if the partner is receiving income from funds provided by a Commonwealth funded employment program. A Commonwealth funded program is to be defined as one where the funding is based either wholly or partly on the number of JSA and NSA recipients who are or will be participating in the program. In the past, the participation in some training programs which provide payment has allowed some JSA and NSA claimants to effectively double dip into the welfare system. Obviously, this must be prevented, and we support this proposal.

The Bill further proposes that new part rate family allowance supplement recipients will no longer receive health care cards. Currently, all FAS recipients receive a health care card which allows access to concessions on pharmaceuticals and to State transport concessions. This proposal will restrict health care card eligibility to full rate FAS recipients, although existing part rate FAS recipients will be allowed to retain their cards for as long as they continue to receive FAS. It will necessitate an amendment to the Health Insurance Act 1973.

The amendment will allow for better targeting of the pharmaceutical concessions scheme and will also head off further increases in the cost of this scheme which would otherwise result from the liberalising of the family allowance supplement income test and the subsequent rise in the number of part time FAS recipients. The coalition also supports this proposal.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, the major initiatives in this Bill relate to the family allowance and family allowance assets test changes, and the introduction of hardship provisions. Family allowance is an income tested payment paid fortnightly to the principal carer of children. It is a payment that recognises the costs of raising children. In 98 per cent of cases the principal carer is the mother, but in the other 2 per cent of cases it is paid to fathers, guardians and even State and Territory juvenile detention centres.

In conjunction with the family allowance supplement, it aims to maintain the real value of family payments through indexation, as well as keeping it relative to other social security payments. Family allowance cuts out when family income reaches $62,057 in respect of one child, this threshold rising by $3,104 for each additional child. For families with one to three children, family allowance is paid at the rate of $10 per week and slightly more in respect of subsequent children. Family allowance supplement is paid as an add-on to family allowance to low income, working families. Its purpose is to eliminate poverty traps, that is, to ensure that families do not find themselves financially better off dependent on social security than at work. The rate of family allowance supplement paid depends on the number of dependent children and whether they are aged under 13 years or between 13 and 15; for example, a family earning less than $18,000 a year with a single child aged under 13 receives the maximum FAS rate of $26.50 per week.

The 1990-91 Budget contained a proposal to impose an assets test on the family allowance of $300,000. This figure was subsequently raised to $500,000 in the hope of ensuring the proposal's acceptance, but it was to no avail as it was not ultimately passed by the Senate. This proposal would impose a family, as opposed to a parental, assets test limit of $600,000 on the family allowance, above which no family allowance will be payable except in circumstances of hardship and for a limited period, as I will spell out further on. Excluded from the definition of assets are the family home and curtilage and debt.

Primary producers will be allowed to transfer debt associated with one income producing asset to another to reduce total net assets. The $600,000 figure will be indexed from 1 January 1993. What we have to ask is: what is the value of a property in connection with this new test? Recently at a banking inquiry at Charleville we heard from many people on the land that the value of their property is being greatly reduced as security by the banks. It must be an understanding that the proper and appropriate value should apply to the property under this particular test. Within my own electorate I know that the cane farms are selling at about half the price they were about 12 months ago. The farmers are also suffering from that reduction of security valuations by the banks. So we ask: how will assessments be made?

The existing FAS assets test, which stands at $347,500, will be converted from a parental to a family assets test in order to catch those who have avoided the test by rearranging ownership of assets among family members. A special financial hardship test will apply for two years. Those families with incomes which in current dollar values are below $13,078 plus $624 for each dependent child, and who have liquid assets of less than $6,000 for a single person or $10,000 for a couple, will be eligible for family allowance even where their net assets exceed $500,000, and for family allowance supplement in addition where net assets are between $347,500 and $600,000.

The family allowance is the only major family payment which is not assets tested, although it was means tested some years ago. This has been an anomalous situation and quite against the trend of tightening assistance to those genuinely in need. We have previously had reservations about the impact of assets tests on those in rural areas, including small businesses, who are relatively asset rich but income poor, especially in tough times, and these have been addressed by the hardship provisions in the Bill. Also, assets tests have been in place for a number of years in respect of a wide range of transfer payments, including the family allowance supplement and unemployment benefits--now the Job Search and Newstart allowances. However, we are concerned that this measure has taken so long to materialise since the first mention of a liquid assets test. The current Treasurer (Mr Kerin) excused himself, his Department and the Government for this delay by saying that the difficulty had been in defining a liquid asset. The Bill defines liquid assets in relation to a person as:
(a) the person's cash; and
(b) the person's shares and debentures in a public company within the meaning of the Corporations Law; and
(c) any amount deposited with, or lent to, a bank, building society, credit union or other financial institution by the person (whether or not the amount can be withdrawn or repaid immediately); and
(d) any amount due, and able to be paid, to the person by, or on behalf of, a former employer of the person; and
(e) any other readily realisable assets of the person.

Concerns have been expressed, by both small family businesses and farmers, as to whether working capital--carry-on business funds--will be excluded from the liquid assets test. It has been assumed that because of their non-inclusion in the definition such funds will be excluded. I would hope that the Government can give that assurance in the closing summary of this debate.

For instance, a farmer may receive $20,000 for the sale of wheat and have the money temporarily available in a bank account or as a credit in a statutory marketing authority but require the funds to pay for fertiliser, seed, rates et cetera. We believe that those funds should be excluded from a liquid assets test. Similarly, a small business person banks his takings for the month and temporarily has a credit in a business account but earmarks that amount for creditors and wages. These amounts should also be excluded.

We ask: to what extent will business transactions of a partnership or a corporation be divorced from the day to day private requirements of the partners or the shareholders in making the assessment? It is critical that we get answers to these particular problems now because this is central to the hardship provisions and the need to extend this latitude to those particular people, the small businessmen and the farmers who are suffering at the moment.

The family allowance was an initiative of the Fraser Government in 1976 when the original child endowment and the taxation rebate for children were brought together into one allowance. Both initiatives were family policies recognising the additional costs and responsibilities of the parent in raising children. The child endowment was a cash transfer--non-income tested--and the rebate was available to the head of the household by way of the reduced tax liability. The family allowance initiative was by far the best family orientated package brought before this Parliament and gave relief to the carer, that is, the mother. I believe it was a great initiative of the Fraser Government. It is interesting to read what the then Minister, Senator Don Grimes, said in introducing the family income allowance supplement in 1986:

The family income supplement is designed to improve the living standards of low income families with dependent children. The number of such families increases as unemployment increases. More breadwinners are being put out of work--
we should remember that this is 1986--
more families are living on a single wage, and more on pensions because there are so few jobs. Some of the reasons why the economic situation has deteriorated are also very interesting.

One might ask in these particular situations: what has changed between 1986 and 1991? Firstly, the living standards of low income families with dependent children are lowering. Also, there are 500,000 children living in poverty, in spite of that grand declaration by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that none would live in poverty after 1990, and there are 75,000 homeless people, as indicated by the Burdekin report.

Unemployment is now over 10 per cent, and forecasters are saying that the number of Australians on the unemployment list will exceed one million. There are now more people than ever before on all types of pensions and benefits because there are so few jobs. So we can make comparisons with the economic malaise created not by Fraser, not by the coalition, but by a Labor government that said that this is the recession that Australians had to have. Do honourable members remember the Budget that was about `bringing home the bacon'? The Labor Party has not even caught the pig yet. The Labor Government under Prime Minister Hawke will go down as one of the most uncaring governments since Federation.

This Government and the Australian Labor Party are now in a policy paralysis situation, with Caucus revolts on Medicare and foreign ownership guidelines for the media, with no coherent wages policy and with no real plans to alleviate Australia's drought. It is interesting to note a comment by Mr Clyde Cameron when he was addressing a May Day rally in Cairns. He called on that rally to sweep the Labor Government out of power at the next election as a penalty for its betrayal of Labor policies and principles and for bringing about the worst recession since the disastrous Depression of the 1930s. Those comments were by a former Minister in the Whitlam Government, one who was described in the article as one of the great men of the Left of the Labor Party. They were his own comments. So the Labor Party has been condemned by its own. If we want to get a bit closer to the bone, we might ask what Premier Kirner and Wally Curran are indicating to the Government about the fact that it has no policy for jobs.

The recession we `had to have' now means that 90 per cent of all pay as you earn taxation is required for our welfare bill. In 1991-92, $37.67 billion will be paid in pay as you earn taxation, and $34.41 billion will be spent on social security payments. Ironically, the cost of this recession is being borne by the people suffering most--those on pay as you earn taxation, those involuntarily unemployed, those suffering poverty in the bush, who are the new rural poor--the farmers. All these people have been the victims of high interest rates that were pitched far too high for far too long, of fouled up transport and wages systems and of record bankruptcies. One might ask in the face of all of that: where is the reality of Labor's social justice policy? In contrast, the coalition does have the policies for recovery.

—-Our programs will be targeted to those who have needs, particularly to families, and targeted to provide some of those one million people permanently unemployed with meaningful jobs. It is interesting that the Parliamentary Secretary at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, is laughing about the plight of one million people right throughout Australia who are currently unemployed because of the policies of his Government. He is smiling and laughing at their plight. He ought to be ashamed.
—-This is absolute nonsense that you are dribbling out.

—-It is an uncaring government that has brought this situation about. As I said, the Opposition opposes the reduction in this Bill of the waiting time for rental assistance, but we do support the other elements of the legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think it is important at the beginning of my remarks to make clear to the House that obviously the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon) was referring to and laughing at the Opposition's inability to come up with any policies. He certainly was not laughing at the plight of the unemployed or people in this country who are oppressed or poor. This Government has a very proud record of trying to assist and protect those people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) contains a number of measures which improve support for low to medium income families and iron out minor anomalies in other forms of assistance. Those other forms of assistance--which do have some anomalies that the Government is attempting to deal with by way of this Bill--include assistance to people obviously experiencing financial hardship, many of whom are in the rural communities and who may not otherwise be eligible for income support. The Bill also incorporates a change to payments to young people living away from home.

From 1 January 1992, for instance, a family net assets test of $600,000, excluding the family home, will replace the existing parental assets test of $347,500 for the family allowance supplement. This change will obviate the possibility of people rearranging their assets amongst other family members to ensure that parental assets comply with the assets test and that they receive income support to which the majority of the community, I am sure, would not expect them to be entitled if their assets were very large.

I remind the House also, in the context of the remarks made by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) concerning PAYE taxpayers bearing the brunt, that the family allowance supplement, as it exists and under these proposals, provides cash for working families. That is exactly what it is; it is for low income, working families who have a wage coming in but that wage of itself is not sufficient, or does not take cognisance of, the dependants in the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Better give it to the farmers.

—-Behave yourself, Neil. The farmers will get it. The farmers will be eligible if they have very low incomes, as many of them do; I am prepared to acknowledge that. But I think it is important that this House understands--and I am not sure that everybody does--that low income working people are the beneficiaries, in the main, of the family allowance supplement. They may, in fact, have a non-working spouse and young children or a number of children. The allowance extends the limit of the test to a very high income, in fact. But because our present wages system--and, I suppose, that of the future--does not take account of a person's family responsibilities and the cost of maintaining children, it has been in the Government's interest, and I think the interest of the community, to ensure that we have a scheme which assists those people and recognises the costs involved in supporting their families.

SPEECH.PARA: A very important improvement, although not a huge one, is that the income threshold at which the full rate of family allowance supplement is payable, which is currently $18,000 a year, will be increased and aligned with the Austudy income threshold from 1 April 1992. At the moment that is $19,300, but it will increase to $20,700 from January 1992 and will be indexed each year in January from there on. I think this will make a difference to the number of people who are eligible for family allowance supplement. It will also increase the number of families, obviously, who are eligible. People will receive more in family allowance supplement as a consequence of the change.

Most honourable members are aware, of course, that FAS recipients are currently entitled to a health care card. That has been an important aspect of FAS because it brings quite a lot of benefit to the family concerned. However, the Government has decided with this legislation to remove the eligibility for future part-FAS recipients; that is, people who now apply for a partial FAS payment will not now be eligible for a health care card. Those who are currently in receipt of a full rate family allowance supplement or those who are currently in receipt of a partial rate family supplement will continue to have access to a health care card.

This change does have implications for the proposals to quarantine card holders and their families from the impact of the decision to permit bulkbilling doctors to charge their patients $2.50 a visit in the future. That is something that the Government recognises. But to quarantine those people has been seen as an important measure. Full rate family allowance supplement beneficiaries are obviously those who are most in need in these circumstances.

Other measures in the Bill also benefit families. The honourable member for Dawson referred in his speech to the child disability allowance. This will be raised by $2.15 a week after indexation. This will help restore the payment to its value in real terms at the time of its introduction in 1987. That is a very worthy proposal and one which I will support, the Government will support and presumably the Opposition will support. The youth disability supplement will also be increased by the same amount.

Another small but significant change proposed in this legislation relates to the back payment of a family payment when the delay in lodgment of the claim exceeds four weeks after the birth of a child. People who have been in that position--as I, and maybe others in this House, have been--realise that not all women are in a position to lodge the claim for their child very soon after the birth. It is not simply a matter of being unable to do it; one has other things on one's mind. Even in the best circumstances, where a spouse is supportive or willing to go down and register the child's birth and then claim for the payment, it does not appear to be a priority at the time. Four weeks is a fairly short time for a person to have to comply with that requirement.

I am pleased to see that the time fame for lodgment has now been extended to 13 weeks, which is a more realistic period, given that one has at least established some family routine in that 13-week period; there may not be a great deal of routine within four weeks of the baby being born. Obviously, that can be worse rather than better if one has other children, although the initial shock and disruption of a first child is probably worse than it is with any subsequent child.

We in this House also recognise that sole parent pensioners face a substantial up-front cost when undertaking education. The honourable member for Dawson also referred to that in his speech. I do not think anybody here would want to deny our sole parents that opportunity, especially when education will usually lead to an improvement in their self-esteem and a better understanding and evaluation of their own capabilities, capacities and strengths when it comes to coping with life outside the home. Many people underestimate the capacity of sole parent pensioners to take on another job or to take on anything outside their role as a parent, and many of the problems associated with this are simply self-esteem problems. To involve sole parent pensioners in any community activity or any form of education is itself beneficial.

I was therefore pleased to note that sole parents undertaking any education will be receiving a payment each year of $200 up-front, which will allow them to pay for books and other items required for their education. Obviously, this relates very closely to the vocational training opportunities that are available to sole parents, many of whom have children over 16 years of age. Where they are undertaking approved vocational education, for instance, they have course fees paid, their books and equipment are paid for and often even child-care is available for them. That is not always going to be the case with people undertaking education where there is no economic imperative, but I think society needs to recognise that education is a beneficial first step for sole parents to take and I am delighted that that $200 payment is being made available to them if they choose to follow that course.

In the second reading speech on this Bill, the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) referred to young persons who have to live away from home or who have to leave secondary studies at an early age. He pointed out that these young people face considerable social and economic disadvantage. That is undoubtedly true and, whilst we as a Government have made great strides in trying to assist young people in their decision to stay in education until at least year 12, which would imply a leaving age of 16 or 17, it is a fact that many young people are still leaving before year 12. Obviously, with participation rates getting up to 60 or 70 per cent, and in some places exceeding that, there are not as many early school leavers as before, but even where there is a 60 or 70 per cent participation rate in post-compulsory education an implied 30 per cent of young people are leaving before they have reached year 12. In places like Western Australia, where, to large degree, even those in year 12 may be only 16, quite a number of 15-year-olds are not working and are getting very little assistance from the Government or from their families in straitened times.

It is a good thing that the Government has now regularised its approach to those under the age of 16 who may not actually have had a job when they left school. This is important because previously, in a better job market when jobs were more readily available to young people, they would have been able to leave school at 15 and get some sort of a job. If they lost that job, they would then have been able to seek assistance through Job Search or unemployment benefits. At the present time, if they have not had a job they would not be eligible and would have to seek assistance through some other measure, usually through a special benefit or a sickness allowance. This does not actually assist them, because it makes them think they are in fact a select group of individuals or a sick group of individuals. That is not helpful either to the country or to them and their psychology of themselves.

The Bill provides that from 1 January 1992 an independent young person may enrol or register with the CES for 13 weeks and then will be accepted for Job Search allowance even if that young person has not previously had a job. That is a very important change to the Act. The Bill also involves a change to our view of Austudy. The Treasurer's second reading speech says:
From 1 January 1992, this Bill provides for social security arrangements to be brought into line with Austudy entitlements for 16- to 17-year-old persons in substitute care.

I would point out to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that when we brought in Austudy in the age related context, that is, for 16-year-olds and over, it was made clear that there were a significant number of students in the under-16-year-old category in South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland, which are the three States most affected, who are in fact in year 11 but are not eligible for Austudy because of its age related nature.

If we are to extend the payments to people who are under the age of 16 when it comes to unemployment benefits or Job Search allowance, it stands to reason that we should at least be contemplating extending Austudy to those students who are under 16 and who are in year 11, which is post-compulsory education, because the original idea of the age related Austudy was to ensure there was no economic disincentive to students staying on at school.

By virtue of this change to the legislation, for kids who are not really wishing to stay at school we may well have inadvertently built in some economic imperative to leave school and get this Job Search allowance, whereas it may be to their long term benefit to stay on at school. We will have to look at that again, and indeed I will ask the Minister to do so. In fact, I would have done so before now, but until very recently I had not realised that was one of the provisions in the Bill and I have not had an opportunity to raise it with him in the interim.

The Bill also contains a proposal to extend the rental assistance provisions to young homeless people. Again those people would often be people who are under 16 years of age, but not always so. The Bill indicates that from 20 March 1992 eligibility for rent assistance will be extended to under-18-year-olds who receive the homeless independent rate of Job Search allowance, sickness allowance, disability support pension or special benefit and who have been receiving social security income support for at least 18 weeks.

To people who are not aware of what is going on out there in the community, some of these provisions may appear not to be necessary; but, believe me, there are many children--and they are still children even when they are over the age of 16 years--who have no support at all or are trying to survive on what is effectively a fairly low social security payment, and pay rent out of it. If we do not provide them with rental assistance, we leave them with very little option but to share, sometimes with undesirable flatmates or housemates, or to not go into any permanent form of accommodation at all and pursue a lifestyle which is not helpful to their future or to their health and welfare.

To regularise the position of those young people and to enable them to pay for proper--albeit not splendiferous--accommodation is to help them settle back into the community in a more normal fashion and resume a way of life that they have lost or forgone.

The Bill obviously has a great deal going for it. I am sorry that the Opposition opposes that aspect of the Bill which allows an independent young person to register for the rental assistance. That is an important aspect of the Bill and it takes into account the Government's concerns--and the concerns of the community--about these homeless young people.

We need to recognise that these young people are not just bums; a great number of them, for very good reasons--not always because of physical or mental abuse, but for very good reason in their minds--decide to leave home. Sometimes they do so at the behest of their parents and yet receive no formal support from those parents. Some of these kids are about 16 years of age. Some of them are attempting to cope with education at the same time.

I do not need to remind most honourable members in this House that 16- to 17-year-olds have problems trying to cope with the last year of high school and with all that implies even when they are still at home. Those who have no home deserve every bit of support we can extend to them. It should not be implied that the benefit they receive is sufficient to encourage them to leave home.

This point needs to be made: support and assistance should be available where it has been established that there are sound reasons for a young person leaving home and it should be clear that the Government is not encouraging them to leave home when the home is perfectly adequate, and where we are dealing with just a teenage tantrum or a minor family dispute.

But there are circumstances--and I have been confronted with them on a number of occasions--where these young people have very good reason for not being at home, or where in fact their parents have insisted that they leave for fairly arbitrary reasons, and there is no financial or other support available for them. We cannot, in conscience, allow those young people to attempt to exist and follow an education pattern without support. If we do not support them, they will be unable to attain education itself. They will then be not able to redeem themselves. I prefer--I am sure that the Treasurer is proposing this--that we assist those young people as much as we can without actually encouraging them to leave home. After all, this time can be fairly traumatic for both parents and children; the teenage years are not easy years for anybody.

Without any further comment, I strongly commend the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) for bringing these proposals forward in the Budget context. I certainly commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise in this House, having already been chastened by the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) and told--in a motherly way--to behave myself. SPEECH.PARA: This legislation illustrates much of what distinguishes the Opposition from the Government. The Government has an obsession with wealth. It measures the success of various Australian families and individuals by what they have acquired. Consequently, the Government has an enthusiasm that I find almost indecent for the redistribution of that wealth.

It is as if, from the Government's point of view, the absence of wealth and assets is some sort of handicap to the way in which people are able to perform as citizens. I suspect that those opposite like to imagine that most of society's major problems can be solved by the acquisition of additional assets or money. This is historic nonsense. I find it repugnant to measure people's individual status by what they own or earn.

I was bemused to discover in the Canberra Times last weekend that Germaine Greer, hardly a pin-up girl in my office, had found that her most rewarding times had been spent among the peasants of Tuscany. We would have to ask ourselves: if the acquisition of assets and wealth really is a measure of people's capacity to contribute, how is it that people in holy orders manage to be so cheerful?

TALK.START.PARA: —-What has this got to do with Tuscany?
—-I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his interjection. What does this have to do with the Bill before the House, he asks.
—-No; with the people of Tuscany.

—-Everything--because the people whom I represent are the farmers of Australia whose assets and wealth, by the Government's measure, have little to do with their capacity to contribute. SPEECH.PARA: All of these sentiments were expressed by members on this side of the House when we debated Austudy. From our point of view the family allowance should not be a social security payment. The fact that the family allowance is what once was the child endowment and is paid to the principal carer indicates that we as a society see it as an entitlement rather than a welfare payment. We on this side of the House recognise that Australia needs nothing more than it needs supportive, stable family life. In that sense, we do not think the family allowance should be a social security payment; it should be, instead, an entitlement that goes to every Australian family who is prepared to make the best contribution it can to social life in Australia by raising well-balanced children.

I am a little uncomfortable. I find myself standing here, trapped--though not trapped, as the Parliamentary Secretary will be tempted to interject, by the discipline of the party room. In fact, I am proud to say that over half of my South Australian Liberal parliamentary Federal colleagues have crossed the floor at some stage in their parliamentary careers. There is no discipline here in that sense. I am trapped instead by the uncomfortable reality that the family allowance ought to go to every Australian family, but the economic mismanagement of this Government obliges me and every Australian to recognise that the Government can no longer make that money available, and so we are obliged to target assistance in all areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It's a real mess.

—-It is a disaster. It was that disaster that had the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), from the other side of the House, and I hammering on the door of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in a bipartisan approach to have last year's absurd $300,000 assets test on the family allowance reconsidered. The best he could offer was $500,000. We recognised that that still would fail to meet the needs of Australian farming families, so we opposed it.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1991 we find ourselves in an invidious position. Here we are with a government sending Australia broke. Here we are, obliged to target assistance in some way. Here we are, considering again a Bill that, thanks to our cussedness, has been improved at least to the point where the assets test will be set at $600,000, which is still far too inadequate, and that includes one sweetener that makes it possible for the Opposition to support the Government in these amendments to the family allowance and the family allowance supplement; that is, hardship provisions, which will allow a number of Australian farming families who ought to access these provisions to do so.

I am pleased to say that the honourable member for Cowan--when I was, I confess, rude enough to interrupt her speech--said `the farmers will get it'. No news could have been better for me and for the Liberal and National parties represented on this side of the House. That is what we need to know. We were a bit bothered that the hardship provisions may not be adequate to allow Australian farming families who will be locked out of the family allowance by their assets--and that will be the vast majority of farming families--access to the family allowance and the family allowance supplement when they most need it.

The hardship provisions say that, if a person's income falls below $13,078 a year plus $624 for every child, that person will be able to access the family allowance. In addition, if a couple has less than $10,000 of liquid assets, in spite of having farm assets of over $600,000, those people will be able to access the family allowance. The honourable member for Cowan assures me that every one of my farmers will qualify. I am heartened by that because what we seek from the Minister--and I convey this to the Minister through the Parliamentary Secretary--is the knowledge that farmers will not be locked out of access to family allowance by having liquid assets that in our view are nothing more than the working capital they need to run the farm.

We reluctantly accept the need for assets testing of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, but we are concerned that the Government may be much too rigid in its interpretation of what $10,000 of liquid assets means. I convey to the Parliamentary Secretary the following two points, confident that he will be able to take them to the Minister: first, that the Minister, to be consistent, ought to consider tapering the assets test so that it goes up, reflecting the number of dependent children in each family, just as it does in the income test; and, secondly, that the Minister should look at the definition of `working capital' and ensure that working capital is in some way excluded from the liquid assets so as to allow people to access the family allowance.

It would cost an average grain farmer in Australia $100,000 to put his crop in the ground. I do not exaggerate, and my colleagues present could vouch for this even more fluently that I could. A farmer with $10,000 of liquid assets is hardly about to go on a sowing rampage such as Australia needs to turn around its balance of payments deficit. I am not a grain farmer; I am not a wheat or wool farmer. I have come into this place with a background in horticulture, principally in fruit growing. That is not a capital intensive industry, but there is no way I could harvest my fruit crops, given that that harvest is still principally undertaken by itinerant labour, unless I had available to me $50,000 to pay those labourers.

We are supposed to sit here and listen to nonsense espoused by Government members as if they were the only ones who knew what it was like to be an itinerant labourer. I will lay London to a brick that I have written out more cheques for itinerant labourers than anyone opposite has. I have a fair idea from the people who work for me year in and year out of what it is like for them to have to survive on what is a very nominal income, which means that most of them qualify for the family allowance supplement anyway.

People in primary industry invariably need on hand, in working capital, a sum of money that well and truly exceeds the $10,000 that the Government has allowed for liquid assets. If this, in fact, is to be a fair and just assets test on the family allowance, and revision of the family allowance supplement, then this level of working capital must be borne in mind.

As I said earlier, I frankly would prefer no assets test at all. In fact, if I were to be honest with the House, I suppose I would prefer no income test on the family allowance either, given that I maintain that it ought not to be a social security or welfare payment, but an entitlement to Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Put it through your Party and get it into policy.

—-Now we have the Minister interjecting. I reassure the Minister that I recognise that given the financial plight of all Australians--particularly of rural Australians--and the consequent fall in taxation revenue available to the Government, it is necessary to target all forms of assistance. In fact, the Bill before the House is estimated to save something like $25m. I cannot, as a member of the alternative government of this country, suppose for a moment that I am going to generate that $25m from some other area.
—-You can't have two bob each way.

—-So I find myself supporting this Bill but expressing the obligation that the Minister and the Cabinet have to recognise that the assets test in October 1991 will invariably price Australian farming families out of the family allowance. The insertion of hardship provisions--I have no doubt that these are well motivated--that the Government has brought into this House need, at least, to be flexible enough in their applications so that farming families who may have a temporary influx of funds to be used either to plant a crop, to pay wages or, effectively, to meet the interest obligations that they are going to have over the ensuing three or six months, ought not, because of that influx of funds, be denied access to the family allowance or the family allowance supplement, as the case may be.

SPEECH.PARA: All too often, I stand or sit in this place and have the impression that, from the Government's point of view, all arguments are black and white; there is no compromise. So it is that if we suggest something it is black, and if the Government suggests it, it is white. It is a luxury, frankly, that we have not been able to afford. From time to time, we have found ourselves obliged to support the Government in things we have been uncomfortable about. As a representative of wheat and woolgrowers, and as a representative of horticulturalists, on the question of tariff protection I have found myself on the question of tariff protection supporting the Government on issues with which I was uncomfortable, knowing that they were imperfect but deciding that they were the lesser of the available evils.

A similar sort of generous spirit has not, it seems to me, pervaded the Government benches because here we are proposing a goods and services tax. It is not a black and white decision, but if one listened to the people opposite, one would swear that it was. Everything we have heard over the past month about the GST has been black. In spite of the fact that it was recommended by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and endorsed by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), everything has been black.

In this debate this morning, before I rose to my feet, what did I have? I had the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon) and the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) telling me that we, the Opposition, have no policies. How that must rile the shadow Minister for tourism and the shadow Minister for education. Before the last election we had policies in every area, and yet here we are being pillaged by the Government because we are about to announce the most dramatic policy change that this nation has seen in 30 years. What does the Government say? It says, `You have no policies'. How on earth can it stand behind a statement like that?

Having been obliged this morning to stand up and uncomfortably support the Government's proposal for some form of assets testing on the family allowance, having been obliged to make a compromise in that area because I see little choice and because economically it is being foisted on me, let me remind the Government that I do not by so doing walk away from the families of Australia or the need to support them. The coalition recognises that, through the GST, there is a real opportunity to offer support to the families of Australia. It is only that sort of opportunity that allows us to support the Government in what we see as a less than adequate family measure currently before the House.

We propose a sort of tax measure which deliberately encourages Australians to be productive and which, in fact, allows the Government for the first time to reduce income tax on Australian families. There has not been one gracious word of support from the Government benches. We have not pretended it is all good, but I am damn sure it is not all bad. Yet, if one listened to the Government, one would swear it was. Does the Government think that in Opposition the proposal of a new tax policy is easy? Of course it is not. It would be a lot easier for us to sit here mute and go into government, as we inevitably will. Instead of that, we have taken the honourable course; we have told the people of Australia what we propose to do in taxation reform and designed that taxation reform so that it will deliberately assist Australian families.

We would like to deliberately assist Australian families by making the family allowance freely available to them all, but the economic reality is that we cannot. So, we have compromised our attitude at that point in the interests of the national economy. I have seen no such realistic compromise on any area of the GST emerge from the Government benches, in spite of the fact that--

TALK.START.PARA: —-We won't inflict it on the Australian people.

—-No, in spite of the fact that before it was politically clever the Minister chose to support the concept of a GST or, if I misrepresent the Minister and he in fact did not, then the record clearly shows that both his Prime Minister and former Treasurer most certainly did.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House underscores some form of asset testing for the family allowance. We have wrestled with this. We uncomfortably support it because we see it as the lesser of the available evils. But we seek the assurance from the Minister for Social Security--and I pass this message through the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) who is at the table--that the real value of farms will be taken into consideration because, of course, they have plummeted and because the $600,000 asset test limit will almost certainly exempt 90 per cent of Australian farmers from the family allowance. The door that the Government then opens to let them in, which is the door that allows them to qualify through hardship provisions, has sufficient flexibility to allow farmers to hold the working capital that they need merely to be farmers and still be eligible for the family allowance and the family allowance supplement where possible. The income test of $13,000 or so elevated for each child ought not to be so rigorously policed that those who are on the margin will find themselves unable to make ends meet or feed their families simply because they happen to be assets rich, but cash poor. This is something that the Government seems to find difficult to conceive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have listened with interest to the previous speakers in this debate this morning and I guess I was similarly amused with some of the comments, as was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon) earlier on. However, I was similarly bemused, I guess, with the comments of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) who concentrated most of his remarks on one aspect of this particular debate before the House this morning. SPEECH.PARA: He noted that the debate about the assets test is similar to the debate that took place previously in the House with regard to the assets test on Austudy. I must say that I will canvass more of the aspects of this Bill this morning than just the assets test that applies to the family allowance and family allowance supplement.

Certainly of great assistance to families, particularly rural families, and small businesses in rural areas are the benefits from the series of social security Bills included in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which is here before us today. Most of the changes, I know, were announced in the Budget, and this legislation is to bring them into action. The raising of the family allowance supplement threshold income from $18,000 to, I believe, $20,700 by 1 January 1992 is to be applauded. Another provision I want to comment on is the integration of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement into a single payment and claim process from 1 January 1993. Farmers and people with small businesses get a deal of attention from the Opposition. We do not have a bottomless pool of funds to draw on, and that means there has to be some limit. How one goes about putting that limit is a matter of debate.
