Let us hope we can be of some assistance to those people.

SPEECH.PARA: I was listening quite intently to the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), and I can only conclude that he really has lost touch--if he ever had touch--with his electorate. I know that the electorate of Richmond is on the north coast of New South Wales and some parts of it include seaside resorts, but it is very much a rural electorate. I can only say that he has lost touch. It goes to show how honourable members, if they are not careful, can lose touch so quickly once they come to Canberra. If the honourable member really wanted to see what is going on out there in the bush, I would welcome him to the electorate of Maranoa and show him some very sad cases that really must be addressed.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) will give effect to a number of measures, most of which were announced in the 1991-92 Budget. I took a sympathetic interest in the bereavement provision of this Bill. The recent tragedy at Strathfield in Sydney's western suburbs highlighted an unfortunate aspect of the current social security legislation whereby child bereavement payments were not available to some families. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) gave an undertaking to correct this deficiency at the first opportunity.

This Bill gives effect to the Minister's commitment and highlights to me the pace at which reform of social security legislation can be undertaken. I appeal to the Minister to reform other unfortunate aspects of current social security legislation in light of the worst drought facing rural Australia for over 100 years. I have appealed to the Government to introduce now as a matter of urgency an unconditional household support payment, which would be equivalent to the unemployment benefit, in the form of a cash grant to many farming families living in these drought declared areas. I think that this measure would correct a very unfortunate situation whereby unemployment benefits are payable to a married couple in the city no matter what the value of their residential property, while, on the other hand, a farming couple becomes ineligible for unemployment benefits once the value of their farm exceeds $157,500.

In his second reading speech, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) emphasised that no person in Australia could not be aware of the special difficulties being faced by the rural community. Does the Minister sincerely believe that the provisions in this Bill help put food on the table of those drought stricken farmers whose resolve has continuously been broken down by nine years of hard Labor policies?

Honourable members of this Parliament need to recognise the severity of the drought crippling much of rural Australia. They need to recognise that nine years of this Government's policies have exacerbated the position in this crisis. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) acknowledges the current situation. Recently he said:
Rural Australia could be facing its worst crisis in 100 years.

Such a crisis does not eventuate out of the blue. The policies of this Government have struck a far heavier and much more savage blow than the weather has. Farmers have fought to remain in business against all odds. They have fought for the last eight to nine years against record interest rates which have led to a grossly overvalued Australian dollar, which in turn makes export products less competitive. They have fought the hidden taxes and tariffs which this Government has introduced. There are many tariffs on imported machinery and spare parts.

In the last nine years the Government has made virtually inoperative the income equalisation deposits scheme, which was an initiative of this side of the House which helped smooth farmers' income and catered for situations such as the one we are confronted with in rural Australia right now. Farmers have fought to have countervailing duties applied to the many imported food products that come into Australia and unfairly compete against the domestically grown product. They are continuing their fight against the corrupt world prices for food. They are fighting the major nation, the United States of America, right now in Brussels to see whether we can see some reforms put in place. They have fought all those battles.

I will give a simple example to put in perspective the relative purchasing power of a farmer today. In 1973, a farmer needed 35 tonnes of wheat to buy a farm utility, which is an essential item around the farm today. In 1991, he will need 175 to 180 tonnes of wheat to buy a farm ute. That is a factor of six.
Mr Andrew interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will repeat that for the honourable member for Wakefield because I know that he has a rural electorate similar to mine and is confronted with these problems daily. In 1973, 35 tonnes of wheat would purchase a farm utility; today, it is almost 200 tonnes, depending on whether it is a premium wheat or a feed wheat.

SPEECH.PARA: That gives the Parliament some idea of the erosion of the purchasing capacity of the farmers in rural Australia in the last 27 years. Based on this fact alone, farmers cannot fight against all these evils imposed by this Labor Government and survive the worst drought in living memory. This Government has succeeded in achieving the breakdown of the farmers' resolve so that when farmers are faced with a natural disaster of this magnitude they feel completely helpless.

Across my electorate--I imagine across many electorates of Australia--there have been financial assistance seminars. These have been conducted by farming organisations to find out what can be done to assist farm families to remain on the land until the next rain. Rain is one thing that no-one can organise. Rain will certainly alleviate some of the problems, but it will not rain money; rain will only alleviate the immediate hardship of the daily chore of feeding livestock.

From these meetings comes an overwhelming plea for understanding and compassion from the Government. Most of these people have never been in this position. Most of these people are very proud people and they have never had to resort to even considering that they may need some form of welfare to get through this crisis that they are confronted with.

This is the first time since the Great Depression of the 1930s that farming communities in the Dalby area have been so united and have come forward together to try to tackle this problem and seek some emergency relief. I believe that that is certainly a sad indictment of Government policies when for 60 years communities have been able to cope but right now they believe they cannot cope much longer. It is the whole community that is united behind this cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Especially when they pride themselves on being independent.

—-Exactly. As the honourable member for Wakefield says, they pride themselves on being independent and not wanting to go to governments for handouts. Even sadder is the lack of financial assistance or understanding that is coming from this Government. I am not talking about an inefficient industry. These farmers are considered `world best standard'--a catch phrase around this place which is often used to suggest that we should strive to achieve world best standards in many industries. They are acknowledged internationally as the best and most efficient farmers in the world. We are not talking about subsidies or assistance for an inefficient industry to be propped up. By failing to attack this problem, this Government is succeeding in destroying Australia's world best industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to note a comment in the Australian Financial Review made by Mr Curran, the Victorian Secretary of the Meat Industry Employees Union. He said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was `a product of the Australian Parliament'. As reported, he went on to say:
He reflects the general conservative views of modern Labor politicians. They've lost the way. Their rhetoric is not the light on the hill. It's the bunker. It's a tragedy.
I would have to agree with him. Mr Curran, the Secretary of the Victorian meatworkers union, one of those on the Government's side, said:
It's the bunker. It's a tragedy.

I must acknowledge in this address the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy's recent visit to Toowoomba on the Darling Downs. He came to Toowoomba about 10 days ago. I hope that as a result of that visit he has an understanding of the real plight in rural Australia. It is so easy to sit in one's swivel chair in Canberra in the comfort of this air-conditioned building and think one knows what is really happening at the coalface. The Minister did visit my electorate and I hope that he gained an understanding of what is happening. I hope he understands what the drought means, because that is what we must focus on now. We must identify drought as a recurring phenomenon but one which must be considered by this Parliament.

The rural adjustment scheme (RAS) certainly does give assistance to farmers at this time. I concede the advantages of this scheme. However, the scheme makes no provision for drought. The rural adjustment scheme pays interest relief, but where does that interest relief go to? It goes to the bank; it pays the bank's interest. It will put food on the banker's table but it will not put food on the farmer's table. RAS lends money to already debt ridden farmers who have struggled to remain efficient and who have survived for the last 10 years under this Government, or forces them to adjust out of farming.

Government policy seems to be more directed at eliminating farmers than trying to assist them. One only has to look at the ABARE figures, which state that in the next three to four years 20 per cent of farmers will leave the land. That is an appalling indictment of this Government. Testimony to this fact is the existence of government incentives to leave the land and policies which encourage the importation of $2.2 billion worth of food imports every year.

The drought policy task force commissioned by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy identified government assistance under the banner of a hydrological cycle. I will explain that briefly. It is a cycle where one gets rain, apathy, drought, awareness, concern and ultimately, crisis. Then the cycle begins again. However, this cycle leaves out any effective form of drought management. It tackles drought at the crisis point and not before. We have to attack the problem before the crisis.

There is a very real need, as recognised by the national drought policy review task force, to encourage commercially and environmentally responsible management under variable seasonal conditions. The Federal Government's approach to the disaster of the magnitude that is now being felt in Queensland and New South Wales is to define drought as a naturally recurring feature of the Australian climate and an ongoing commercial risk associated with rural enterprises. However, the task force recommended an additional part to rural adjustment--part D. This part addressed household support--the very basis of what I am talking about today--under drought conditions.

It is this provision which should come under the banner of this social security legislation. The cash reserves of these people out there right now have all dried up. They have spent an awful lot of money, all their cash reserves, feeding their livestock and, in some cases, they have been selling their livestock, if they are saleable, to pay their bills. Many grain growers have been without income for the last four seasons. Let me assure the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is at the table, that our welfare net is missing the farmer and his wife, unlike the farmer's city cousin.

Whilst unemployment benefits are payable to married couples in the city no matter what the value of their residential property, no such benefit is afforded farming couples who may wish to remain on the land. They only become eligible for unemployment benefits once their assets are below $157,500. Honourable members might think these people get picked up under the family allowance or family allowance supplement, but they do not. To be eligible for family allowance or family allowance supplement, they must have dependent children. So the older couple, or the young couple trying to get a start in farming, are not picked up under the social security network.

Part C of the rural adjustment scheme under household support provides no benefit for those farming families who wish to remain on the land. To become eligible, they must put their property--their assets, in other words--on the market and sell within two years. If they do not sell within two years, the household support which they have received under part C of the rural adjustment scheme is converted to a commercial loan; the money that has been paid for the last two years is converted to a commercial loan.

When farming families put their property on the market to receive this household support they also put the family home on the market. So when they adjust out of farming they leave the land homeless. This is the only way that they can get household support today. There are strings attached. I believe it is time that we altered that criteria for drought affected farmers, such is the severity of the drought that is being suffered in so many areas of rural Australia today.

Certainly household support must take on a new dimension in drought declared areas. I have several cases in my electorate right now where people have sought outside work, which is very difficult to find. I had one case in my office the other day. This person was able to obtain $60 a week in part time work. I said, `How do you use that money?' She said, `That is what the family is living on. That is buying the groceries'. Other families did not attend these rural financial seminars--they rang me. They believed that they could use the money that they would have spent on petrol to get to town in a better way. They rang the 008 number which I have at my office to give me some idea of the hardship with which they are confronted.

The Queensland Government has an initiative right now which gives $200 in emergency aid to put food on the table of some of these families who are suffering extreme hardship. It is not the type of scene that I would have expected in Australia where a government boasts that there will be no child living in poverty. It is the type of scene that one would see in a Third World country. Two hundred dollars of emergency food aid, in this day and age in Australia, is a sad indictment of this Government. We are faced with the worst drought in living memory, since records were kept in my electorate and in many parts of Australia. We must have, under this social security legislation, unconditional household support for up to nine months to address the extreme financial difficulties being faced by these drought declared farmers.

At the end of the drought, machines can be replaced and animals can be repurchased, but we cannot replace the four and five generations of farmers who have worked that land and who have an intimate knowledge of what it can do. They have knowledge that has passed from father to son. It is not in the textbooks. That is what we are going to lose if these farmers are forced from the land. Right now they are asking for a little compassion and some support. I believe that support must come in the form of household assistance. This will certainly take the weight off some farmers' minds as to how they are going to continue to keep food on their tables. It is a problem that this Government must address as a matter of urgency. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I place on record my personal support for some of the points raised by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). He outlined the concerns that people have in rural areas and has exposed the plight of people out there. Recently I went to a rural crisis meeting in Biloela in part of my electorate in central Queensland. Some 200 people brought forward similar problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that by way of support, I find it very difficult to continue that support when the honourable member says that there ought to be unconditional household support for nine months. That is an amazing suggestion. He is saying that regardless of the wealth, regardless of the assets, regardless of the capacity of a person to borrow on a rural property, the Government, the people of Australia, the pensioners, the workers, the low income person, ought to give unconditionally money for a nine months period.

I understand the honourable member's concern because I have travelled my electorate and I know the sorts of problems that people are having. But I suggest that we do not achieve very much in a debate such as this when people come out with such extreme propositions. We need to be fair. I try to be fair to the honourable member for Maranoa, as his electorate joins mine. We try to work for the same constituency, our rural people. But we need to ensure that, when we give assistance, we provide it efficiently and that we also provide it to those who need it most. That has been the significance, the characteristic, of the Australian welfare system. It is extremely efficient; it is means tested and it targets those in most need.

It costs less than 3.5c in the dollar to deliver this service. Honourable members should think about that. We have seen all sorts of allegations against privatised type welfare agencies where 78c of every dollar given goes into the administration. But, of every $100 that we expend or appropriate for welfare, only 3.5c actually goes to the cost of delivering that service. That is a minor amount. One of the reasons for that is that we do it efficiently and properly and we target those most in need.

I also want to take issue with the honourable member when he continues to raise the matter that no child shall live in poverty. Everyone understands that what this Government had as a policy, as a principle and as its objective was the provision of assistance to families. When those opposite continue to criticise this Government because families--or parents, those within the family system--are not prepared to pass on that assistance, that is an unfair criticism. What this Government has done over the period 1983 to 1991 has been to implement a major change, a revamping of the welfare system, and this recent Budget continues that revamping, continues the improvements in the system and improves the efficiency.

Surely we cannot be held responsible if the mothers, fathers or others in families who get the assistance do not pass it on. But that is what those opposite are saying. They are criticising us because there are still children living in poverty. Do they want a socialist, communist system? Do they think that we should drag children away from parents who do not provide them with suitable care, who do not pass on to them the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, who do not use their rental assistance properly but instead go down to the pub weekend after weekend and blow the money? Surely that is not what those opposite are suggesting. Yet that is what they are saying every time they criticise us for the fact that there are still children living in poverty today, which I and all honourable members admit. But we do not have the capacity, nor do we have the right, to go into a family home and drag out those children because a parent is not carrying out his or her responsibilities.

I concur with many of the points made by the honourable member for Maranoa, and I understand where he comes from on these issues because I know the plight of the people and the deprivation that is taking place and the attitude where they just want to walk away because they have seen their life work being destroyed because of climatic conditions, and in some instances because of government policy. They just want to walk away from it all and throw up their hands. But I suggest to the honourable member that we are trying to address that. If the honourable member had taken extra time to read the detail of the Budget Papers he would know that as from 1 January the assets test pertaining to rural people will be increased significantly to $600,000. That is a massive increase because the present FAS limit is $347,500, excluding the family home. But as from 1 January it will rise to $600,000. I would like to go further with this; I think we ought to do it now; I do not think that we can wait until 1 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is what I am calling for.

—-The honourable member has not even given us recognition or credit for what we are doing. I suggest that the lift is desirable. It is much needed, but it is needed now. I have made that point publicly and I will pursue the matter further with the Ministers relevant to that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we are continuing to change the system. We are continuing to improve the welfare system so that it is efficient and targets those in need. The proposals that the Bill before the House picks up are matters that have been of concern to all members of parliament, that is, that we need to streamline and bring some sort of consistency, continuity and simplicity into the system of welfare provision. What we are doing here is joining together Austudy thresholds and FAS thresholds. We have at the moment a FAS threshold of $18,000, with $624 for each extra child, so a family earning under $18,000 and with one child will get FAS, and it goes up by $624.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Your Austudy hardship provision was a great deal meaner.

—-Let us deal with what we have to start with. At the moment the Austudy allowance is $19,300, so we have the difference between $18,000 and $19,300. The Austudy allowance will increase to $20,700 in the new year and we are going to make them the same. That is what we did when it came to what a pensioner could earn without having to pay tax. Originally, we had the stupid system where the Department of Social Security said that pensioners could earn $40, but if they earned more than $6 or $7 a week over that, they faced tax. So, after a lot of consideration in bringing the systems together, we overcame that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: We are targeting those who most need government assistance. The money is not coming from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) or from me. It is coming from all Australians. It is money that goes into the general pool and is then disbursed back to those who need it most. This Government has as its priority the giving of assistance to those who need it most.

In this Bill there is an increase of $2.50 in the child disability allowance. It is not much, but again it is an indication of our priority and our willingness to help those in need. We are also increasing the youth disability supplement. We are also picking up the gaps. On the one hand, we say to sole parents that we want them to go and study. We have given them an Austudy supplement for that purpose. But we also understand that sole parents have major problems if they enter a study course. They have to buy books, pay course fees and get equipment. So, understanding that problem, this Government is introducing a new up-front cash grant of $200 to solve that problem. But no credit, no recognition, of that is being given from the other side. Those opposite do not recognise that here is another problem, in the myriad of problems that exist out there in the fabric of society, that we are weaving back, fixing up and patching up. We are doing it properly. We have an understanding of the problem and we are doing something about it.

Again, in the independent young person category, for a long period young people below the age of 18 have faced the problem that, because they have not been employed, they could not access allowances such as Job Search and sickness benefit. They simply have not been able to do that because of this employment requirement. We are now changing that. We are now saying that, irrespective of whether someone has been employed, they now have a right to access this Job Search allowance. That is what this Government is about: having been made aware of problems, it acts on those problems.

We are making the welfare system fairer and more efficient. We are committed to maintaining policies that really raise the issue of compassion. We recognise the special needs and problems of the sick, the aged, the disabled, the unemployed, the low income families and, for that matter, families generally. With the family allowance, a family can now earn up to $65,161 and still get the family allowance, so we are targeting families generally and ensuring that we are doing what is best for Australian people.

What we are doing is in sharp contrast with our counterparts on the other side. One has only to look at the policies that have been enunciated and announced by them in recent documents. An article in the Bulletin magazine, written by David O'Reilly some weeks back, really exposed what the Opposition Liberal and National parties are about. They would cast on the scrap heap people who have been unemployed for nine months. They would privatise the delivery and provision of welfare services. They would remove the universality of the system. What it means is that, whereas at the moment one has a right in law to access, to gain sickness benefit or assistance by way of Austudy or whatever, that lot over the other side would leave it to the discretion of some welfare group. They would give some welfare group a lot of money and it would decide how much one gets and when one gets it.

Surely the people of Australia will not accept that proposition. But that is very much part of what the Liberal and National parties are about. They are also coming up with some brand new ideas, which I will mention later, such as the goods and services tax. I noticed that the Opposition spokesman on social security, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), mentioned in that article a retirement tax. We know that those European nations that have introduced a consumption tax, a goods and services tax or a value added tax also have this retirement tax. They charge people now for their future retirement. We do not do that. Yet about 23 per cent of all tax revenue in Europe comes from that retirement tax.

Those opposite have not talked about that when they have discussed their consumption tax and GST, but the honourable member for Dawson has let the cat out of the bag. He has exposed the hidden agenda. They are not only talking about a tax on everything that is eaten and worn, they are not only talking about removing the exemptions of sales tax from charities; they are talking about other taxes as well. I thank the honourable member for Dawson for his honesty and for his willingness to place on the record the other aspects of these propositions being put forward.

As I said before, we are about helping Australian people based on their needs. This is why we have introduced rent allowances, to try to subsidise or underpin those costs that people have to pay. At the same time, this Government has made sure that people in need have had telephone rebates and that through local authorities there have been rebates and subsidies on the rates and charges levied. The States have also pursued that line with rebates and subsidies on car registration. We have been trying and we continue to try to work to improve the lot of the low income person and those in need.

I went to a meeting the other day in Biloela and I was amazed to hear one person say that we had done nothing about tax. It seems to me that we do not get our message through out there, so I pulled out some figures just to show what tax changes have taken place. From July 1991 a single pensioner will now pay no tax whatsoever unless he or she earns over $9,789 a year. Under the previous Government such pensioners paid tax on everything they earned. Let us go back to some of the other changes for the employed person. A $15,000 income earner back in 1980 had to pay $3,673 tax. Today, under the Hawke Labor Government, it is $1,998.75--a drop of 45.6 per cent. For a person on $25,000 it is $3,205.21 less, a saving of $61.63 a week. For the person on $30,000 a year the tax has dropped from $10,508 to $6,594--very close to a $4,000 drop in tax in any one year. For people on $35,000, or around $680 a week, the tax has dropped from $13,111.72 in 1980 to $8,799.75--$83 less per week in tax.

We have also increased the threshold. So we have lowered the tax rates and we have increased the threshold. No-one now pays any tax unless he or she earns over $5,400. We have also ended the fringe benefit rorts--the entertainment deductions--and we have required substantiation and accountability. We have got tough with the system. We have got tough on those who have abused and misused the system, and at the same time we have redistributed the revenue available to government to help those who need it most.

I read a recent article that has gone right across Australia showing how effective we have also been in overcoming the problem of people who abuse the system. Hundreds of thousands of people have been caught because they failed to disclose other income, because they falsified their assets, or because they gave false numbers for the number of children they looked after--children who have left home and have been kept on the home list. They have used false names in their bank accounts and they have used false names for pensions and unemployment benefits. They have also had undeclared bank accounts. We are really cleaning up the system. It is not easy when there are people who will falsify forms. I believe the person I have used as an example came out of the taxation system. He got all these false declarations and false birth certificates, but they finally got him. The key here is that it is a deterrent to others. It is a deterrent to abuse and to rorting.

We now need to increase the work we are doing and the explanation of it. I came across a booklet the other day called Help the People in Country Areas, produced by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy through the Countrylink program. It is an excellent book. The reason I raise the issue is that some time ago I was in part of my electorate and a lady of 62 years of age came to me and asked whether she was eligible for a part pension or pension because of her age. She said she had thought about it two years ago but her friends and her husband said she was deserving of nothing. I followed the matter through. She should have been getting $80 per week for the last two years, but did not get it because she was ill-advised. Misinformation caused this problem for her. She missed out on that sort of money, something like $4,000 a year for two years, simply because of misinformation. So I welcome what we are doing through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and through the Department of Social Security. We need to do more of it. People need almost a university degree to understand some of the forms and documentation. The onus is upon us as a government to ensure that people are informed. We have to sit down and make sure that people find it worth while to apply.

I have had people say, `What's the use; I can't understand the forms; I don't know what to supply in terms of documentation of earnings or otherwise'. That has certainly been true with the family allowance supplement, where at the start hundreds of thousands of families did not take up their rights. That was money that could have helped raise the purchasing power of those families and improve their quality of life. So we need to do more about it; we need to ensure that people are informed. We also need to make sure that people are informed about the alternatives. This is the thing that really worries me. I think most Australians understand that we are getting to the issues; we are ensuring that the loopholes are being closed and that the needy and not the greedy are getting the assistance.

The real threat is an ideological one. It is not administrative; it is ideological. We have coming from those on the other side an attitude which is Australia's brand of Thatcherism, where they simply attack anything that is called welfare. They seem to put down people who are unemployed, people who are on pensions, people who have been disabled and people who are sick. They put them down all the time and make them lesser Australians. I will not cop it and other people in the Labor Party and those who support our position will not cop it, either.

Those on the other side intend to destroy the very fabric of the system of support that we have built up over many decades--built up also by the Menzies and the Frasers, who saw a need and tried to do something about it. They intend to destroy Austudy--fancy throwing out the concept of Austudy--and privatise university education so the rich get the best places. That is an abhorrent proposal, but it is part of the proposition being put forward by the Liberals and Nationals.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Absolute nonsense; totally wrong.

—-It is true. The honourable member ought to read what his own people are saying. I will send him a copy of the Bulletin magazine. He will see what his own spokesmen have said about Austudy. Let me go on. I mentioned the retirement tax. They want to destroy superannuation. With the plight that this country is in at the moment, for every person who is elderly and on a pension there are five people out there in the work force. Within 30 years, for every person who is on a pension there will be only two in the work force. We have to build now for a retirement system. The Opposition wants to cast aside and destroy everything we have done to bring about a superannuation system that is universal. It is amazing that, when we realise the importance of building up a national savings account and of pooling that money so people need not borrow from overseas but can borrow in Australia, so they can start to plan and save for their own retirement, those on the other side want to destroy it. Why? They have not explained why. They are simply saying no, no, no; they will have some other sort of system. Then there is the goods and services tax. If ever there was an attack on people who really cannot afford it--those people who are on low incomes, the superannuants, the charities--it is the GST.
—-You are wrong.

—-I will take up that point. I have only 30 seconds left, but let me take one example: the charities. At the moment the charities have tax exemption under the wholesale sales tax system. Under the Opposition's proposal they will pay tax on everything and, not only that, they will not be able to recover that tax, because it is really a VAT. Ultimately, the system is that the business person adds it to his price and sells it and gets the money back; but charities do not sell it, they give it away. If ever those opposite are going to hurt anybody, they are going to hurt hundreds of thousands of people out there who are directly helped by charities, and they are also going to hurt the charities themselves. I think it is amazing that some of those opposite, whom I know personally--and I know they care; they would not be in this job if they did not--are introducing such a policy. Shame on them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The forerunner of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, child endowment, came from the enlightened social laboratory that was Australia in the first decades after Federation. Child endowment and its successors are the only recognition of women's work in the home, the value of which has been estimated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics at between $142 billion and $154 billion in the production of gross domestic product, if we also take into account women's voluntary work. One of the early advocates of child endowment, A.B. Piddington, said in 1921:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a strict and even-handed canon of plain justice will recognise that the children of those engaged in industry have a right to maintenance from industry and that the mother who rears children for the future of industry and the State has a right to receive the only wage she ever asks--enough to enable her as society's trustee for nurture and education to discharge the duties of her trust.

Child endowment from the start was a radical proposal to transfer income to the mothers of dependent children, so severing the connection between wage fixation and family size and allowing adult male wage rates to be based on the needs of a married couple or a single man. Child endowment was also envisaged by its advocates as preparing the ground for equal pay for women by removing the problem of men's family responsibilities having to be allowed for in the wage. In fact, as a survey of women in manufacturing in 1928 found, 30 per cent of women were either helping to keep or keeping other family members. Child endowment acknowledged the separate rights of women and children to their own independent source of income.

A limited version of child endowment was first introduced for Commonwealth public servants in 1920 and later in New South Wales in 1927. While initially opposed by Labor governments, its value was recognised during the Great Depression. When unemployment was 33 per cent in 1932, the regular fortnightly payments to mothers meant sustenance for the unemployed.

National child endowment passed into law during the Second World War when it was introduced in 1941 to ensure that children were kept in stout boots and had food in their stomachs, despite the climate of austerity. It provided endowment direct to the mother at a flat rate of five shillings per week for each child other than the first child under the age of 16 years. This was at a time when the average wage in Australia was around #4 per week.
Labor leader John Curtin, speaking for the Bill introduced by the Menzies United Australia-Country Party coalition, said:

With this Bill we are, for the first time in the history of this country--except for the Maternity Allowance Act--writing into the statute book our realization of the national significance of family life. This is not a platitude--that means something. There never has been any doubt of the value of the services, infinite in variety and extent, which the family renders to the nation. Primarily, it is the source of national continuance; it has supplied the human material indispensable for the production of the means of subsistence; it provides for the replacement of the old and the dead, and is the sole guarantee for the redemption, in the future, of those obligations which previous and present generations have found it desirable to incur in order to enjoy the fullest obtainable measures of security, comfort and civilization.
Curtin said that there was:

. . . no device which can be regarded as an adequate substitute for actual cash in the mother's hands, for she, better than any agent of the state, is able to use what resources are available to the best advantage of the children.

At the time there were, of course, conservative critics who regarded child endowment as a subversion of men's role as family provider. What child endowment recognised pragmatically was that men were sometimes prone to drink away the household money or, even if wealthy, to retain that by keeping their purses closed, even to their own families.
Later Commonwealth child endowment legislation in 1966 was commended in terms acknowledging the importance of the payment to women. It stated:

We realized the enormous difference it would make to mothers, not only to have it paid to them. For many mothers this was the only money that they were entitled to in their own right and it gave them the first taste of economic independence.

Indeed, the main complaint raised with the Department of Social Security, as reported in the 1960s, was husbands' objections to their wives receiving and having money. In 1941 John Curtin applauded the principle enshrined in national child endowment that there be no means test. He said, and his words are worth remembering today:

This nation consists of not only physical but also human values. For too long we have failed to appreciate that human values have a paramount claim upon us, and indeed are more important economically than material ones.
Curtin's words were echoed by those of Harold Holt in introducing the Bill. Holt said:

Child endowment can be rightly considered as a profitable national investment. A free enterprise economy such as ours provides inadequate incentive for investment in persons as compared with things. This is because it is rarely possible for people who make investment in persons to profit from it. For this reason governments subsidize education. For this reason also the investment of the Commonwealth Government can be expected to make a high return in human happiness.

Over the years child endowment has been broadened to include the first child and children up to the age of 25 if still dependent students. Child endowment payments were at their peak value in 1950 when they represented 11 per cent of the basic wage and 7 per cent of average weekly earnings. In 1980 the value of family allowances for two children represented only 4 per cent of average earnings; for four children, the value of allowances was 9 per cent of average earnings.

Thus, until the advent of this Labor Government, a government of quite another complexion to that of John Curtin, child endowment was a universal payment to families that acknowledged the cost of families. The cost is high. It is estimated that the first year of a child's life costs around $9,000; disposable nappies alone cost between $600 and $1,000 a year; and infant formula costs $1,000. Teenagers cost the most, estimated at around $10,400 a year. Assuming that a mother loses $24,000 in annual salary, a household suffers a loss after having a child of some $35,000 a year. A 1988 study by the Australian National University estimated that the average woman lost $336,000 in earnings after having a child. Second and third children added further losses of $50,000 and $35,000.

The Hawke Government began to income test the family allowance in 1987, so turning what had been accepted as a universal payment in recognition of the costs of children into a social welfare benefit. In eight years of government the Hawke Government has disqualified 10 per cent of families from receiving the family allowance and its value is now only two-thirds of what it was in 1976. The current threshold of $62,057 for one child and an additional $3,104 for each further child is not princely if one considers the effect of high interest rates on home mortgages and small businesses throughout the 1980s. Small businesses still pay 24 per cent interest. High interest rates were the policy of this Labor Government, not of some natural disaster, something which the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) in speaking before me conveniently failed to mention when lauding the Government's tax policy.

I know, for example, of one doctor who supports a wife and three children. With a salary of around $70,000 he misses out on the family allowance but has to wear the punishing costs of working and living in Sydney. He has downgraded his home to find a home with a backyard to accommodate the romping of three small boys. His wife is unable to work because of the need to care for the children. Outside care of three children simply is not affordable, even if desirable. The family now has no car and the doctor walks to work at the hospital which is nearby. He says he cannot even think of putting up the $5,000 for a second-hand car. There are too many day to day expenses on top of the Sydney mortgage.

Taking another example, $62,000 is only two very ordinary salaries combined. Because of the hike in mortgage interest rates, hundreds of thousands of women have had to go back into the work force to help meet the mortgage repayments. This has been seen against the background of an enormous increase in the amount of income tax collected from ordinary Australians on very average salaries because of income bracket creep, which the honourable member for Capricornia also conveniently neglected to mention. Inflation puts them into even higher tax brackets.

Total taxation on individuals has more than doubled under this Labor Government, rising from $23 billion in 1982-83 to almost $51 billion in 1989-90. Inflation and wage restraint have meant that the real value of the average wage has fallen by as much as 10 per cent. Striking directly at people's purse strings in the shops and supermarkets, the wholesale sales tax, first introduced by the Scullin Government in 1930, has trebled in the eight years of this bankrupt Government--from $3.5 billion to $10.7 billion this year--as more and more items, including food and beverages such as orange juice, flavoured milk, ice-cream, biscuits and snack foods, have been quietly added to the list. Withdrawal of family allowance may be the last nail in the coffin for many Australian families.

To these trials this Government adds yet another. It now proposes to introduce an assets test on the family allowance from 1 January 1991, which sets a limit of $600,000 in assets, apart from the family home. The assets test which already exists on the family allowance supplement, and which targets Australia's lowest income earners, is to be further tightened, making it impossible for a family to shift ownership of assets into the name of any other family member in order to be eligible for the benefits. The assets limit is $347,500, apart from the family home.

The family allowance supplement applies to only about 7 per cent of Australian families. The threshold for this is to be grandly increased from $18,000 to $19,300 from 1 April 1992. Further, families with limited cash funds may continue to receive either if they fulfil certain hardship provisions. These provisions are draconian. People must have an income of no more than $13,078, the maximum pension rate for a couple, and they must have income amounting to not more than $624 per child receiving family allowance. They also have to satisfy the Department of Social Security that their estimate of income is correct. On top of this, a couple must have less than $10,000 in liquid assets and a single person must have less than $6,000. This clearly discriminates against both small businesses and farmers.

Between 50 and 75 per cent of farmers have incomes of over $13,000 and more than 50 per cent have capital investment in their farms of over $600,000. For many farming families the family allowance has been the difference between being able to afford to buy groceries or not. It is more difficult to pinpoint the effect on small business operators because of the dearth of statistics available. But what we do know is that the assets test is more likely to affect small manufacturers, who make up 97 per cent of some 37,600 manufacturing businesses Australia-wide.

Almost 54 per cent of the population live in households consisting of parents and children. Children are our future. Families cannot be expected to manage completely on their own. By eroding the support given to families, except those in the most depressed sector, the Government removes from women the choice of being able to afford to stay at home to raise young children. Many families are now making great sacrifices to allow one parent to stay at home with the children. They need all the help they can get. So too do those parents who have to work to support their children.

The virtue of the family allowance was that it did not distinguish between either group. The lack of support for ordinary Australian families creates horizontal inequity between those who have children and those in the same income tax bracket who do not. Under this Government, people have been effectively penalised for having children. We can claim a tax deduction for an overseas trip, yet we can claim nothing for the enormous expenses of raising children. Why do we rate children so lowly? The sole parent rebate and the dependent spouse rebate are not income tested. We can take out superannuation and, no matter what our income, get a tax deduction. Why should it be different for children?

Then there is the recognition of child endowment--and, later, family allowance--being made to women in their own right. Women are ill served by the Government's flight to superannuation. Tax rebates and deductions do not go directly to women and so cease to give women, particularly those working in the home, some small moiety of what they deserve for their efforts in building the economy. We must remember that economic systems should accommodate people; people should not accommodate mechanistic economic systems, which should only exist to facilitate the greatest human happiness.
John Curtin, the man whom the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pretends to eulogise, speaking of the child endowment legislation in 1941, said:

To the degree that this merging of each individual in the fate of the nation has been forced upon us by the state of the world, and to the degree that that brings us nearer to each other than has hitherto been the case, I hope that that approximation, between Opposition and Ministers. . . shall in this country, give to the children who are now being born, and the youth and mothers of Australia, the assurance that their needs at any rate shall be placed beyond the hazards of political controversy, and that no future government will deal with this legislation which we are now passing except to widen and improve it. We shall not retrace this step; no economic burden which this scheme imposes shall be regarded as insuperable. If economic trouble in the immediate future, or in years to come, should involve something being dispensed with, then there are a number of other economies which this country can afford to make with greater regard for the welfare of our citizens than any economy at the expense of legislation of this kind.

Instead, the Hawke Labor Government has reduced the extent of the application of family allowance and whittled away its substance. By 1993 it is to be further limited by being subsumed into the family allowance supplement.

Curtin's sentiments were noble and honest, but this Labor Government has given the lie to them. We need to help Australian families now. The Labor Government has failed for eight years and it fails again today. Only when the coalition taxation package is announced shortly will average Australian families find a package that supports them. In the meantime, I am reminded of a lampoon of the old chivalry towards women and children. A cartoon depicts women and children standing on the edge of a cliff. Someone calls out, `Women and children first'. That is the pass to which we have come in this country under the Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am happy to join the debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) has attacked the removal of universality of the family allowance on the ground that about 10 per cent of people are unable to get it. Do people who are on $60,000 a year really need the family allowance?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what has happened with the introduction of the family allowance supplement. In studies that were done well before the Hawke Government came into office, families with children were found to be among the poorest in the Australian community. At the moment, farming families are the poorest; they are the ones who need assistance. Instead of just a few dollars a week, these people are receiving up to $53 a week for a child. It is better to take the family allowance away from those who are on higher incomes--people with children do not need the family allowance if they earn $60,000 or more a year--rather than to take it away from people on very low incomes.

This is what happened: the poorer families with children got the benefit of the family allowance supplement. We got children out of the rut of subsistence feeding. I can remember when I was working in the community some 15 years ago visiting a family that was on a very low income and the children were eating bread and butter for their evening meal. Through the policies that have been introduced, we are getting them out of the rut of subsistence feeding, low achievement and early departure from school.

Families have been helped. John Curtin would have supported our policies, because in his day, when there was universality of family allowance, most people needed it. Today, there is a certain section of the community which needs help to get out of that rut of subsistence. It needs help to get out of the rut, and it is now being provided. I applaud the policies. Like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I was involved in the development of those policies. They have been successful.

We have helped the youth. Things have changed for young people. I can remember when young people were put out of their family home quite often, and I can recall when the Liberal-National Party Opposition in New South Wales was attacking the fact that young people were being supported when they left home, but they were not really looking into the reasons why young people were leaving home.

It is interesting that when the present Minister for Family and Community Services, Virginia Chadwick, became Minister she quickly realised that quite often when children left home it was because they were being abused, or it was because they were finding life extremely difficult in the home. They have to be catered for occasionally with accommodation. Just over the boarder from here in Queanbeyan, 21 young people were under bridges and on seats in parks in the middle of the cold winter that we members know about. That was intolerable. We have to get away from it. Now there is a youth refuge in Queanbeyan. Accommodation is being provided. Things have changed.

We have helped the ageing. We have developed on the reports that were made by the present Speaker and others on his committee so that we have got away from just institutionalising the retired, the older people. We have found that under the home and community care program we can actually keep them in their own homes longer if they want to stay there. There is plenty to do, plenty to improve on, but at least it is starting to happen.

Then there is the unemployed. What have we done for these people? I guess it has been harsh in some ways, but it has also been kind in others. Unemployed people, the jobless, are now finding that that is the case. Unlike the Opposition's policy which is to abolish unemployment benefits after nine months and say to them all, `You look after yourself from now on', we are balancing the taxpayers' desire to see their money efficiently spent by helping with the needs of the jobless. Through programs like Newstart, Job Search and Jobstart, we are able to get people back into work to a much greater extent than we were in the past. We are balancing the desire of the taxpayers with the needs of the jobless. Taxpayers said to us, `We are not happy with the way benefits are just being paid to someone. They are left on the dole and nothing happens'. So, from 1 July, the concept of the dole was abolished. A person cannot get the dole any more. Now he can go and get an allowance from the Commonwealth Employment Service and, after a year, maybe earlier, the Commonwealth Employment Service asks the recipient to come into one of its offices and come to an agreement with the Service.

Just recently I visited the Commonwealth Employment Service offices in Cooma, Queanbeyan and Batemans Bay. In each case I found that the people who were on Newstart were delighted with the fact that someone had taken the time to bring them into the office and actually go through a list of suggestions with them so that they could present themselves better for work and take a job if it is offered. Now the allowance is given under different arrangements. It gives the people more dignity, but also it says to the taxpayer, `Yes, we are spending your money properly. If a person refuses to cooperate, refuses to present himself properly, refuses to take a job when it is offered, then he is not entitled to the allowance'. But we do not see people starve. We help them, we make suggestions and we have an agreement with them. The concept of the dole is gone.

Then there is the disabled. Just a few weeks ago in this Parliament we were debating legislation relating to the disabled. What was the suggestion of the Opposition? It moved an amendment suggesting that we are not really going to help the disabled unless we introduce a goods and services tax. Has anyone ever seen anything more insulting? Most disabled people are on relatively low incomes. They will be the people who will be hurt by a goods and services tax. The goods and services tax is going to give them a tax where there has not been one before. If they have not been on a very high tax, they will be paying more with a goods and services tax. Everything--things such as food, bread, milk and clothing--will be taxed under the goods and services tax. The last thing the disabled would want is the acceptance of the Opposition's amendment for a goods and services tax to help the disabled. It certainly would not help the disabled.

Of course, the goods and services tax is being introduced by the Opposition as a proposal which will help everyone. The Opposition even introduces it, as I said, when we are talking about people who are poor, people who are on low incomes. I ask the Opposition: What about the disabled? It should think about the disabled when it is actually formulating its policy on a goods and services tax. What about people on low superannuation, people who are not on a pension, but who are receiving superannuation? What about people in the country? A small country store might charge, say, 60c or 70c more for an item than, say, a supermarket in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Hobart or even Darwin. They may charge a little more. Every time that person pays an extra 60c or 70c in the country, he is paying a goods and services tax on the extra 60c and 70c; he is paying more.

The goods and services tax is going to be a day of reckoning for the National Party. The National Party ought to be considering just where its alliances should be, because we are going to reach the situation in Australia, I believe, where it is going to be forced by its constituency to think about where its alliances are and whether it really should be aligned with the economic rationalists on the other side who really are not interested in anything but user pays.

The Opposition's goods and services tax will hurt everybody. Of course, it says that it will be adjusting pensions to cater for the tax. If we recall what happened under the Fraser Government when CPI increases were refused to pensioners, we cannot be all that sure that pensioners will get that sort of adjustment. To talk about introducing a goods and services tax when it will cost three times as much to collect the same amount as is being collected by the wholesale sales tax at the moment seems to me to be pointless, from an economic as well as a social justice point of view.

The honourable member for Menzies called this Government bankrupt. He has called it bankrupt when it is having its first deficit in years. Unlike any Howard Budget when Dr Hewson was there assisting the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) as Treasurer, this Government has been many years in the black. Now we can afford a deficit. We need to have a deficit because we need to make a calculated decision to protect the less fortunate who have been hurt by a range of problems. These are not only the recession because of over $6 billion less coming into Australia for the sales of our commodities overseas--and this spreads to all our industries--but also because of problems like drought and the recession that has crept into the country and crept through the cities. So we have to protect the less fortunate, not least those who are in country areas. It is fortunate that we are having a deficit. I certainly do not accept the Opposition's proposal that we should go back into the black in this time of difficulty. Australia is a country which has great resources and can afford to have a deficit.

Of course there are things that we need to do. We need to look again at the family allowance supplement and the fringe benefits tax that is paid by pensioners. I would say to the Government that we should be considering allowing fringe benefits to apply to all people who are on a pension, even a part pension. I include the fringe benefits that come from local government and State government. This will involve, of course, discussions between the State and Federal governments, because travel, rates and telephone charges can all be involved in the provision of fringe benefits, as can pharmaceutical benefits. It is important that we discuss the ramifications with the States and with local government representatives; perhaps the Federal Government could come up with payments to improve the accessibility of fringe benefits to people who are on even part pensions.

Opposition backbenchers, including the honourable member for Menzies have come into this Parliament trying to paint the Liberal and National parties as compassionate parties. The people of Australia will not wear it. When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was attacking the Australian Council of Social Service, he could not have been attacking the administration of ACOSS, because that is a skeleton staff, and he could not have been attacking the constituent organisations--the Salvation Army, St Vincent de Paul, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and others--because they have very small, skeleton staffs.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition was really attacking the people on your street and mine--the people who work for the community, for those who are in need: the Salvation Army, the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Smith Family, family support organisations, a wide range of organisations supporting Aboriginal people and a wider range of organisations supporting women and migrants.

These are the people he was attacking and accusing of empire building. If they were responsible for 1 per cent of the empire building that occurs on both sides of this House, I could understand it. This is the sort of place where empire building is happening--not the social service organisations. To tell those organisations that they are empire building is an absolute disgrace. How can any honourable member of parliament go into an organisation of that kind and accuse its members of empire building when it is giving wonderful service throughout our community. Just because those organisations are getting together and becoming a political force in this community is no reason to accuse them of empire building.

This legislation makes some constructive proposals for sole parents, which were outlined by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). Those proposals are for Job Search allowance, sickness allowances, adjustment for child disability allowance of $2.15 and provision to allow 13 weeks from date of birth to claim various types of allowances. They also include the establishment of a hardship test to protect families with assets above the family allowance and the family allowance supplement thresholds where they are producing very low income. This was done through Government members, a very high proportion of whom are from country areas. We made sure that country people were assisted as far as possible.

In addition, the income threshold at which full family allowance supplements are payable will be aligned with the Austudy threshold, another very important measure. There will also be modification of the assets test to allow primary producers to deduct liabilities which relate to the carrying on of primary production from the value of assets used in that production, which is to commence on 1 January, and modification of the rules for assessing notional ordinary income within the hardship provisions, so that owners of residential premises that are occupied by family members in certain situations will not be penalised because the premises do not attract commercial rates of rent.

It is extremely important that we acknowledge that these measures are being taken. In relation to rent assistance, the waiting period for recipients of allowances will be reduced from 26 weeks to 18 weeks; that will commence on 20 March 1992. There are also a number of changes to the disability reform package.

It is extremely important that we make the point that, whatever happens, whatever the proposals, whatever Opposition backbenchers say in this debate, the evidence is there in the attitudes of their leaders: they believe in making everyone pay; they do not believe in relieving people's problems; and they certainly do not support the Government's concept of assisting those in need so that they can achieve better things as they grow older.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I address a question to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. Is the Minister aware of claims that the Government has cut funds for higher education? Can he advise the House on the validity of such claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

Some of those reports have included the claim that the Commonwealth's funding for higher education has been cut. That is an obviously untrue proposition. I will give honourable members the actual figures. Since this Government came to office, the real level of higher education funding has increased every year. It went up by 33.4 per cent in real terms between 1983 and 1991, and up by 22.4 per cent between 1987 and 1991. Of course, this accompanied large increases in student intakes, of planned load, which is up by 101,000 effective full time student units between 1983 and 1991 and by 56,600 EFTSU between 1987 and 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that, for a period, growth in student numbers outstripped the total level of funding, leading to some decline in the level of funds per effective full time student unit. The Government acknowledged this problem and has put in train a number of decisions designed to correct that situation. Going back to 1987, when things really reached their trough, and looking at planned loads since 1987, we see that funding per EFTSU has risen by 2.7 per cent.

More significantly, I would like to draw the attention of the House to the set of decisions taken by the Government in the last three months to address the situation in higher education and to ensure that we get not only a large higher education system providing opportunities for a very large number of potential students but also one which provides a quality education. In the Budget, the Government announced major new decisions over and above the normal rolling triennial arrangements. As honourable members would be aware, the Government provides funding for higher education on a rolling triennial basis. In a policy statement on quality and diversity which I made last week, I announced an additional $169m for 1994--$70m for quality assurance and enhancement, $41m for further growth, and $58m in additional capital funding. That brings total capital funding for 1994 to $270m, which is getting to a pretty high level historically. Overall, in the course of the 1992-94 triennium, we are committing $12 billion to higher education, which takes us above the 1 per cent of GDP benchmark which the AVCC, among others, has set.

—-I direct my question to the Acting Treasurer. Is he aware of the claims that Australians are world masters at cheating the tax system? Can he advise the House whether these claims are valid. Apart from the introduction of capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, full substantiation of deductions, disallowance of entertainment expenses and action on tax havens, does the Government intend to introduce any additional measures to change the Australian tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware of this rather amazing and insulting claim to the Australian public that was made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition last month. He denigrated the Australian people by saying that they were the world masters at tax cheating. He based that claim on his assessment of the black economy, that is that part which has unreported income for tax purposes, as being about $40 billion. He based that estimate of $40 billion on work that was conducted by Dr Neville Norman of Melbourne University for the year 1983-84 and on some work which is contained in the draft White Paper on the consumption tax prepared in 1985, updating that to the current income levels.

ANSWER.PARA: That type of analysis is totally invalid because since 1983-84 and 1985 there has been a major transformation of the income tax system. As the honourable member for Dobell mentioned in his question, a vast number of steps have been taken both in the area of base broadening, that is, to bring to account for income tax purposes income that was previously exempt from tax, and in eliminating tax evasion directly bearing on the black economy. Consequently, the tax system today contains far less tax avoidance and evasion than prevailed pre-1985.

I will quickly remind the House of the kinds of steps that have been taken since 1985: the introduction of the capital gains tax, which will raise about $700m this year, opposed by the Opposition; the fringe benefits tax, which will raise about $1,300m this year, opposed by the Opposition; the resource rent tax, which will raise about $735m this year, opposed by the Opposition; the abolition of the deduction of entertainment expenses, an estimated $300m this year, opposed by the Opposition; reform of the taxation treatment of foreign income; improved substantiation; total reform of the system of prescribed payments, which we introduced in 1983 and have completely revised to make it bear more directly and more effectively on this area of the black economy; the introduction of the tax file number, again related directly to the black economy; the establishment of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, very clearly aimed at the black economy; and increased activity in auditing by the Australian Taxation Office, again focusing on areas where there is suspicion of substantial amounts of unreported income.

In other words, through all of these measures since 1985 there has been a very substantial amount of change to the tax system. It is a vastly reformed system with a much broader base for income tax purposes and it more effectively focuses on areas which previously were able to escape taxation through tax evasion. It is ridiculous to say that we will update some study done in 1983-84 or 1984-85 and come to some assessment as to what the black economy is today, ignoring all the things that have been done since then.

The Opposition is about beating up the black economy to create a magic pudding, a source of additional revenue that it can claim will be brought to account through the introduction of a GST. It is very much aware that a GST will be inherently very unpopular. I understand that in Canada it is known as the gouge and screw tax. To sweeten up this gouge and screw tax measure, the Opposition is trying to maximise offsetting tax cuts by pretending that it will be able to tap some vast fiscal dividend by applying the GST to the black economy. This is clearly a nonsense. The fiscal dividend which was referred to in 1985 came mostly from the areas that have since been attacked by the base broadening measures; that is, it is already subject to tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How do you know that?
—-Order! The member for Flinders.
—-That is laughable. How do you know that?
—-I warn the honourable member for Flinders.
—-The honourable member should stop laughing. It is absolutely right and he knows it. He has been engaging in a massive exercise in deception.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same tax seminar, where the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was lambasting the Australian people as tax cheats and beating up his claims about the amount of untaxed income in Australia and saying that GST was the answer to that, there was evidence given that the GST was not going to be the solution to providing this magic pudding. The Courier-Mail of 17 September, having reported the honourable member for Flinders in the terms that I have mentioned, stated:
His insistence on this came despite warnings from New Zealand and Canadian consumption tax experts that such a tax in their countries had not resulted in windfall revenue from the black economies.

The reality is that there is no magic pudding. Attempts by the Opposition to base tax cuts on the assumption that there is one would clearly be reckless, irresponsible and an attempt to deceive the Australian public on a grand scale.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Can the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development inform the House whether recent analysis of Australia's export performance indicates a longer term structural change in Australia's pattern of trade in manufactured products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for Perth for his question. It gives me the opportunity to look at this issue in perspective for a slightly longer time than is usually possible in the hurly-burly of this place. We can say with confidence that there is now evidence that the obvious growth in manufacturing exports in this country is not a temporary by-product of the recession, as has sometimes been alleged, but is now a permanent feature of a changed Australian economy. A recent analysis undertaken by Treasury shows strong and durable growth in manufactured exports throughout the last six years. All the evidence therefore points to a structural change having taken place in Australia's pattern of trade rather than simply temporary or cyclical factors. I want to look at the evidence for that.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, over the last six years there has been very strong growth in elaborately transformed manufactured exports, which has accelerated in the last three years. The result of that is that in 1989-90--the last year for which we have complete trade statistics--$7.63 billion came from elaborately transformed manufactured exports. In one standard method of categorisation, that makes them the chief source of export values in that year. When we add to those elaborately transformed manufactures simply transformed manufactures, such as iron, steel and aluminium, we get a total for 1989-90 of $12.3 billion in those exports, which is 21 per cent of total exports of goods and services. The evidence for last year, 1990-91--we have only the first three quarters--shows that those manufactured exports are up some 20 per cent over the first three quarters of that financial year.

Not only have we had this strong and durable growth, but we have also had a very significant shift in the markets to which those manufactured exports are going. Since 1983-84, the market for Australian manufactured exports has increasingly shifted towards the Asia-Pacific region. In 1983-84, the European Community was the dominant place to which those exports went. It has now been surpassed by Japan, which is our largest single market, at least for simply transformed manufactures. The rest of north-east Asia comes in second, with the European Community now in third place. In relation to exports of simply transformed manufactures, those to the ASEAN region have increased by 180 per cent in the last six years.

If we look at the figures internationally, we see that between 1985 and 1989, Australia's manufacturing export volumes grew by 79 per cent, and this compares with a 31 per cent growth in the rest of the OECD. Indeed, if we look at ourselves in relation to the G7 nations, we see that only the United States has had a bigger growth than Australia in manufactured exports over that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What about Thailand, Taiwan and Korea?

—-Despite the dribbling noises from the Leader of the Opposition, we can draw some fundamental conclusions. Firstly, contrary to popular myth, Australia's manufacturing sector has steadily increased in both output and exports since 1983-84 and, secondly, an increasing and significant proportion of these manufacturing exports is going to north-east and South East Asia, and despite the difficulties that the manufacturing industry has faced in the recession period, in general this sector has responded vigorously to the challenge of becoming more internationally competitive. Let me say that no single trend is more significant for the transformation of our trading performance and for our growing international competitiveness than that particular trend.

—-My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister.
