Senator Button responded in the following terms: `I think the answer to that question would probably be yes'. I ask, as I did before: does he agree or not agree with Senator Button?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Let me make a couple of things clear.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-As the honourable member will not ask me the question but asks a Minister who manifestly is not responsible for the administration of the Broadcasting Act--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Dundas! The honourable member for Gilmore!

—-What the honourable member is now dealing with front and centre is the Broadcasting Act. Let me just explain one or two things to him because I am amazed by the extent to which there is, in general commentaries in this place, a lack of understanding of the operations of the Broadcasting Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Broadcasting Act means this: if the Tourang bid were to establish what the honourable member has described as an unacceptable concentration of media ownership, it would do so only in one circumstance. That would be the circumstance in which the investment by Mr Packer in it is something more than simply an investment vehicle. If it were, via the process of the Tourang bid, an instrument for his control or influence over the operations of the Fairfax group, it would be manifestly in breach of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's rules on the subject of cross-media ownership.

What tends to be not well understood in the debate to this point is that there are two elements in the cross-media propositions under the broadcasting rules. One is permission to people who have newspapers or people who have television stations to invest in the other operation to the tune of less than 15 per cent. That is one element. The second element is that no person who has so invested, be it to the extent of 2, 3, 4 or 14.9 per cent, and who has, via that process, a capacity to influence or control, will be permitted to do so. If he does so, he will find himself in breach of the Broadcasting Act and therefore will be obliged to divest.

I might say that there are some remarkable inconsistencies in the Opposition on this question. When this was debated in the House the other day, for example, the right honourable member for New England put the question to the Government on precisely this point, in which he opposed the changes that we were making to the Broadcasting Act and are before the Senate. He said:

I strongly put it to the House that it would be far better for us to defer this legislation. In that climate, each of the bidders can put in their bids before the event. They can take note of the fact that there is a debate in the Labor Caucus and that the Parliament will be dealing with legislation, although they will not know what it will be.
He was following some of the views expressed by the Opposition spokesman when he said that. He also had one or two other things to say. He said:
I happen to be a person who is against cross-media ownership restraints.
He further said:

It does not really matter whether caucus says it is an arbitrary 20 per cent and how the 20 per cent is defined and whether it is equity or non-equity or quasi-equity. It is essentially a matter which the FIRB and the Treasury look at in relation to what they see as being in the public interest.
So the Opposition position on this sort of thing seems to change on almost an hourly basis, if not a daily basis.

I might say that I am pleased because it seems that, as a result of discussions we had in Question Time here yesterday, the legislation that has been put up to the Senate is now not going to be deferred but is going to start through the committee process on Wednesday afternoon. The mere introduction of that Bill by the Government a couple of weeks ago has clearly had a very substantial impact on the way in which Fairfax bidders have approached the position that they might find themselves in under the Broadcasting Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question was a simple question directed to the Acting Prime Minister, and it is now being answered by another Minister. The question was whether he agrees or disagrees with the statement by Senator Button in the Senate today. I ask that you direct the Minister to answer the question that was put to him.
—-The question that the honourable member for Bass asked canvassed a fairly large preamble, and the Minister is answering the question that was raised.

ANSWER.PARA: The point that I would make and reiterate here is that I think it is about time that some people made some studies of that because, as I was saying before I was interrupted by the Manager of Opposition Business, quite clearly in the events that have unfolded over the last couple of days, the fact that the Broadcasting Tribunal is investigating those matters is clearly having an effect on the way in which people approach the whole issue of the cross-media rules.

So the point is this: if a bid by Tourang were to produce a situation in which an owner of television stations, irrespective of the level of his investment in the vehicle, was in a position to control and influence the operation of the Fairfax group, it would be ultra vires the Broadcasting Act. It will be much easier for us to see that situation properly reviewed by the Broadcasting Tribunal if the Bill that we have put before this House, so disparaged by Opposition spokesmen when we did it, is allowed to pass through the Senate in as rapid order as possible.

—-I direct my question to the Acting Prime Minister. Has he seen recent reports of the state of the housing industry? Can he advise the House whether the bringing forward of payments to the States under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement would provide a substantial stimulus to the housing sector? Is it intended that such a course be followed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government announced in March that it would accelerate payments to the States under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement at a cost of $25m. In August this year I wrote to the State and Territory Ministers agreeing to their proposals for expenditure of accelerated payments under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. So the funds in total of $842m are being paid to the States in two payments in the first half of the financial year instead of monthly as has previously been the case. Obviously, the offer, in a situation in which the housing industry has reflected the overall economic downturn, is designed to boost activity by enabling the States to bring forward those programs. In return, State and Territory Ministers agreed to bring forward projects which continue to keep apprentices in employment, use the financial benefits of early payments on their housing programs and bring forward projects consistent with achieving higher urban density and better cities.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, the States and the Territories are accelerating the levels of activity in the public housing sector. New South Wales has agreed to more than double its planned level of activity in the first half of this financial year from 500 commencements to 1,230. Western Australia has agreed to double its public rental housing commencements in the first half of this financial year from 200 to 400. Queensland has made a similar commitment to bring forward about 300 additional housing commencements on its planned program, and South Australia, the honourable member's State, has increased its planned commitment by an additional 100 dwellings.

Each of those shifts, occurring within the context of the Commonwealth's initiative, has had an effect in terms of helping to smooth out activity at a time of downturn in the housing industry. It is occurring at a time when there has been a trough in the housing industry, but we can see the signs now of recovery. The Indicative Planning Council expects that to be not only a reasonably strong recovery in this financial year, but very much stronger in the next financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I ask whether the Minister's attention has been drawn to a press conference yesterday in which a Mr Peter Jones, a member of Senator Vallentine's staff, asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Why spend $200m on the Defence Science and Technology Organisation when it is reported to have been producing cluster bombs?

What contribution does the DSTO make to Australia's security and in particular to the Government's objective of greater self-reliance in our defence policy, and what evidence is there of community support for that objective?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am sorry that in answer to the question by the honourable member for Brisbane I have to disappoint the Australian Democrats. As has been noted, it is not for the first time. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation does not produce and does not export cluster bombs. It is true that in the early 1980s the organisation did develop a prototype bomb and a small number of those were produced for trialing by the RAAF, but the bomb did not go into production, was not for export and was not exported.

ANSWER.PARA: What we do export is some of DSTO's state of the art expertise in this and related fields. For example, as many honourable members know, Australia currently has an Army team in Pakistan which is operating as part of a United Nations mine clearance training team. Another example is that Army personnel and DSTO scientists have been very instrumental in the efforts being made by the United Nations to monitor Iraq's chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs and activities, again as part of the Gulf war cease-fire provisions. We have peacekeepers in the Western Sahara and we are preparing to send a major peacekeeping mission to Cambodia, the largest such mission in a long time. So the ability to respond to aggression is only part of our defence posture; working to secure peace is an equally important part.

We spend $200m-plus a year on DSTO because it plays an absolutely essential role in guaranteeing Australia's security. In a large, sparsely populated continent we are dependent on maintaining and developing sophisticated state-of-the-art surveillance, transport and communications technologies. To do that we need an organisation like DSTO. Its expertise is crucial in achieving that, and a lot more into the bargain.

Let me give a few examples of the exceptional technologies that DSTO has produced: the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar, which for the first time provides a radar sweep over the vast sea-air gap to our north; the special steel which made possible the manufacture, in the electorate of my good friend the honourable member for Port Adelaide, of the Collins class submarines, the first of which will be completed in 1993; and the advanced boron patching system for the repair of aircraft skins and superstructures, which has already saved Australia something like $700m through life extensions of aircraft. That technology, I might point out to the House, is now being exploited commercially through a joint venture, and it looks like having a very large market in the United States and other countries over the next five years. Another example is the laser airborne depth sounder which will enable us to map our coastal waters something like 25 years faster than if we used conventional means. A further example is the Kariwara towed arrays for surface combatants which enable them to detect other vessels, including submarines, at great distance--another technology which we are hopeful of exporting.

That is far from an exhaustive list. I might mention to every member of this House that in the mural hall there is an engineering exhibition of excellence, in which DSTO has an exhibit, and I really recommend that people go and have a look at that exhibition. They will see that DSTO, as a result of commercialising its technologies, has pushed into Australian industry, not just the defence industry, contracts which are worth $1.8 billion.

They are a few reasons why Australia should be happy to spend $200m on DSTO. I conclude by answering the second part of the honourable member's question, which related to community support for the Government's objectives of defence self-reliance. I will just mention one index of that. The Prime Minister launched in Brisbane just 10 or 12 days ago the Ready Reserve, the new form of reserve service for young Australians. Over the period from 2 October, when that was launched, to 14 October--nine working days--Defence received 8,842 inquiries about the new scheme and over 1,600 applications. I might add that 50 per cent of those inquiries were from the honourable member's home State of Queensland. I cannot think of a better demonstration of the fact that young people are prepared to serve their country and to respond enthusiastically to new forms of service which are tailored to meet their lifestyles and expectations, and I believe it is a ringing endorsement of this Government's defence policy.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have received a letter from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The devastating impact of the Government's policies on young people of Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Almost everyone in Australia has been hurt by this recession that we are told we had to have, but no one group has been affected more than Australia's youth. The promise on youth poverty by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is notorious, and it is to the youth of this country that he should apologise. Young people today are having to cope with enormous pressures. There is amongst them an unprecedented pessimism about the future, and for many the future is indeed bleak. Young people today are having to cope with drugs and AIDS, the breakdown of the family unit, concerns for the future of the natural environment, the tensions of a changing population mix and a lack of confidence in government. Indeed, they question the relevance to them of the whole political process.

SPEECH.PARA: They are also concerned about the availability of jobs and the post-Depression record youth unemployment, the inability of the tertiary education system to meet demand and, finally, the dire straits which the Australian economy is in.

Young people are indeed the `casualties of change', as Richard Eckersley said in his 1989 report for the Commission for the Future. As Professor Philip Hughes of the University of Tasmania wrote in February 1991:
The social environment for young people is one of tension and uncertainty.

But there is not only tension for young people. There is, of course, great tension for their parents as they attempt to contend, alongside their children, with the enormous problems facing this country.

The future of this country depends on its youth. It would be unreasonable to blame the Hawke Government for every problem faced by young people today. However, the Government has exacerbated the problems, and its policies have contributed to the extent of them. The Government has clearly mortgaged the future of young Australians. It has plunged this country into enormous debt. Net debt in June 1991 was $130 billion, representing 34 per cent of GDP. By some estimates, this net debt will rise to almost $240 billion by June 1996, and that represents 44 per cent of GDP. As we attempt to cope with this debt our living standards will continue to fall.

Young people are rightly concerned that they have the responsibility of wrestling with this enormous problem. They find it very difficult to understand that this Government's solution is in part a willingness to sell off just about anything in an attempt to stem the tide, but even this is to no avail.

Young Australians are clearly at the cutting edge of this Government engineered recession. Ten years ago, 42 per cent of those aged 15 to 19 had full time jobs. Now the figure is 22 per cent, and next year it will be 15 per cent. Recent surveys have shown that employment is the No. 1 concern among Australia's youth. Youth unemployment, currently at around treble the adult rate, has reached post-Depression record levels.

However, in the present recession the collapse in employment for young Australians is far greater than the unemployment figures actually indicate. The real unemployment figure among those aged 15 to 19 is closer to 40 per cent. Many young people are staying at school longer and this, to a large extent, disguises the extent of unemployment. There is, of course, also mounting underemployment for young people as part time work has increased from 17 per cent to 37 per cent in 10 years, as 236,000 full time youth jobs have just disappeared, 70 per cent of that figure in the last two years.

One must ask how many of the 230,000 secondary students on Austudy are actually on a de facto unemployment benefit. Of course, the Government maintains that an increased participation rate in post-compulsory education is one of its major successes. However, this clouds the real issue. Clearly many young people are staying at school longer because they have no prospect of getting a job; in many ways, the education system has failed to respond adequately to the needs of these young people who remain at school beyond the compulsory years.

The real sting, however, is in the fact that these increased retention rates have created an expectation for higher education which simply cannot be met. At the moment, 30,000 qualified Australian students are locked out of tertiary education at the same time as 15,000 full fee paying overseas students are admitted, and this, as the Industry Commission observed recently in a report, is a serious inequity.

Clearly, funding of the higher education system has failed to keep pace with the enormous growth in student numbers. In per student terms, funding has decreased by 30 per cent since 1975, and no amount of gobbledegook by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), in answering a question along these lines in Parliament earlier this afternoon, can alter this particular fact. Universities are overcrowded and underfunded and each of us with a university in our electorate is aware of the extent of this problem. Also, enrolments at TAFE colleges have fallen disastrously and vocational training in Australia is extremely low compared with the OECD average.

Young people in our society are alienated. This Government's policies have now created a situation where there is a real risk that we will have two separate societies of young people. We will have those who have and those who have not. There will be those who have in education and those who have not. There will be those who have jobs and those who do not have jobs. Many will have neither, and may never have.

I ask the Government what future there is for these people. Only an expectation, I suppose, that the welfare system will provide. But what sort of solution is that to this problem? There are, of course, even those who have homes and those who have not. The Burdekin report, with which many honourable members will be familiar, estimated that there were between 25,000 and 70,000 homeless young people in this country. Government policy has failed to address even this important problem.

One of the most telling indicators of the increased stress and pressure on Australian youth is the marked increase in the incidence of youth suicide. One in every seven deaths of males aged 15 to 19 is caused by suicide. In 1966 the corresponding figure was one in 20. In 1988 there was one teenage suicide every 46 hours in Australia. The period of increasing youth suicide strongly correlates with the high youth unemployment rate. Unemployment in general, and prolonged unemployment in particular, is associated with low self-esteem and with emotional, economic and psychological insecurity.

Many of today's young people have grown up in welfare dependent families. Studies in the United States have clearly indicated that welfare dependence is passed on. The average family in Australia is now considerably worse off than it was in 1983. There are almost 400,000 single parent families in Australia. Most of these are headed by women, and most of these women are living on welfare. There are more than 500,000 children who have at most one parent. There is a desperate need to keep families together. Family breakdown in our society is endemic. Almost one in three marriages ends in divorce. Government programs to address this particular social problem have clearly also been inadequate.

The future for the young people of Australia is clearly at risk. Young people have been badly treated by this Government. They have been given unreasonable and unattainable expectations of an education. There are very limited full time job opportunities available to them. There is a drastic need for a new direction. Coalition policies will provide this direction. They will give hope to young people. They will provide young people with a vision for the future. Young people today are clearly worse off than they were in 1970 or 1980. We want them to be better off by the year 2000.

There is a desperate need for a whole new approach to taxation which will restore the incentive for people to work. There is a clear need for a new industrial relations system where productivity becomes the criterion for wage increases. Unless youth wages are related to productivity, they will continue to suffer and, particularly in times of recession, youth jobs will be amongst the first to go.

Union activities which have sustained relatively high youth wages have had a disastrous impact on the availability of jobs for young people. Young people are not stupid. They understand the balance between the need to preserve the environment and to create jobs. They recognise hypocrisy when they see it in decisions such as those the Government took in relation to the mining of Coronation Hill and Wesley Vale. They recognise crass politics when they see it. They see through the Government's mickey mouse job creation schemes and training programs. They have little respect for politicians. Why should they? Politicians are largely responsible for the mess which Australian people see in the country today.

I believe it will be an absolute priority for the Opposition when it comes to government to address the concerns of young people in our society. We, the Opposition, have listened to them, and we are listening to them. Unfortunately, however, a great deal of damage has been done in the last nine years, since this Government came to office. It will in many respects be a very difficult task for us to reverse much of this damage, but there is no doubt in my mind that the future of young people in Australia depends on developing policies which address the needs and concerns of young people.

This MPI condemns the Government for the policies it has developed, the things it has done and the things it has not done which have impacted so heavily on the young people of Australia. This Government has clearly failed everyone in Australia, but it has particularly failed the young people of Australia. Its legacy to the young people of this country, a legacy of failure, unfortunately will affect Australia and the society of this country for many years. This Government has failed the young people of Australia, but we will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-During Question Time on any day, including today, any question in this House that relates to the portfolios of Education, Employment and Training, Higher Education and Employment Services, Community Services and Health, and Social Security more often than not is met with derision by Opposition members. Yet those are the very portfolios which impact on children and youth, the very portfolios which, by the actions of those opposite, appear to be held in contempt. The Australian electorate will measure this Opposition and its policies on youth as it did in 1983, 1984, 1987 and 1990. The Opposition will be measured and duly rejected by the Australian electorate. The rhetoric of Opposition members simply does not match their actions on matters that affect youth in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In this debate, Opposition members have espoused policies of the lowest common denominator. That display, quite clearly--for all to see--is a very convenient and selective reflection by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) of history in this nation. The intellectual content of discussions about youth in this House, in terms of a taxonomy of educational objectives for youth, reflects the lowest common denominator--that of the lowest intellectual skill by a concentration of knowledge and specific facts and processes. Perhaps even that is not totally correct, as indeed there is very little reference to any process whatsoever. Where is the rationale, the vision and the philosophy of what has been stated here today by Opposition members? They have to do more than just mention words. Where are the processes, the mechanisms, the means and the facilitation congruent with a vision? As one would expect, they are totally absent.

The comments made in this House today by the honourable member for McPherson are purely outcome driven and task driven, with no reconciliation with vision or progress. They are totally reliant upon the recall of facts that are very selective and specific but without great substance. Education of our young--as the honourable member for McPherson acknowledged--should not be simplistic and of the lowest common denominator. Goals set should be long term, and the attainment of them will take a generation. If we are serious, and if the honourable member for McPherson and those opposite are serious--and we ought to be--we at least ought to acknowledge that. Those goals for our young must be more substantive than just a reliance on the selective factual information given today by the honourable member for McPherson.

Educational objectives include insight, translation, prediction, comprehension, interpretation, analysis and synthesis--goals that are totally absent in the thinking of Opposition members. The Opposition's recipe for our youth in the 1990s and into the twenty-first century is a repeated recipe for failure, because the Opposition's approach is totally outcome driven and it ignores rationale and process. It is a guaranteed recipe for failure that the Opposition offers the young in this country.

I will repeat several points I have made in another debate in this House because I believe they are relevant to this debate. There is no doubt that every thinking, rational Australian is concerned about the current youth unemployment levels in this country. There is no doubt that for the same thinking, rational Australians there still exists a vast gulf between the thinking of the Government and that of the Opposition.

It is an informative exercise to put the track record of the Opposition up to scrutiny. In 1968 the OECD made significant recommendations to the Australian Government to significantly lift its game in retention rates and participation in higher education and vocational training. It was not the Labor Party that ignored those recommendations that Australian governments should do that so that Australia could take its rightful place in the world. It was not the Labor Party that increased the retention rates in our schools from a miserly 25 per cent to 36 per cent in 15 years. It was not the Labor Party that virtually ignored vocational training, treated TAFE as a second-class citizen and ignored higher education places for disadvantaged people.

It was not the Labor Party that had a resource policy based on agriculture and mining and not the resource that is placed between one's ears. It was not the Labor Party that in Malcolm Fraser's days, when unemployment and inflation were 10 per cent, referred to people who were unfortunate enough to be unemployed as dole bludgers. It was not the Labor Party that called, as some Opposition members are doing, for the abolition of training programs such as Skillshare.

It is not the Labor Party calling for the abolition of student income support in the form of Austudy. It is not the Labor Party calling for the abolition of unemployment benefits after nine months. It is not the Labor Party calling for a $3 billion cut in expenditure in health, welfare and education, the very portfolios that impact on women and youth.

I point out to the honourable member for McPherson that it was not the Opposition that had the courage and the guts to begin the tortuous process of restructuring in this country. `Restructuring' is a pretty interesting term--one that is often mentioned by those opposite. But what is the Opposition's record on that? Ducking, weaving; ducking, weaving. Opposition members talk about restructuring and they talk about micro-economic reform, but they do not do anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What have you done?

—-We have done plenty; I will get onto that in a moment. When it comes to regeneration and micro-economic reform, what emanates from the other side is zilch, a blank, nadir. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) said in this House not long ago, it was not even members of the Opposition who thought up the line `Labor isn't working; neither are one million Australians'; they got it from Margaret Thatcher. The infamy of that line! The Minister said that Margaret Thatcher's policies created three million unemployed. In four or five years she managed to increase unemployment in the United Kingdom by 154 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take a town in northern England called Hull. Eighty-five to 92 per cent of the kids who left school last Christmas still do not have a job. Towns such as this are the places where riots are occurring in the United Kingdom. The policies that caused that situation are the policies the Opposition puts forward. Those policies would create two million unemployed in this country. Who would they impact upon most? Youth--that is who. The irony of the 1983 election in the United Kingdom is not lost on Opposition members because, unfortunately and paradoxically, Margaret Thatcher won that election.

Perhaps Ross Gittins, in a recent article in the Sunday Age, summed up the Opposition's attitude towards people who are unfortunate enough to be unemployed. I will use some of his words. He summed up honourable members opposite with a very accurate and cutting remark. He referred to unemployment, but his remarks could just as well apply to youth. His words were; so the Liberal Party bleeds for the unemployed? So the Liberal Party bleeds for youth? I think not--Ross Gittins words. The policies of honourable members opposite are those of the Thatcher Government. The Opposition would double unemployment in this country. It would increase it by over 150 per cent, and the greatest casualties of that unemployment would be youth.

Let us look at some of the achievements of the Australian Government as they affect Australian youth. The Hawke Labor Government is responsible for a revolution in education, employment and training in this country. There are some figures that the Opposition cannot, in fact, deny. There are now more Australians in schools, in TAFE, in training courses, in universities and in jobs, even in the current climate, than ever before in our history.

Let us look at some of the specifics as they affect schools, the very foundation stones of a clever country. To benefit our youth in our nation there are now more young people completing year 12 than ever before. By the year 2001, if we start applying the recommendations of the Finn report, we are aiming at 90 to 95 per cent of 19-year-olds. There are some ideas. There are some processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I hope you have a relevant curriculum for them.
—-The honourable member should read the Finn report. He would find not only a rationale--
—-It's here.

—-Yes, the honourable member will find a rationale, he will find some mechanisms, and he will find some outcomes. It is a pity he cannot get the trinity right. By the end of the 1992 funding period, funding for schools in this country will be almost $500m more than in 1983. More than $2 billion a year is spent on government and non-government schools, on disadvantaged students, and on isolated students.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at what is going on with the funding of schools. For primary kids it is up 37 per cent; for secondary students it is up 102 per cent. This is the Government that does not care for youth! What about the neediest non-government schools? Their funding is up 36 per cent for primary students and 26 per cent for high schools. I think the Opposition thinks that the Finn report is a comic in the Sunday papers, from the way in which it has referred to it today. What about support for disadvantaged students? That is acknowledged. That is something that we do not see coming from the Opposition. What about TAFE and vocational training which are areas of education that have traditionally being ignored by many on the benches opposite? Again, as one would expect, there is a large gulf between the thinking of the Government and of the Opposition.

With the release of the Finn report, the Government is quite clearly leading the debate on post-compulsory education. It is ideas driven, not outcomes driven. We are planning for our young to 2001. The Finn report recognises that both individual and industry needs are leading towards a convergence of general and vocational education. New measures for participation post-year 10 are clearly spelt out and outcomes are reconciled with ideas and processes that 95 per cent of our 19-year-olds should have completed year 12 or have an initial post-school qualification and be participating in formally recognised education and training. These matters concerning TAFE should have been addressed by those opposite in the 1970s. Why would the Australian electorate believe the Opposition would do anything in the 1990s?

In summing up, may I say in relation to Australian youth and children that the lack of planning, substance and detail on the part of honourable members opposite during the Fraser years locked out our youth. That is right, it locked them out and prevented our youth from participating and being able to attain their real potential. The Opposition would do it again. Make no mistake, the Australian electorate knows that it would do it again. The track record of the Opposition in relation to youth and children, welfare groups and the unemployed has not changed, and that is a great pity.

Take, for example, the vicious attack on ACOSS by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hweson) recently. In that attack, the Leader of the Opposition quite clearly pointed out from whom he wished to take funds--women, children and youth. Those honourable members opposite know it. They know it all right. They must have cringed in shame when they saw the reports coming back from that attack. They deserve to cringe in shame.

Youth and children in this country are indeed our future. Youth and children need and deserve support, and this Government has the runs on the board. Youth and children deserve more than the illusions offered by the Opposition. I acknowledge that improvements need to be and must be made. I am sure that everyone on the Government benches would acknowledge that. Youth and children deserve more than rhetorical catch grab one-liners devoid of intellectual content that fail to acknowledge a rationale, that failed to acknowledge a process, and that are simply an ad hoc collection of synthesised outcomes. The Opposition, whether it is its health policy, micro-economic reform, or taxation reform, continues to take the easy options. It is devoid of analysis. Perhaps to borrow a phrase that I read in the press the other day, the Opposition is in a state of analysis paralysis.

What would a Liberal-National Party Opposition do in government? Inevitably, it would repeat the outcomes created and achieved by the United Kingdom Government under Thatcher. It is incapable of planning for the future. It continues to drive this debate by an ad hoc collection of outcomes. It continues to fail to reconcile ideas and mechanisms and procedures for improvement. If any individual in everyday life did this in tackling problems, they would inevitably fail. If any group in this country followed the procedures, the methodology and the modus operandi of this Opposition, it would fail. If a government in the guise of the Opposition followed this way, it would fail. As certainly as night turns to day, it would repeat the achievements of the Thatcher Government and increase unemployment in this country by 154 per cent and the greatest casualty would be the youth of this nation.

Sadly, I hear what the Opposition is saying. I hear its real thought-out remedies. The Australian people will surely say, `No, thank you. No, thank you very much'. Civilised societies in this world are noted for their care of the aged, the disadvantaged and the young. We do not see the evidence of that coming from the other side. On all three of these aspects the Opposition fails. By its actions and its words, it is confirming those messages to the Australian electorate and it will be rightfully rejected. (Time expired)

That is only one of a million people out there on the streets wanting to work. There are young people who are qualified, intelligent and keen to work and they do not have the opportunity to do so because this Government is not putting the policies in place. It is absolutely paralysed with its infighting and its lack of policies to get this economy working.

One of the problems with the Hawke Government at the moment is that it kept high interest rates in place for so long, with the recession `we had to have'--it was brought upon us by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating)--that it did not know how to correct the situation. It just kept forcing interest rates up in this recession and did not realise the high price that young people in our community were paying. The young people right throughout this country will remember the policies of the Hawke Government.

The honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) will be the next speaker on the Government side. I look forward to her speech because as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I invited her to visit my electorate. She was able to see at first hand the problems people were experiencing in the country area of Victoria with Austudy. They were having difficulty in getting access to Austudy assistance because of the stupid policy that the Government has put in place and the poor administration which has required three inquiries--and still there has been no better result in the administration of that organisation. She will obviously have some very enlightened input into what is happening in rural Australia.

We need major structural reform; major tax reform; labour market reform; enterprise bargaining; and efficient privatisation to improve our competitiveness. An article in the Canberra Times of 14 October is headed `Labor `burns' over job crisis'. It is not Labor that is burning. Labor's policies are burning the young people of this country--the policies that it has had in place now for the last eight years, almost a decade, of increasing unemployment in this nation.

We have reached the highest level of unemployment since 1983. Honourable members will recall that in 1982-83 we were subjected to a drought year. The Government pointed out the unemployment figures at that time, but it very carefully glosses over the fact that Australia experienced one of the worst droughts in its history. Once the rains came in 1983, the economic recovery was immediate and employment started to blossom. But now, because of the policies the Government has implemented, the unemployment situation has progressively deteriorated.

My Party has set out to recharge the Australian economy and provide some confidence, particularly to employers who will be in a position to employ young Australians in the work force. We are going to instil confidence in the private sector, which will become the largest employer in the small business area. Our taxation reform will be of tremendous advantage to small business people throughout Australia and will create employment opportunities. We are also encouraging a high level of privatisation in an efficient manner. We should get government out of business and out of running many activities and let the private sector do it. TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resolution of the House of 9 May 1990 concerning Parliamentary Secretaries be amended so as to read:

That, for the purposes of the procedures of the House, any reference to Ministers shall be taken to include Parliamentary Secretaries, with the exception of references to questions seeking information (chapter XI of the standing orders).
On 9 May 1990 the House resolved:
That, for the purposes of the procedures of the House, any references to Ministers shall be taken to include Parliamentary Secretaries, with the following exceptions:
(a) presentation and motion for second reading of government bills; and
(b) questions seeking information. . .

Essentially, the motion I have moved would remove that first qualification. I did indicate, when I moved the original motion, that the way in which we handled the matter of Parliamentary Secretaries in this place would be very much a matter of trial and error. I suggested that, while most of their functions were to assist their portfolio Minister, it was clearly intended that they would assist the Ministry generally in the conduct of the House. There is no doubt that Parliamentary Secretaries in both chambers have performed very valuable functions and responsibilities during the past 17 months. I think it is an appropriate time to reconsider their role, and to expand it slightly.

The purpose of the motion before the House is to enhance the role of Parliamentary Secretaries, but without overriding the ongoing responsibilities which Ministers have to the proper conduct of business in the House and, importantly, the courtesies that they are expected to extend to it. The same motion was successfully carried in the Senate on 19 June 1991, and experience since then in the other place indicates that the new arrangements work effectively and with strong bipartisan support. I must say that to some considerable extent our moving of this motion is influenced by the fact that this position has been adopted in the Senate.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I must ask you to convey to the Speaker when he returns from overseas my appreciation of the very significant and historical role he has played in bringing about the reintroduction of Parliamentary Secretaries last year. It has been conducted in a way that is both appropriate and desirable. I recollect that, at the time when we were considering whether or not we should establish Parliamentary Secretary positions, he played an enormously supportive role by suggesting to the Government that it was a sensible thing to do, and he made a few suggestions about enhancing this role. So, to some extent, this motion reflects some of his ideas.

I would also recommend to honourable members who are interested in these particular procedures a very good paper prepared for the Parliamentary Library by Margaret Healy, which details the role and responsibilities of Parliamentary Secretaries in a number of countries and states of the Commonwealth. What is quite evident from a study of what she has had to say is that no two systems are exactly the same. There are features which are unique to virtually every parliament that operates with Parliamentary Secretaries. I think it would be true to say, however, that if one went through a list of things they might do, we would have to say that we were perhaps on the most generous side in terms of the roles that Parliamentary Secretaries undertake, when compared with the other parliaments identified by Margaret Healy.

It is worth while saying one or two things about conventions that might apply here. Again, some of these matters have been discussed with the Speaker and not formalised, but there are one or two things that might be indicated. It is intended that under the new arrangements Parliamentary Secretaries will be able to introduce some legislation and have carriage of it through each reading stage, including the committee stage. It is expected that Ministers will continue to have responsibility for the carriage of all substantive legislation within their portfolios, but housekeeping type legislation, including portfolio omnibus Bills, can readily be handled through all stages by Parliamentary Secretaries.

Parliamentary Secretaries would not, under this proposition, be able to answer questions without notice or seek information, nor would they be able to ask questions without notice of their portfolio Minister. I really ought to talk through with the Speaker the matter of their asking questions. I think there would be a pretty reasonable case for arguing that Parliamentary Secretaries ought to be able to ask questions on matters of relevance directly to their electorates.

The Speaker has suggested that the Parliamentary Secretaries, like Ministers, might not participate in private members' debates, grievance debates and 90-second statements. Again, that is something I think I ought to talk through with the Speaker to ensure that that does not overly impinge on the role of people who are in fact not Ministers but members of the Executive Council.

One aspect of the role of Parliamentary Secretary requires some clarification. It has been the practice of some Parliamentary Secretaries to speak at the dispatch box while participating in second reading debates and, on other occasions, they follow the practice of participating in debate only from their allocated places. The Speaker has informed me that if the motion is passed it would be more appropriate for Parliamentary Secretaries to address the House from the dispatch box rather than from their allocated places.

These changes add to what I think has been a very substantial array of reforms introduced in the House in recent years. They have included the introduction of private members' business on Thursday morning, which has been very well received. The sitting arrangements of the House, with two weeks on and two weeks off--that being prescribed by the doctors on this side of the House--seem to have produced a situation in which a proper balance between electorate and parliamentary work is being assumed by members. The improved hours of sitting which have the House meeting earlier in the day rather than sitting very late into the night have also been of benefit.

It is essential that members continue to give consideration to measures which would improve the operations of the House. Changes to improve the nature and conduct of Question Time are always worthy of consideration. Improving the timely introduction of legislation is another. Advisory debates, an initiative of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), will commence shortly and will provide yet another opportunity for members to have substantive input into the Executive decision making process.

I think that for the Parliamentary Secretaries this particular motion is very important. It will more firmly stamp authority on their conduct in this House, given the status they have acquired principally by virtue of their being members of the Executive Council. I notice that one who might be described as the head of the Parliamentary Secretaries trade union, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), is here in the House. I pay tribute to him for the constant pressure to enhance the role of Parliamentary Secretaries.

I think the business of government over the years has increased extraordinarily and that even a cursory look at what parliaments dealt with even 20 or 30 years ago would indicate that, particularly as we on this side of the House have adopted a position that we will have portfolio Ministers. In many ways, the position of senior Ministers has expanded quite dramatically under this Government. As a result of that, they require much more assistance in their normal legislative functions than they have had otherwise. The position of Parliamentary Secretary is not one that we on this side of the House invented; it was one put in place, as I understand it, by the Fraser Government. What we have done with it is to take it several stages beyond the way in which it functioned under the Fraser Government. That has been very much to the good order of business.

In conclusion, I point to the role of the Parliamentary Secretary who operates in the Senate, Senator McMullan. He effectively is de facto manager of Government business in the Senate and has an even more substantial role than that which this motion, replicated in the Senate, effectively gives him. That is again very much in the interests of the better functioning of that place. As far as I can see, his particular role has well and truly received multiparty support in that establishment, as I hope it does here today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in May last year moved to revive the institution of Parliamentary Secretaries, the Opposition supported the motion. However, it will be recalled that in supporting the Minister's motion we expressed a strong reservation about Government Parliamentary Secretaries being on occasions in charge of the House. It is fundamental to ministerial responsibility and it is a courtesy that the Executive owes to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The original motion excluded Parliamentary Secretaries from introducing Government Bills and from answering questions in the portfolio area. Now the Government is seeking to invest them with the power to introduce Bills and presumably to steer them through the House. The only responsibility that the Government is not seeking to transfer to Parliamentary Secretaries is the authority to answer questions.

If this motion is carried, there will soon be very little difference between the roles of Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries in Parliament. It will clearly diminish the role of Ministers. So far as Parliament is concerned, it will mean that the only difference between them will be that Parliamentary Secretaries will not be accountable for their respective portfolio areas. In all other respects they will be carrying out much the same functions in this chamber as Ministers perform.

Parliamentary Secretaries are going to be able to introduce Bills, to move for the second reading and to see through the House legislation coming from various departments and Cabinet. Despite our opposition, they have already at various times been in charge of the House. As the Government treads down this path of investing Parliamentary Secretaries with powers that almost match those of Ministers for the purpose of duties in this House, the only conclusion is that this is another step by the Executive to erode the authority of the Parliament and the processes of this place.

In this context, we all know that not so long ago the Government was floating the idea of rostering groups of Ministers for Question Time on a weekly basis. This would have had the effect of reducing the exposure of Ministers to questions on their administration and the eliciting of information concerning their portfolios. Fortunately, this has not come to fruition. If it had, it would have been another example of the Government seeking to downgrade the Parliament and the proceedings of this place.

We have already had enough experience of this through most of the life of the Hawke Government. It has ruthlessly resorted to the guillotine to process its legislation. The House will be aware that I have repeatedly protested against this practice of the Government's short-circuiting the legislative process by not allowing adequate time for proper scrutiny and analysis of legislation and often far less for debate. I am glad to be able to say, though, that this current sitting has been much better managed than in the past. I am hoping that this will be a guillotine-free sitting, which, having regard to the Hawke Government's record, would be a parliamentary landmark.

With this motion, making it unnecessary for Ministers to handle their own legislation in the House, this Parliament is further shunned. In the interests of the institution of parliament, this should not be tolerated. Parliamentary Secretaries have a role in relieving the ministerial workload, but, in assigning duties relating to this House, distinctive functions should be retained as the responsibility of Ministers. It is our view that the carriage of legislation should be one of them.

The reason for having Parliamentary Secretaries is to assist Ministers. But this assistance should be defined so that it does not impinge on the parliamentary process or take over responsibilities that should be the reserve of the responsible Ministers. Parliamentary Secretaries, to be effective, should have a range of particular but discrete tasks that do not cut across the full ambit of the Minister's responsibilities.

A broad outline of the sorts of tasks Parliamentary Secretaries should perform was given when we introduced the Parliamentary Secretaries Act in 1980. It was suggested that members serving in the role of Parliamentary Secretary could provide valuable assistance to Ministers by undertaking, as requested, a range of duties, including assistance with correspondence and other papers, liaising with other members of parliament and meeting with delegations and clients of the department and authorities, and other representational activities. Parliamentary Secretaries will be able to play a very useful role, particularly in assisting to bring the views of others to the attention of Ministers. Ministers must, of course, retain their responsibility to parliament. These tasks were largely echoed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement announcing the appointment of the present Parliamentary Secretaries. Otherwise, the Parliamentary Secretary has to become answerable to the House for those things. That is why the Opposition is opposing this motion.

It is our view that Ministers should be fully responsible for the legislation they present here. If the Government believes that its Ministers are so overworked that it needs to upgrade the responsibilities of Parliamentary Secretaries, it should face up to making them Ministers and bring in the necessary amendments to increase the size of the Ministry. The Opposition does not advocate this course of action. On the contrary, we believe that any perceived overload on Ministers stems from the Government's poor management and its ineptitude in organising itself. Instead of shifting more ministerial responsibilities to Parliamentary Secretaries, the Executive should be reorganising itself and looking to ways of improving its administrative practices.

The Government's policy paralysis has been clearly evident in recent weeks. We have seen it backing and filling over its media ownership policy as well as its other communication areas, its absolute ineffectiveness in coming to grips with the devastating and growing unemployment problem, as well as a major split over Medicare, to name just a few of the signs. There have been Cabinet meetings finishing at 3 o'clock in the morning, with decisions on major issues such as media ownership being made as Ministers were about to leave. It all adds up to chaos and a government completely lacking in direction.

The real role of Parliamentary Secretaries is meant to be supportive. However, if the Government wants to make them more than that and if it continues to pursue such a course, of which this motion is indicative, it could run the danger of raising the spectre of section 44 of the Constitution and the disqualification that arises from a member of parliament who is not a Minister holding an office of profit under the Crown. Honourable members will be aware that the section says:

Any person who . . . holds any office of profit under the Crown, or any pension payable during the pleasure of the Crown out of any of the revenues of the Commonwealth . . . shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

Under the current arrangements for Parliamentary Secretaries as regards remuneration for expenses incurred in the performance of the duties of their appointment, that problem does not arise. However, past experience dictates that it is something that needs to be watched as governments search for ways to ease the burden on Ministers without increasing the size of the Ministry.
The motion before the House is another example of the Hawke Government reverting to the old Fabian device of gradualism, as spelt out by the Prime Minister in 1984, when he said:
For the right moment you must wait . . . but when the time comes you must strike hard.

Through the life of the Hawke Government in so many instances we have seen its technique of nibbling away at the edges and then bringing in a major change through the back door. This motion has all those hallmarks and we consider it unnecessary.

One of the primary principles of ministerial responsibility is accountability to this Parliament. This accountability is discharged in two ways: firstly, through being present during Question Time to be cross-examined on policy matters; and, secondly, through advocating and defending legislation introduced into the Parliament. The motion before the House will remove one of those two main pillars of accountability. The Opposition is strongly opposed to it and we will vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to make some observations about this motion in the context of support for my colleague the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) graciously referred to the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980. He pointed out that that legislation was introduced by the Fraser Government. Honourable members should be well aware of the fact that the concept of the Parliamentary Secretary essentially grew out of the Westminster system. It was introduced by the British in the nineteenth century when they had two forms of secretaries: they had parliamentary private secretaries, who were personal appointees of Ministers and secretaries of state; and they also had parliamentary secretaries, who had additional responsibilities of a more constitutionally based nature, despite the fact that the British have no written constitution.

The point made by the honourable member for Hume is absolutely correct. He was pointing out that if it was such a wonderful idea to have Parliamentary Secretaries, one has to ask the question: why was it not introduced at the time of the Hawke Government in 1983? The fact is that the Government introduced Parliamentary Secretaries finally because of the basic embarrassment of having on the back bench too many people regarded as `rich in talent' to whom it wanted to give positions by which they could be involved in some way in sharing the limelight. Therefore, the decision was taken that the easy way out of the problem was to have a few Parliamentary Secretaries.

Then the task facing the Government was: what can we make them do? In fairness, I think I would have to say that the initial period, 1980 to 1982-83, was, for us, very much a trial period. I think the responsibilities which were given to Parliamentary Secretaries in that period were very limited indeed. The simple reality, which is the view of the Opposition, is that Parliamentary Secretaries should not be used in the Chamber as an alternative to Ministers. It has to be emphasised that a proposal for a system of rostered Ministers at Question Time was put forward as a serious concept by the Prime Minister. It was not suggested, as I understand it, that Parliamentary Secretaries should necessarily fill the gap. They certainly could not do that because they have no constitutional responsibility for the passage of legislation or for the administration of legislation. Under the Act, they have the responsibility of assisting Ministers in the conduct of their normal administrative duties. Those duties, of course, are relevant and they are very onerous on a Minister, whether they be correspondence, liaison, representations, attending functions or, as has been the case in recent years, taking over the actual administration of some legislation.
