For a long time, since the late Lionel Murphy was in the Senate, there has been a proliferation of committees in the Senate of a different order and a different character from those that function in this place. Whilst for the first time in this Parliament I have participated in the parliamentary committee system, to my mind there is a total difference between the responsibilities to the government of members and committees of a lower House--the chamber of the people, the chamber from which the Prime Minister is elected--and those of a House of review.

Of course, the Senate is an elected chamber. It has many elements of difference from the House of Lords, on which to a degree it was modelled in our Constitution. Significantly, the House of review is there to pursue scrutiny of legislation and scrutiny of the actions of government in greater detail than is possible in this place. For all of us there is a consciousness that after our second reading debates we have a very perfunctory committee stage debate.

If we consider debates on the Estimates, there is a big contrast between what takes place in the House of Representatives and what takes place in the Senate. In the Senate there is significantly greater opportunity for scrutiny of the line by line allocations than is the case in this chamber. It is true that we did have Estimates committees in this place. When I was a senior Minister, I was one of those who suggested that it was difficult to provide the time necessary for that scrutiny to be facilitated, and it is of interest that in the changes to which the Leader of the House referred there has been no suggestion that we return to Estimates committees in this place.

I do not need to outline for those who are here the extent to which there is a difference between the two Houses. There is a totally different environment within which legislation and the functions of government proceed in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. I understand therefore the role played by Senator McMullan. Within the Senate he is one of a few Government members who are entitled to sit at the front bench and who are in fact responsible for all those portfolios that are largely represented in this chamber. So do not let us for one moment draw a parallel between the responsibilities of the two Houses.

The second area of concern is with the doctrine of the separation of powers, which has been addressed in various forums with greater or less understanding. Let us be quite clear that there has not been and can never be any real doubt about the role of the courts and the way in which they operate separately from the administration and the legislature. But within this chamber the separation between the administration and the legislature of recent years has become more tenuous.

It is true that, because we have inherited the Westminster system, our Prime Minister, Leader of the Opposition, Ministers and all members of the front bench on both sides are elected members of the Parliament. For all that we have a provision under our Constitution whereby for a period of three months a Minister need not be a member of either House. There is a requirement that, if he is not after three months, his office be terminated.

It is essential when we look at the Westminster system that we recognise some of the responsibilities as well as the opportunities that flow from that relationship between the administration and the legislature. One of those responsibilities for those who are Ministers is that they retain a contact with the Parliament, that they do not just appear during Question Time. I do not intend to pursue the argument of the honourable member for Hume and the honourable member for Bradfield, although I endorse it, about other proposals for the rostering of Ministers.

It is important that Ministers listen to and understand the proceedings of this chamber. I find it deplorable, for all that we have a quorum procedure which is used basically for political purposes, that for so much of the time there is barely a soul in this place. Those who come to hear proceedings in the chamber must wonder what the devil everybody is doing. I can assure them that everybody is working. But that is not really the argument. The argument is that this chamber should be the basis from which argument is allowed on matters of prime public importance affecting the Australian electorate, Australia's relationships with other countries, the economy and all those significant issues that are allocated to the Commonwealth under the Constitution, and others that are of general public interest.

I commend the Leader of the House for some of the changes that he has introduced. But let us be realistic. We have had some procedural changes, including those on Thursday morning which give private members greater opportunities to speak, and other changes that flow from them. But, while they have allowed greater opportunities for private members to speak, realistically those speaking opportunities are not translated into legislative opportunities. They are not translated into the passage of private members' Bills. The consideration is perfunctory, as we all know. Sure, there is a procedure to allow a second reading speech, but, unless the Government adopts the legislation as its own, that is the end of the matter.

Indeed, there is no longer a reasonable procedure by which any member of the Opposition or any back bench member can be scrutinised--nor, as I understand it from this motion, will even Parliamentary Secretaries be--on matters for which they are responsible. Under the old procedure, if a member, being a private member of this place, were to have a Bill in his name, he could be asked questions relating to that Bill, and there was a limited opportunity. That is no longer there.

It is important that we understand that this measure is really yet another step to reduce the powers of the private member in his relationship with the administration. I see it as a greater separation between the administration and the chamber and a lessening of the opportunities for those who are Ministers to listen to and understand the debate.

As the honourable member for Hume has suggested, one immediate consequence will be that during second reading debates--and certainly during the committee stage--there will be no Minister at the table; Parliamentary Secretaries will be largely rostered for duty. I know it is an onerous duty. I know that it is a responsibility that at times many of us find somewhat irksome.

But the Minister responsible for a Bill should be in the chamber during debate because members from either side may have a view that they feel they strongly need to express. They may have concerns that relate to their electorate or to some area in which they have some special knowledge, or they may have amendments that they feel are significant. We all know how frequently legislation is returned from the other place because it has been dealt with inadequately either at the Cabinet level, at the parliamentary counsel level or in scrutiny through this chamber. There are far too many errors in legislation which should not happen and should not be allowed. Often those could be redressed if some consideration were given to submissions made within debate in this chamber. I know that so often the debate is political--I accept that--and I know that it is difficult for Ministers, particularly senior Ministers, to spend time in the chamber. But my concern is in the reduction of the powers of this place and what I see as the greater separation of the relationship between the government and the House.

The third area of concern to me is in the restructuring of the Ministry itself. I accept, and I have spoken to the Leader of the House on several occasions about, the degree to which the restraints of section 44 of the Constitution, to which the honourable member for Hume referred, impose discipline and make it difficult for Parliamentary Secretaries to perform the role in some sense that one would like them to perform. I support the idea of functional Ministries. I like the idea of having a senior Cabinet Minister who is able to spend more time considering policy. But that separation within the Ministry is really now being extended to a far greater degree by the additional powers to be given to these Parliamentary Secretaries. As I see it, what is being done is the creation, to a greater degree than ever before, of a third tier of Minister. That third tier will be unpaid, thanks to section 44, but nevertheless will be largely given the responsibilities of a Minister within this chamber.

If there is a role for Parliamentary Secretaries, I believe that that role should be enhanced outside of the chamber, not within it. We have all spoken about the extent to which today party room and factional deals tend to be the politics of administration. We all know the extent to which the bureaucracy is expanding. We all know the degree to which, in looking and caring for individual departments, there is, certainly under the Labor regime, a far greater difficulty in keeping in touch with Peter, Paul and all those others out there in the woodwork. But, surely, that is an area to which Parliamentary Secretaries could be directed, as the charter of responsibilities to which the Manager of Opposition Business referred is intended to provide the responsibilities of Parliamentary Secretaries.

This measure does not enhance a proper and more efficient role of the ministry. I think there is a reason for Parliamentary Secretaries to try to lighten the load of senior Ministers in particular, so that they can spend more time on policy issues, so that they can spend more time in Cabinet and so that they can spend more time in the House. It is because of that last vital obligation that I see this measure as going in exactly the reverse direction.

I oppose the measure and do not believe that it is going to assist the functioning of government in any way. I regret that such a fundamental change is apparently to be pushed through in a climate where I believe there will be a significant alteration to the relationships between individual members--because Parliamentary Secretaries will have an enhanced status. I regret that the measure should be forced through against the wishes of the Opposition and in a way which is certainly going to lead to a fundamental division of opinion on the way in which this Parliament should function.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--In summing up, I thank honourable members who have participated in the debate. We get far too few opportunities to discuss the nature of our House and what it does. Even though I cannot agree with the three Opposition spokesmen on this matter, and do agree with my colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Price), I nevertheless acknowledge the fact that the views they have put come from a wealth of parliamentary and governmental experience. It is not as though we on this side of the House do not take their views seriously; we do, but we think they are unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, if a study is made of the paper to which I have referred, unquestionably we are giving as much authority to Parliamentary Secretaries as anyone else does; we are not in that regard totally unique. A large number of modern democratic governments that operate with something that approximates the Westminster system have found it necessary to create the institution of Parliamentary Secretary and give Parliamentary Secretaries roles that do not simply refer to the administrative tasks of Ministers in their Departments, but also relate to administrative and legislative tasks in the House.

We did not implement the office of Parliamentary Secretary in the initial stages of our Government. I think in so doing we were misguided. We took the view that at the time the Opposition introduced the institution of Parliamentary Secretaries, when it was in government, Parliamentary Secretaries were introduced for something like the reasons that have been described as the reasons why we introduced Parliamentary Secretaries in the last couple of years. I am sure that our arguments to the Opposition when it was in government and introduced Parliamentary Secretaries were unsoundly founded, as are the same arguments applied to ourselves.

The reality is that the super-ministries were created only after enormously careful checking with the Attorney-General's Department and an assortment of outside opinions, because of the sorts of risks that both the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), referred to. The super-ministries were created only after that advice said that it was okay to do so.

We very rapidly reached a situation where the narrowing of the portfolio base created problems. This was particularly so where portfolios had responsibility for omnibus legislation, as my portfolio does every session. Every session we have an omnibus transport and communications Bill of some description in which we are fixing up some part of one of the plethora of Acts for which the Transport and Communications Minister is responsible, but which does not necessarily involve substantial legislative and policy activity on his part.

Oddly enough, such matters tend to be the parts of the portfolio which are effectively administered by the Parliamentary Secretary. Parliamentary Secretaries are well placed to be able to handle them effectively in the Parliament and respond to them. For example, my Parliamentary Secretary has responsibility for frequency allocations and for a whole range of that type of backbreaking work which is appalling in terms of the amount of correspondence that it generates but is not necessarily of a very high policy content. He knows a lot more about it than I do. It is not inappropriate that he ought to be in a position where he answers for that here in Parliament.

The right honourable gentlemen who spoke last for the Opposition correctly pointed out differences in the roles of the Senate and the House. He said that senators, largely because of functions they have attributed to themselves--again, I fully concede, largely on the initiatives of Labor Party senators back in the late 1960s--have created over the last 25 years a greater level of differentiation between the functions of the Senate and the House than there has ever been before. That is partly as a result of the powers senators have accrued for themselves and partly as a result of the working through of the changes introduced by Arthur Calwell in 1949, effectively making for proportional representation in the Senate. For a period of time, because of the fact that the two-party system held up rather well for about 20 or 30 years after that, the full potential for the implications were not realised. However, the two-party system, at least in Senate voting habits, has, to a considerable degree, fallen apart since the late 1960s.

As Parliament increases in size, and by virtue of the fact that the Opposition, when in government, unfortunately failed to get through its nexus-breaking constitutional amendments back in the late 1960s, the Senate must inevitably increase in size as well. That new character of the Senate will become more manifest as time goes by and as successive governments adjust the size of the Parliament.

However, there is a similarity between the functions here for Parliamentary Secretaries and the functions that Senator McMullan performs. Basically, as with Ministers in the Senate, whilst an onerous part of Senator McMullan's duties is representational as far as his colleagues in the Senate are concerned, and while he has to handle legislation in the Senate which is not germane to his portfolio area, he nevertheless handles legislation himself; and legislation is initiated in the Senate and passed to the House. Senator McMullan, under the changes, has the authority to do that, in the same way we are extending the authority here, and he will utilise that authority. The authority, as I have said, has been granted to him on a bipartisan basis.

Honourable members opposite are sincere in their concerns about the possible impact on ministerial accountability. I would not accuse the right honourable member of grandstanding on this for political purposes, if for no other reason than that, while the matter should have been of vital interest to everybody in the House, I do not regard these procedures necessarily as of vital interest to anybody outside this place. Therefore, there is not much percentage in the right honourable member adopting an obstructive view in this place for political reasons. Nevertheless, I do think he is wrong. The basic problem that we have here with ministerial accountability is not due to any set of procedures that may arise from the creation of the position of Parliamentary Secretary; it arises because of the nature of this House in relation to the Executive. This House supports an Executive. If it does not do that, the country is not governed. The restraints that are placed on private members in this place stem largely from that fact. Perhaps the restraints are too heavy.

I think the right honourable member for New England was wrong in one area. It is true that we have a situation here where more private members' legislation has been moved and had a second reading in this place than ever before in the history of the Parliament. It does not actually come through to any fruition unless the Government takes it up, largely as a result of the way in which the Selection Committee operates and the amount of time that is made available for honourable members.

Nevertheless, it remains a possibility that, if any member in this chamber actually moves a piece of private member's legislation and it is on the books and on the Notice Paper, it is open to members of the Parliament to question that member on it in this place. So for all those who have put forward things like the Flags Bill and all the rest of it, it is possible, should anyone want to ask a question about the processes being undertaken, for them to respond to that question.

The Manager of Opposition Business raised the issue of whether or not this would bring into question any element of the situation that the Parliamentary Secretaries confront in relation to the office of profit question. It does not really impact upon that. Not only Parliamentary Secretaries conceivably suffer that problem; there are also Chairmen of Committees for whom that could conceivably arise. All I can say is, from my own experience in trying to get these fellows a raise every now and again, or a bit better treatment--at least to the level of the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee or whatever--that I am constantly warned that there has to be a very detailed investigation by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to make sure that their positions are not in fact placed at risk. To this point of time it is a matter that the Attorney-General has under consideration. But the extension of powers does not go to that. It might go to the sympathy with which we might view an allowance claimed by the Parliamentary Secretaries, but it does not go to whether or not they are actually to be entitled to that.

The Manager of Opposition Business also raised the matter of Question Time, and was cheerful about the fact that a proposition circulated to the Opposition by the Government did not subsequently proceed, by and large because we did not really think it reasonable to ram through the Opposition a change in the nature of Question Time if the Opposition really did not want to play ball with it. Personally, as someone who is very much an advocate of that proposal, I am disappointed. Ministers in Question Time here are not subject to being rendered accountable for their portfolios. Here, the political issues of the day get a run. Questions are largely directed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and frequently they are directed to the Prime Minister when in fact there are Ministers along the front bench who have portfolio accountability for the matters raised. It is not an abuse of Question Time; it is clearly open to the Opposition to do that, but it does not add to the accountability of the place.

If there were a situation where that sort of process took place perhaps once a week, as happens in the United Kingdom Parliament, that would be fine, but the rest of the time there would be serious, detailed consideration given to the way in which each Minister administers his portfolio. It necessarily goes beyond what is generated by the headlines of the day.

As I said, this is not something we will press on the Opposition. On reflection, over time, the Opposition might well like to think about that, and think about whether or not in practical terms it would get a better performance in Question Time from the Government and be able to engage in more serious scrutiny of what the Government does. I always remember Barry Cohen, when he was a member of this place, telling me that the best hits we ever scored on the Opposition when it was in government were when the front bench walked away from Question Time. I must say we used to do that a bit more frequently than this Opposition seems to have done in the last eight years. Ministers suddenly started getting pinged on the administration of their portfolios, as of course they turned up to Question Time without being briefed for it. All that every Minister is briefed on in this place are the issues of the day that impact upon his portfolio. What he does not get briefed on is the detailed administration of that portfolio. I remember that Barry Cohen, once or twice, very effectively got under the guard of Ministers on that subject, to their not inconsiderable embarrassment. I do think that is something the Opposition ought to bear in mind.

I think this change in relation to Parliamentary Secretaries is a good one. It is one which will stand the test of time. If the Opposition finds itself in government, I very much doubt whether it will walk away from anything we have done in relation to Parliamentary Secretaries. I also understand that the debate does offer opportunities to people to get up and make wide-ranging criticisms of some of the Executive's handling of the Parliament. Some of the points are valid; some are unavoidable. As I said, I do appreciate the spirit in which the Opposition and, indeed, our side of the House have conducted this debate.
Question put:
That the motion be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: as a result of the passage of that resolution, could you inform me whether Parliamentary Secretaries will be able to move motions without them being seconded, or is it still a requirement, as it was, that a motion moved by any member of the House other than a Minister should be seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That:
(1) the House authorises live television broadcast and rebroadcast of:
(a) the proceedings of the House and excerpts of proceedings, including the adjournment debate; and
(b) the public proceedings of House of Representatives committees, subject to the approval of individual committees --
as provided for by this resolution;

(2) the House supports in principle the amendment of the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 to make statutory provision for the televising of the proceedings of the Senate, the House of Representatives and the committees of each House and joint committees of both Houses;

(3) a standing committee be appointed in each Parliament to consider and determine in respect of live television broadcast and rebroadcast of proceedings and excerpts of proceedings of the House of Representatives and the public proceedings of House of Representatives committees:
(a) the conditions to apply to television broadcasters;
(b) the guidelines for operators of sound and vision equipment;
(c) the guidelines for the televising of House of Representatives committees; and
(d) whether breaches of the conditions and guidelines have occurred and, if so, what penalties should apply;
(4) the committee referred to in paragraph (3) of this resolution shall:

(a) consist of those Members of the House of Representatives who are members of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings in each Parliament, who shall elect a chairman and deputy chairman; and
(b) have power to send for persons, papers and records;

(5) until otherwise determined the conditions and guidelines to apply to live television broadcast and rebroadcast shall be those set out in the Report of the Inquiry into the Televising of the House of Representatives and its committees dated August 1991;

(6) the arrangements relating to the live television broadcast and rebroadcast of proceedings and excerpts of proceedings of the House of Representatives shall be reviewed by the committee established under paragraph (3) of this resolution prior to the end of the 1993 Autumn sittings of the House; and

(7) the House requests the Government to seek advice from the Attorney-General as to the legal position of bodies authorised to receive the signal of proceedings with a view to the House granting access to that signal to government departments, political party headquarters and others.

This motion deals with the recommendations of the Select Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives dealing with the televising of Parliament, extending the authority of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings and formalising its structure somewhat. I guess the most significant change that will emerge from the Committee's recommendations will be to permit the televising of adjournment debates. By and large, we think the televising of Parliament has worked well. There have been breaches of the rules every now and then, but they have not been extensive and they were able to be dealt with, so I do not think very many problems will emerge from that.

The passage of this motion will create the anomaly that the rules for broadcasting the House on radio will now be somewhat different from the rules associated with television. I think the Committee should give early consideration to the implications of that and recommend some appropriate changes on the strength of what it finds.

One section of the motion deals with a request to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) for advice. That advice arrived a fair bit earlier than we expected it would--as the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife) knows, because we gave him a copy of it--but I will leave the motion as it stands and we will pass that advice straight to the Committee rather than go through the bother of trying to devise a different set of words which would allow the Committee to take that on board. From my understanding of conversations between the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and the Manager of Opposition Business, I do not think the Opposition has much trouble with this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) arises from the recommendations in the report of the Select Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives, which was tabled in August. The Opposition supports this motion, which proposes the adoption of the 12 recommendations made by the Committee in its report entitled The Eyes Have It.

SPEECH.PARA: In a few instances the Opposition would have liked this motion, which provides for the live broadcasting of the proceedings of this chamber to continue on television, to go a little further. I will refer to these later. But, as there is provision for another review in 1993, we believe it is reasonable to see how these guidelines work and to amend them again, if necessary, following the review.

Two of the most important recommendations which will be adopted if this motion is agreed to are the provision for the televising of committees of the House and, as the Leader of the House mentioned, the adjournment debate. This is an advance which the Opposition welcomes. We have been saying for some time that there did not seem to be any valid reason for excluding the adjournment debate from either television or radio. If the adjournment debate is to be available for television, it must follow that it should be carried on radio. Accordingly, I assume that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, as referred to by the Leader of the House, will take this up and ensure that the necessary adjustment is made. This will end the broadcasting prohibition on the adjournment debate, which has been in force since 1946--apparently imposed at the time for no other reason than a financial consideration.

Equally important is the decision to recommend that the committees of this House can be telecast. This will not only broaden the scope of coverage available to TV news organisations but also give the Australian people an insight into some of the major work undertaken by committees. It will also help them to have a better understanding of the work that parliamentarians are involved in while in Canberra. Being able to see the work of the committees will help members of the community to appreciate that being a member of parliament not only involves making speeches and asking questions in the House but also includes a range of other activities as important--sometimes more so--as what transpires in this chamber.

In effect, through the adoption of this motion based on the select committee's report to Parliament, I am glad to say that we are catching up with the television age. Australia was among the pioneers in the radio broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, being the second national Parliament of the Commonwealth of Nations, after New Zealand, to introduce the practice.

So far as television is concerned, we in this House have moved much more cautiously, with a trial period of televising which began only in February of this year. In the interim, of course, we have permitted the television cameras to record some of the more notable parliamentary events. Since 1984, televising of the Budget Speech and reply has become an accepted component of proceedings of the House. Television coverage of several other major economic statements and Opposition replies has also been authorised, as well as the debate on the motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of January 1991 relating to the Gulf war.

All this has provided valuable preparation, but it has been no real substitute for the public being able to get some appreciation of what goes on in Parliament through live telecasts of proceedings. It is true, of course, that the guidelines will continue to impose some restrictions, but they are sufficiently broad to convey what really goes on here in what is the nation's major political forum.

In this respect, I have one or two critical reservations. I would have preferred the adoption of a common set of guidelines for both Houses. I regret, for instance, that no withdrawals or points of order are to be shown in any replay of broadcast, even though they have been carried earlier in the live version. This suggests a sensitivity to image, rather than being prepared to present what goes on here in the way that it happens.

Sanitisation will not engender the esteem that we should be seeking for both the Parliament and its work. There has to be an openness about what goes on here if we are to improve the public's perception of politicians and the political process in Australia. There is, after all, a sense of disillusion in the community about politicians and about what they promise and what they deliver. By opening this House to television viewers right around the country, we are imposing a discipline on ourselves to raise our standards and address the urgent issues which confront our nation so that people can see that we can responsibly represent their interests.

It probably is necessary, as has been recommended, that the Joint Statutory Committee on Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings review the scheduling of radio broadcasting of proceedings, though I recognise that there are difficulties. However, any such review should in no way seek to curtail television coverage which, as the Committee's report shows, is creating viewer interest with, according to a recent survey, an average of 68,000 people being drawn to Question Time.

For some time I had been concerned about whether the guidelines covering Question Time were flexible enough to fully capture that very lively segment of the proceedings. However, I am now assured that the camera guidelines, with provision for wide-angle shots, do provide scope for conveying the real character of Question Time. But it is something that should still be monitored between now and the next review.

I note too the suggestion for a weekly parliamentary program. I trust that this will be pursued. I think an interesting round-up program interspersed with some comment and interviews could emerge and generate interest, not only on Australian networks but also perhaps overseas. It is certainly worthy of consideration.

We are proposing here to allow television stations to use parliamentary excerpts in their promos on air. In taking up this privilege, they must accept that they are bound to use parliamentary material in station promos in a fair and responsible way for the genuine promotion of bona fide news. Any dramatic distortion of Parliament, or use of parliamentary excerpts in a way that diminishes the standing of the Parliament, should not be tolerated by this House, and the Speaker and the Committee will need to carefully watch this aspect.

Another matter that I wish to raise in this debate is the question of television and radio coverage when, and if, the Leader of the Opposition chooses to reply in a major debate, such as the Budget, at a different timeslot to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer or any other Minister who might have carriage of the legislation. Strictly speaking, under the Standing Orders the Leader of the Opposition should be able to reply to the Budget or any other major Government statement at whatever time he chooses. While there is nothing to compel TV and radio coverage of such a reply, over the years reciprocal coverage has become established practice. On the basis of fairness and balance that, of course, should continue. But I suggest that the networks should be prepared to cover the Leader of the Opposition, even when he chooses to reply in a different timeslot to the Government spokesperson, especially when this is clearly permissible under the Standing Orders.

The conditions set down for televising state that reporting must be fair and accurate and such `as to provide a balanced presentation of differing views'. While I realise that covering the Leader of the Opposition at a different timeslot may present some programming difficulties, it was no problem when the Budget Speech was given at 7.30 p.m. If the Opposition chooses to make its response at that time, or at 8 o'clock, I suggest that TV coverage should be extended to it on the same basis as the Government's offering. The principle should be that television should match one live speech with another live speech. The timing of speeches in the Parliament is a matter for the Parliament. It is television's duty to convey the proceedings of Parliament as they happen. This is certainly an area that needs clarification and one which should be resolved before next year's Budget.

While, apart from the decision to televise the adjournment debate and the proceedings of the committees of the House, the general thrust of what is proposed does not really change the nature of the telecasts to any great degree from what we had during the trial period, they are a significant step forward in that we are formally providing for telecasts of the proceedings of the House. We have been tardy in coming to this point and, as the record shows, the Government has had to be goaded into it under Opposition pressure.

Although the viewing audience may not be big, the surveys that have been done show that the numbers are growing. When something really big occurs more people turn to the TV, and some of those are usually retained as regular viewers. For people in our rural communities who tend to follow what goes on more closely than those in metropolitan areas, regular telecasting of Parliament is going to be a boon, especially the repeat broadcasts in the evening.

There is no doubt that the televising of our proceedings would go some way to restoring the relevance of this House to the affairs of the nation. With individual members more visible to their constituencies, I hope it will also see us lift our game and that Question Time will become more relevant and less demeaned by overuse of Dorothy Dixers and longwinded ministerial replies. I hope there will also be less resort to the guillotine which has been so much a feature of this Government's legislative process.
Carriage of this motion will be another landmark in the history of this Parliament and I believe that it will enhance the role of the House in the democratic process.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, we were debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, which, interestingly enough, was introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), whose role in this field has not been particularly notable. I will address some aspects of that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: For my part, a number of these changes are very welcome. Indeed, as I was Minister for Social Services for a period of three to four years, I know the difficulties in trying to ensure that there are not too many anomalies in the welfare system. I register that, every time one adjusts a benefit, all one does is move the margins of discontent.

In several of the proposals there is much to be commended. For example, the new child bereavement payments, which provide for some continuity of payments of family allowance after the death of a child, are to be commended. The tragedy of the Strathfield shootings in the circumstances which have been discussed in the House earlier I think are matters which every honourable member would endorse. Indeed, there is nothing more tragic than the death of a child in a family, and I think the circumstances of providing for that continuity of entitlement are certainly something that we would all accept.

Equally, I believe the increase in child disability allowance needs to be supported. I have long had a fear that there are enormous difficulties in trying to provide equity for those with disability. I am not happy with the changes that the Government has introduced in some respects for the handling of those who have disabilities. For all that I know, it is the fashion that they be housed separately and many succeed in accommodating their new environments very effectively.

Parents are worried--through the Challenge Foundation, I know that some worry greatly--that as their children grow older their ability to be able to care for them under these new arrangements will become less and, when they go, there is the inevitable concern as to whether or not there will be anybody to care for them at all. I support that amendment. I equally agree with the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the opposition he expressed to the reduction in rent assistance waiting periods.

The part of the legislation to which I really want to draw the attention of the House and on which I wish to speak is that pertaining to family allowance. I think all of us are aware that this is the current form of child endowment, a measure introduced by Harold Holt in the 1941 Budget. Over the years, this measure has in a way been related to the benefit first introduced in the industrial sense through the Harvester decision, when there was essentially a basic wage for a man and a wife and their two children.

With the social changes that have occurred and the inevitable pressures that there are on the family, I want to express a few concerns I have about the alterations in this Bill and my opposition to them. Firstly, the family allowance was the product of fundamental changes to the child endowment system introduced during the Fraser-Anthony Government days. Our intent was to ensure that those with children were not disadvantaged in the overall structure of the social welfare tax system.

It is always difficult to find an equitable balance. Family allowance has some problems and it has gone from one side of the Budget to the other. To a large degree, it is now cash payments instead of coming through the tax system. There are inevitable difficulties in trying to ensure equity in a society where to a greater extent both partners of a marriage work. Those difficulties arise not only where both partners work but also in the case of a single parent. It is almost inevitable that, with the financial pressures that are brought to bear, at least one parent works.

So the first thing I would say in my concern about these changes is that I believe the nature and character of family allowance are being fundamentally changed because, for the first time, a number of people are to be excluded from any entitlement at all. I want to come to the basis of exclusion. I do not want anybody to believe that in anything I say I am opposed to the idea of having an income means test to discriminate or to separate entitlement between those who might reasonably be said to be in need and those who are not.

I know that in the past family allowance has been available, irrespective of either income or assets. I believe to a degree in the social equality sense that can be justified. Within a family those who do not seek to work have the same responsibilities for their children as those who do. There is certainly a difficulty for many who, having been in the work force, suddenly find themselves at home without that independent income. In many ways, when the family allowance benefit was first introduced it was seen as a way to provide some income, particularly for married women who wished to stay at home. As I was involved at the time in government, I had a great deal of sympathy for that point of view.

It is in the general concept of ensuring that there should be recognition of children and the role of those children that child endowment and family allowance, and now family allowance supplement, have their particular direction. I am concerned in the social sense that there are many families today who, under this particular provision, are going to be excluded as a result of changes introduced by the present Treasurer. In his days as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy he contributed much to the plight of those about whom I now wish to speak.

In his second reading speech, the Treasurer referred to both the new family assets test and to the earlier debate--the extent to which the Government had tried on earlier occasions with other assets tests only to be rejected in the other place. This particular measure is to introduce, from 1 January 1992, a family assets test of $600,000 of net assets, excluding the family home. There are three aspects to that on which I want to particularly spend a little time. The first is the quantum.

I find it absolutely farcical that we are debating this legislation in a week when the two major institutions--AMP and National Mutual--have announced a 20 per cent drop in the asset backing of their portfolios. More significantly, they have acknowledged that there has been a drop of 40 per cent in their real estate portfolio. It is true that much of that relates to commercial property in Sydney. We should note that there has been a 40 per cent drop in the valuation of the real estate portfolios of the two major real estate investors in Australia. These are two big institutions and, within their superannuation entitlements, within the balance sheets that reflect the flow of funds, they have had to make an adjustment across the whole of their portfolios of 20 per cent, but I gather that the real estate section is down by 40 per cent.

From 1 January there is to be a $600,000 family assets test. We are looking at the arbitrary valuation, set presumably on a market assessment, that is generally the criterion from which valuer generals have laid down their judgment. So that $600,000 is not market adjusted. It is not a criterion that is in any way set to take account of changing prices. It is set across Australia irrespective of location and irrespective of financial climate.

As one who is particularly concerned at the moment about two sectors of the community--that is, the small business sector and the rural sector--I know that, when we take account of that 40 per cent drop to which I referred a moment ago, the $600,000 has no equity in it. Of course, the Minister will say, `Yes, but we have compensatory provisions'. I will come to them in a moment.

Let us look at the arbitrary application of an assets test which in the future is going to be the limit beyond which there will be no family assistance available. My concern is that, as far as FAS is concerned, there is a real problem in trying to ensure that all children receive an adequate access to education. I do not pretend that the amounts paid by government under these benefits are ever going to be able to provide for all the necessities of a child. But I can tell honourable members that in my part of the world I have seen farms that are unable to be sold, small businessmen going broke--we know of the record number of bankruptcies--and children being withdrawn from school at the end of their primary education because their parents can no longer afford to keep them at school; and this legislation is supposedly dealing with an equitable situation amongst all families.

Of course, it will be said, `But there is a hardship provision'. I have never seen a more onerous hardship qualification in my life. The limit for net assets--that $600,000--as I have endeavoured to illustrate is nonsense in financial terms. Whatever the limit, no matter what figure we put there, I do not believe it could be sufficient to permit those who are genuinely in need--and some of those to whom I referred have children who are being denied equitable treatment--to have a reasonable chance of getting that minimal social security benefit.

I began by talking about what I see as inequitable treatment in regard to family allowance. I see that allowance as a benefit to try to help children; to try to give children, through those who are responsible for them, some assistance to ensure that they are given an equitable opportunity to be educated, housed, fed and brought up as young Australians. I do not believe that the application of an assets test, using any figure, is a criterion which can be justified, given the variable market circumstances, the rural collapse, the financial predicament in which we in Australia find ourselves, that 40 per cent reduction in regard to real estate values, and the real crisis arising in many instances from the fact that, even where a valuation is placed on a property, there is no capacity to sell.

Indeed you, Mr Deputy Speaker, know so well that there are enormous problems in a large part of Australia. One can put a value on a place; but I know of a place--with willing sellers--that has been on the market for two years. Let us be honest, the people who are out there buying at the moment are the superannuation funds, which will look twice at these properties in view of the deterioration in the value of their assets; the odd neighbours with cash--and there are not too many of them around at the moment; or perhaps the very occasional alternative investors--and it would be very unusual if they were out there looking for rural estates.

So, firstly, we have the deterioration in values; secondly, we have the problem that valuations really do not mean a thing because they are an arbitrary judgment by a bureaucrat, taken in good faith but without any relationship to the genuine value of the place; and, thirdly, in many instances the assets are just not realisable. Even if someone walked off his holding, it is still there related to him. But then it is said, `Of course, we have excluded the family home'. This criterion, supposedly, is to provide equity because the family home, curtilage and debt are to be taken off this obligation. What the Government is saying to any owner of a well run property or small business whose debt in normal circumstances is under control and who has a family home, curtilage and debt excluded, and anything like a reasonable place in normal times is virtually that the $600,000 limit will apply.

I remember Professor Freddy Gruen making a recommendation to the Government not long after it decided that the Prime Minister's promise that there would be no capital gains tax really did not mean very much. Of course, we have seen subsequent instances of the Prime Minister's not keeping promises that he has made to the public. At about that time Professor Gruen brought down a report that said that, for there to be horizontal equity, capital gains tax had to apply to the family home, as it does to any other asset. I suggest to the Treasurer that, in considering this family allowance and this criterion of an assets test which he is going to apply, he should ask himself how he can equate the value of a city home--or, for that matter, a country home--with the value of an asset? As we all know, quite often in small business the home is part of the premises. So, although one can take out one little part, the premises have to be included. With a property, quite often the value of the family home is nowhere near the value of the other assets, because it is from those other assets that the property owner earns his income. Indeed, I suggest it is on those other assets that a good farmer will have been spending money. And this is supposed to provide equity!

The disparity in value between family homes, whether in the city or in the country, is such that I think it is grossly inequitable. Indeed, only today I have been told the story of a family who have just been forced by the bank to sell up. Apparently they had a fire back in 1954. They had a beautiful home, and four other station hands' homes on the property. The whole place has been sold for $750,000. I suspect that that family home alone, if it had been in the city instead of way out in western Queensland, might well have sold for $500,000 or perhaps more if it had been on the right site. But, of course, that does not apply in the bush. The value of a family home in isolation is not the cost of building it or the cost of replacing it. It is a different value altogether. It is certainly not a criterion that can be applied with equity, as I see it, with the exclusion of the family home, curtilage and debt. For that reason, I do not believe that there is horizontal equity in the exclusion of the family home. I certainly do not believe that those in the bush and those in small business are being dealt with fairly, and so I believe that the criteria applied are inequitable and unjust.

The whole concept of introducing an assets test for family allowance and family allowance supplement is, to my mind, based on the wrong premise. It is based on the idea that there are people who have these very valuable assets who are trying to sneak through the system. To that I would say that that is the purpose of the income test.

When I was Minister for Social Services I found that there were always difficulties in trying to apply any sort of a means test or assets test, so when I became Minister for Primary Industry back in 1970-71, when we had enormous difficulties, I introduced a hardship provision which was made part of the rural adjustment package. That meant that household support was equated to the unemployment benefit, and the whole of the assets of the person, because of the uncertainty of value, were excluded in determining that person's entitlement. We provided that household support to a large number of people who were in an extraordinarily impecunious situation.

This legislation in its present form discriminates harshly against those who need help the most. There is no criterion for assets that is equitable. At a time of economic difficulty and of disparity between different people in the community, when some are unable to keep giving their children an education, and at a time when land values have certainly slid dramatically, an assets test of this sort will exclude a large number of people who are in critical need of financial help through the family allowance and family allowance supplement schemes. For that reason, I do not support the proposal that has been advanced by the Minister. I regard it as inequitable in its approach, and I very much regret that I see it, in the way that it has been pursued by the Government, more as a device than as a genuine attempt to strike some sort of a balance between the various needs of people in our community.

I do not accept as equitable an alignment with the Austudy income threshold, but I will not in any way suggest that there should not be a balance by which we determine who should receive Austudy and who should not. I guess any income test becomes difficult. I accept that there should be an income test on quantum, but I fear that for far too many in rural Australia, even under that Austudy test to which the Treasurer referred, there are difficulties. I can tell honourable members that for country children who have to board and stay away from home, the cost of receiving an ordinary education is far greater, and I believe that this legislation discriminates significantly against them. For that reason, I do not support the introduction of the assets test into this legislation, and I certainly will not be supporting it if it should come to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This issue has been one of the more difficult ones for me to confront in my parliamentary career, the reason being, of course, that I represent a very large group of farmers--wheat and sheep producers primarily--and I am very cognisant of their current economic circumstances. I am the owner of a farming property that could be considered, I would think, typical of those in my electorate. I am well aware of the financial circumstances that would be confronting any person seeking to live on and run a farm as the sole source of family income. Such people would be substantially in negative income circumstances. Every day I pick up the newspapers it appears that the price of one of those principal sources of income--wool--falls a little further. Consequently, in this very large Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) we find a provision relating to the family allowance as we know it today.

SPEECH.PARA: I am old enough to remember the original child endowment and the great discussions about that. I am old enough to remember when Malcolm Fraser was lauded by every political party when his Government introduced the present concept of the family allowance because it paid money to carers. It reversed the situation where there was a small amount of child endowment but primarily a tax rebate or tax deduction which of course generally went to the breadwinner, and the breadwinner did not necessarily pass that benefit onto the wife, who was usually the carer.

Over time there has been criticism that people on high incomes really did not need that benefit and that the money they received should have been redirected to others. I have not really contested that argument; notwithstanding that, in my view, people who have children, be they rich or poor, suffer quite a disadvantage financially compared with those who do not. I have read statistics which give the differential between a four-unit family and a two-unit family. They show that a four-unit family needs an additional $20,000 a year to have living standards the equal of a couple who have no children at all.

Nevertheless, the Hawke Government in 1989 decided to apply some income tests. They were reasonably generous, commencing at $53,550 plus $2,678 for additional children past the first child. Those figures have grown through indexation, and they are now $62,057 and $3,104 respectively. That is an income test. If the Parliament were debating today the definition of income, if it were proposing to lift what I might call the corporate veil and to decide what is the real income of individuals, and if it were to ask itself whether taxable income is the true measure of people's disposable income, I would bring to this Parliament a wealth of knowledge of how the business sector in particular manages to hive off income.

Over the recent years of mega-richness, time and again it was at least rumoured that some of the very wealthiest people were getting Austudy for their children. Why? It was because personally they have no income. There are many aspects of the taxation system that give tax deductions when in fact no money is lost. It is probably less today than in the days of investment allowances when one could buy a $100,000 item on lease for an outlay of about $2,000 and gain a $40,000 tax deduction. All the Taxation Office ever looked at was a person's taxable income. It was quite silly, and in those days it would have been more like a $60,000 deduction if the item was depreciable.

If we were talking about income tests today I would be doing my best to see a fair and equitable arrangement because I agree that there is a level of income above which it is probably just not necessary that the taxpayers of Australia should further support someone's income. But we are not. We are talking about asset testing. We have heard the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who, like me, sees this situation daily. The simple fact is that in the last Budget the Government came to this House suggesting that persons with more than $300,000 in assets should not be eligible for the family allowance. The opposition of the coalition was such that in attempting to sweeten that, and I guess to get it on the statute books, the Government took that figure up to $500,000. To its credit, the Opposition at that time held the line and, with the aid of the Australian Democrats in the Senate, that proposal was defeated.

That resulted in substantial criticism in this place of our leader, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and others. I was very grateful that he managed to stand onside with us on that occasion because as far as I am concerned we took the right decision. Now we are back discussing not $500,000 but $600,000--$600,000 excluding the family home and after the removal of any debts associated with the business.

Let me get down to something that is fundamental to most people who have assets. Most of them rely on them for income, so there is a direct relationship between income and the ownership of assets. We read in the paper day after day of the return that people can expect on their assets, and of course that return is always predicated on the value of those assets from day to day. It is usually referred to in percentage terms. There is a little bit of history about that and it is particularly notable in the rural communities because, as I say, people rely on their assets for income. In the case of rural communities the asset--typically the family farm--is home, business and income; it is the lot. That is all they have got. Very few farmers have any substantial extra assets. It is a family farm; it has been inherited; it has no value; the farmer has no plan to sell it; and he did not buy it.

But there is an authoritative body of opinion that says that over time a farming business will return about 3 per cent on the investment involved. If one looks at the ABARE figures for recent years, we find that in 1988-89 ABARE declared the return on the assets of a farming enterprise was 3.7 per cent. In 1989-90 it was 2.5 per cent and in 1990-91 it was minus 0.3 per cent. Any average of those figures is well below 3 per cent, and I remind honourable members that 1988-89 was a good year.

When we go back to these two provisions, the income test and the assets test--$62,000 for the income test and $600,000 for the assets test--the clear inference is that farming assets after debt return 10 per cent. Okay, those figures I have cited would include debt. Nevertheless, we have to take into account a few simple facts about farming. If, for instance, a farm were worth $1m, the banks would be unlikely to lend more than $200,000 or $300,000--and it would depend when the $1m valuation was made. Banks have been traditionally very conservative in the amounts of money they lend to the rural sector. The fact is that a $1m farm would be very unlikely to have $400,000 worth of debt, and therefore it has a net value in excess of this $600,000.

I remind honourable members that the value of that property is not what the valuer general puts only on the land; the value of that farming enterprise is everything that is there, less debts. There is machinery. If a farmer wants to buy a decent header in my electorate today he will get small change out of $200,000. Farmers have learned that it is not wise to buy things until they have got the money because when they used to contract debt to buy machinery they very soon lost their farms. That is one single item of equipment, but a farmer does not harvest a crop until he has bought the tractor and the combine and all the other things. A farmer could have $600,000 worth of equipment on a typical farm without trying very hard--certainly equipment worth $400,000 to $500,000.

Then of course there are the animals. Cattle are worth $600 or $700 each, if they can be sold. They are saleable, but if a farmer sells all of his breeding stock he is out of business. There is a similar situation with sheep. Notwithstanding the terrible price of wool, the animals have a reasonably high value. Again, if they were to be sold the farmer would not have an enterprise. But they sit on the property, add to the assets, and may deny families access to the family allowance if this legislation is passed.

I bring honourable members back to my example. If the true value or the true return of a farming enterprise is 3 per cent and the Government, notwithstanding the very correct arguments of the right honourable member for New England, is hell bent on going down the road of an asset test, why not let it take account of that return? It is simple enough; it is simple arithmetic. It means that the asset should have a value of about $2m. If the Government wanted to argue a value of $1.5m and change this legislation accordingly, I would probably accept. We should be looking at about $2m, not $600,000. It shows the immaturity of this Government in terms of business enterprise that it thinks even small businesses can achieve 10 per cent returns. They do not; they never have; and they should not be categorised as doing so--not when we have an income test that clearly is $62,057.

The first point I want to make is that we should be extending this particular asset test, not because I like the concept but, because the Government has initiated this, I have taken the value to $2m. I draw the House's attention to the fact that in the committee stages I will move an amendment to this clause to deal with that point.

The other aspect of this matter is that, if one is an income earner and has more than one child, one is allowed an extra $3,000. If the asset value of one's property is the source of one's income, why can one not extend the asset value of the property if one has more children? It seems pretty logical and fair to me. Consequently, I will move an amendment to extend that, to add $100,000--3 per cent again--for each additional child. I am so committed to this that I intend to see that the Parliament votes on this amendment to test out people's commitment. It is a matter of great concern to me.

When someone throws a figure like $600,000 in assets around, there is an immediate belief that that refers to a wealthy person. Let us look at my million dollar farmer who may have $300,000 worth of debt. I will tell honourable members what his problems are today. Firstly, he cannot sell his farm. As the right honourable member for New England said, they are basically unsaleable. Secondly, notwithstanding all those additional assets, he cannot borrow against them because no-one will lend him any more money. Thirdly, because he is now considered such a wealthy person, he is not eligible for any of the normal welfare programs, such as the dole, and this Parliament is about to say that his wife can no longer collect $10 a week per child up to the first three children and $13-odd if she has a fourth child. When we have women in my electorate walking up to the supermarket checkout and finding that they do not have enough money to pay for the groceries in the trolley, which they have been very careful in selecting, that is pretty serious.

When I mentioned this figure of $2m today, someone said to me, `How could you go to the unemployed on the dole and tell them you want to give additional assistance to someone who has $600,000 worth of assets? How do they compare?' I said, `I will tell you how they compare: one has the dole and the other hasn't'. I remind honourable members that for someone with $600,000 net, no borrowing capacity, no ability to sell and no ability to realise at anything other than prices which would not pay off the debt, we are saying, `You can't have the only little bit of money you have left, the family allowance'. People say to me, `But if the property will only sell for less than that $300,000 or $400,000 debt, clearly the value is not $600,000'. They should tell that to the Valuer-General. What did he do in Perth the other day? There was almost a riot. He put out his values in Perth--I know that is not the country, but it is still small business--taking the boom activity of 18 months ago and applying it now.

One property that I happen to own was valued at $114,000 throughout the boom. The valuer general has now put it up to $400,000. Whom do the public servants go to when an individual seeks to retain the family allowance and wants to self-assess? They do not say that one's property is worthless. I will tell honourable members what they say. They say, `What is the value?' They are putting false values on these properties, which will take them up to levels that will drive these people out. That is the situation we have.

Are these special cases to be treated as rubbish because someone has a hate for people who own something? I cannot understand any Liberal arguing for a tax system that basically says, `We want to encourage you to save or invest' and then says, `But if you've got investments you can't have a little bit of help for your kids when you desperately need it'. That is what we are debating today--whether those people in desperate need should be assisted. The Government will say, `But we have the hardship provisions'. What are they? Firstly, they apply for two years only, to try to get this thing through the Parliament. Secondly, if one's income is less than $13,000 plus $624 for one's children and if one has no liquid assets, or liquid assets less than $10,000, one can have it anyway--the Government will be generous.

The simple fact is that in a farming enterprise if one does not have $10,000 one does not plant the next crop--if one does not have $30,000 or $40,000 one does not plant the next crop. We have a self-assessment system. This is the same as in the tax Act. The Government says, `You can self-assess; take the punt. Between November and February you will have the value of your wheat proceeds in the bank--$30,000 or $40,000--but just ignore that'.

I will tell honourable members something about self-assessment. Self-assessment no longer allows one simply to get a ruling to apply. If people come up before a random audit and are found to have not been truthful according to the standards of the Public Service, they are criminals--they have stolen from the Government. They are a lot worse than someone who just asks. This is what is confronting people. I cannot understand why we choose to do this thing at this time when people in the rural communities, as everybody knows, are in such dreadful shape.

The hardship provisions will not assist in most cases. They will demean people by the processes people must go through just to keep something that for 40 years in this country has basically been the right of every mother. I am not objecting to taking it from those who still have adequate income. I am quite happy to look at those who hide their income. But honourable members should remember that one can live in the metropolitan area with a $2m house with very simple corporate arrangements, have no income, and get all the money. The situation is the same in many other circumstances. The Government is barking up the wrong tree. It should have been looking into the income arrangements and leaving people with these small farming assets that unfortunately are worth a lot more than $600,000. (Time expired)
