The honourable member for O'Connor has foreshadowed an amendment. I understand that the chamber will divide on it. I will be absent when that happens. I would like to place on the public record the fact that I do not support the honourable member's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Like previous speakers, I want to emphasise in this debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) the problems that the proposed changes will have for the rural sector and also for small business. The Bill, of course, includes quite a variety of changes to many sections of social security legislation, different changes and benefits for those with disabilities and many other provisions. However, the Bill highlights and draws attention to the third attempt by this Government to introduce assets tests for family allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we are dealing with family allowances at all under social security legislation demonstrates how much family policy has changed over recent years. The $10 family allowance is all that is left of the once universal child endowment arrangements. For 40 years, child endowment helped every family with those extra costs that are associated with raising children. It was an example of fiscal equalisation, a recognition that it costs something more to have a family and that there ought to be some recognition, either in the tax system or by way of providing some degree of balance and assistance, for those families who take on that particular responsibility. Now it is merely another welfare measure. That may be good socialist propaganda or good socialist philosophy, but it really destroys what was an excellent concept that contributed greatly towards building Australia.

The family allowance, child endowment, was an investment in the next generation of Australians, an investment from which we have received rich rewards. Now it is just in the same category as the dole, sickness benefits and the like. Instead of emphasising and encouraging the raising and the development of Australian families, it seems as though now we will use immigration to import other people's children. We are not prepared to support our own Australian families, but we are prepared to place our emphasis in other areas.

Indeed, it is quite obvious that this Government places much greater emphasis on raising children in child-care centres by providing for additional child-care places in almost every Budget, and indeed boasts about the provision of those resources, but is unable to find sufficient funds to continue the universal child endowment. They have allowed it to degenerate to a mere $10 a week so that its effectiveness has been severely limited. Even more people are to be denied it but, more particularly, it is to be amalgamated with the whole family allowance arrangement eventually into a single benefit system.

As I mentioned earlier, this is the third attempt by the Government to introduce an assets test for family allowances. It tried initially in 1990-91 with a miserable $300,000 assets test. It was shamed into raising its bid to $500,000; but that was not enough. Now it is trying again, this time with $600,000--indexed, I might add, on 1 January 1993--but this also is not nearly good enough. Indeed, the deceit and dishonesty that has been associated with the Government's portrayal of its family allowance package is quite monumental.

The Government has been attempting to sell this package on the basis of the extra people who are going to receive family allowance supplement. It is true that some more families will be eligible to receive the $26.50 family allowance supplement payment. However, what the Government is choosing to overlook is that for the first time it is trying to implement an assets test for family allowance, a $600,000 assets test that will cut out thousands of families from receiving the allowance they have received for a very long period. In fact, very many families will be affected. The Government's own estimate is that $25.5m or more will be saved from this single measure in a year. At $10 a week, that amounts to a lot of families.

What is of particular concern to the rural sector is that the last time this matter was being debated in this chamber, evidence was presented from the National Farmers Federation and many other groups that around three-quarters of all the families that are going to lose their family allowance as a result of the assets test are farm families. I do not think that there have been any significant changes in the new arrangements which would alter that figure substantially.

This legislation makes a number of changes to the assets test rules. It changes the parent test into a family test. That is going to have particular effect on family partnerships, and again the major impact of that measure will be on family farms and family businesses. It is not uncommon for family partnerships to be established to help run family businesses or the family farms and to involve the children at an early age so that they take an interest in the business or the farm. In those instances now the assets of the whole family will be taken into account in determining the limit.

One benefit will be that primary producers will be able to deduct liabilities from their assets, and that obviously will be a significant improvement, even though it takes effect only from 1 January 1992. Very few people will benefit from that provision. The Government has estimated it will cost only $400,000, so clearly there will not be many beneficiaries.

The most significant change, and the measure which this Government is endeavouring to use to sell this package as being a little more humane than some of its previous attempts, is the inclusion of hardship provisions for those particularly affected. It is an attempt to soften the blow, but it is only a light softening of the blow. To begin with, the provisions apply for only two years. So hopefully people will swallow the poison, enjoy it for two years, and then feel the full consequences.

Under these hardship provisions the family allowance assets test will be relaxed in cases involving amounts above $600,000 where the income level is below $13,078 plus $624 for each additional child. However, there is a liquid assets limit of $10,000 for each family, which I am anxious to refer to in more detail later in my remarks. The family allowance supplement assets test will be relaxed in instances between $347,000 and $600,000, again with the same income limits applying. The Bill, in clause 37, defines liquid assets as including personal cash, shares and debentures, money in the bank, amounts due and readily realisable assets. All of them can total only $10,000 or the hardship provisions will not apply. It is not actually specifically included in the Bill, but many of the glossy publications and much of the publicity material that accompanied the announcement of these hardship provisions on Budget night included a specific provision that this $10,000 included working capital. I hope that when the Minister or the Parliamentary Secretary responds to this debate, he will clarify whether or not it is the Government's intention that working capital be included in this $10,000 total of liquid assets.

I also would be interested to know what kinds of shares and debentures are going to be included in this assessment. For instance, many primary producers are obligated, as a result of their production of a particular commodity, to have shares in a primary producer cooperative. These shares often revolve, and there is no possibility whatever of their being cashed out early or ahead of their time. They are just a way in which a particular cooperative recognises its equity. Surely those kinds of arrangements should not be included in liquid assets.

Most particularly, I want to refer again to this question of working capital. An amount of $10,000 is very, very small. Cropping farmers in particular, those who grow grain, cotton, sugar, fruit or any other similar commodity, have seasonal incomes. They have periods of very high expenditure, followed by just one or two months when their income is received. They need to hold on hand from their income in one year the money that they need for planting their next crop. And they cannot plant much of a crop for $10,000.

I know that the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has now made about three visits into the country and is starting to consider himself an expert on rural affairs. But I hope that even he has now discovered that one cannot plant a crop of wheat--or for that matter any other primary product that is likely to make a farmer viable--for $10,000. I am not a very big farmer by any means, but each year my family partnership budgets on approximately $100,000 to plant its crop and to bring it through to the stage of harvesting. If I borrow $80,000 of that $100,000 and have a mere $20,000, a mere 20 per cent, of the required needs of working capital in any kind of liquid reserves, under these particular arrangements I, and others in the same position, would not qualify under these hardship provisions. Indeed, they are Claytons hardship provisions which almost guarantee that any genuine working farm will be seriously disadvantaged. Under these hardship provisions, very few of those who are still in business will have the opportunity to qualify.

It is a serious problem for those who are endeavouring to guarantee their next year's income to accumulate the necessary funds to plant a crop, fertilise it, spray it, water it and tend it in all the ways that are required in this modern day and age. It requires a significant amount of capital to do just that task. Unless a farmer has to borrow pretty well 100 per cent of his working capital, he will not be eligible under these hardship provisions. Anyone who has to borrow 100 per cent of his working capital to produce his next crop is in very serious difficulty and is probably on the verge of bankruptcy, if not already bankrupt. Those are the kinds of hardship provisions that are being written into this legislation, and I appeal to the Minister to look at them again. The Government should exclude working capital altogether in coming to a conclusion on what are liquid assets and it should adopt a reasonable attitude in developing appropriate hardship arrangements.

I do not argue with the $13,000 income limit. Of course, it is significantly lower than applies to other social security recipients, such as those on the family allowance supplement. But it is obviously a hardship provision and so it is reasonable that there should be an income limit and that that income limit should be quite severe. But the working capital limit is unreasonable and ought to be reconsidered.

There are many faults with the whole principle of an assets test. Of course, it is anti-property by its very nature, but to fix it at an amount such as $600,000 or $347,000 is clearly treating it on an inequitable basis when compared with the income test. Income test levels are adjusted for each extra child. That does not happen with the assets test. There is no shading. You are either all in or all out. That sort of thing also does not happen with the income test.

Perhaps one of the worst features of the assets test is, as referred to by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), that not all assets are counted. The family home is exempted whether it is a caravan under a tree in the bush or a multimillion dollar mansion on the Sydney north shore; whether it is a working asset or the luxurious fruit of previous labours, a bequest, a gift or whatever. No consideration is given to the need of that asset to produce income.

Nor is there any recognition of whether the asset's value is actually realisable. What is a farm worth in this day and age? The valuation is unrealistic. A farm worth $1m a few years ago is perhaps worth theoretically $700,000 today. But, in truth, there are no buyers, so what is its real worth? If it were put on the market for $500,000, it would not be sold because no-one would want it at any price. The banks are carrying many of these people, allowing their asset value to slip away because they know that, if they foreclose on them, they will get even less than they would by attempting to carry the customers through. They know also that, by foreclosing on a number of clients, they will further erode property values and put even more producers in difficult circumstances. So, while the asset may have a theoretical value, that value is often unrealisable and should therefore be ignored in these kinds of issues.

Most importantly of all, the assets test is not related to earning capacity. One can earn $62,057, plus $3,104 for each additional child, and still receive the family allowance. That is the equivalent of around 11 per cent return on investment for the $600,000 assets test limit, and that excludes any capital gain. Bank interest or any business returning 11 per cent is very rarely found in this day and age. As the honourable member for O'Connor very rightly and forcefully pointed out earlier, ABARE's latest estimate of the return on a farm investment is not 11 per cent. It is not even one per cent; it is 0.3 per cent.

In other words, a farm valued at around $600,000, the maximum assets test limit proposed by this Government, would return on average $2,000 for the year. So a farmer earning on average $2,000 or less is considered to be too rich to get the family allowance supplement, while another person earning $62,057 or more can still receive the family allowance. This is clearly inequitable. The farmer on his knees at the bank manager's table, pleading for some carry-on finance after years of negative income, cannot get the family allowance, yet the bank manager sitting on the opposite side of the table can. That applies not just to bank managers but to many doctors, lawyers, senior public servants and university academics. Probably even members of Federal Parliament could qualify for the family allowance under the income test, but farmers on negative incomes cannot. What does that say for the Government's agenda for social justice? In fact, on ABARE's estimate of farm returns, a farm would have to be worth close to $10m before it would trigger the income test. Clearly, there is a gross inequity in all of these issues.

The Government takes this action at a critical time for the rural sector. In my electorate, there will be no dry land grain harvested this year. The whole Queensland crop is estimated at about 10 per cent of last year's. The sugar crush is almost over. The Government blames international factors, but does little of its own to relieve the hardship in the rural sector.

Of course, the rural sector misses out on most of the welfare measures available to other sectors of the community. The unemployment benefit is available for people who lose their job. People are not expected to put money aside for the day when they lose their job. Unemployed people qualify for this benefit very readily. However, social security is not available to farmers in their time of trouble. Rural adjustment assistance can be available, but more often than not it is only through loans, unless the farmer is already committed to leave the industry. There is a need for appropriate drought measures, appropriate subsistence measures, to tide farmers through their current difficult circumstances.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has proposed that a high level Ministry team be established to endeavour to address the rural crisis that we are currently confronting--the economic and cash crisis faced by so many farmers. His idea has a great deal of merit, although I have very little confidence that the sorts of high level Ministers that we need to be attracted to this team would lower themselves to be even concerned about the problems of rural Australia.

There is talk of bipartisan rural summits. The Queensland Graingrowers Association has been endeavouring to establish such meetings to initiate new ideas to come to grips with the current crisis. But, for many, all of these measures will be too late. Property values are falling. There are many forced sales and values are plunging. In fact, the circumstances are so desperate that the Queensland Government is now offering $200 food packages through Lifeline for farmers who cannot feed their children. How low has our country sunk.

It is good that the Government has chosen to recognise hardship provisions, but it has not gone anywhere near far enough. The hardship provisions fail to address the real tragedy of the bush at present. Many needy families will still miss out on these benefits. I ask the Government particularly to reconsider its definition of working capital, to look at the way in which it values family farms and--(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 implements the major part of the Budget announcements in the social security area. A number of the proposals are very welcome. The new child bereavement proposal provides for some extension of the family allowance payment after a child's death. This came up following the tragic Strathfield Plaza massacre. The increase in the child disability allowance is also welcome, indeed overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: In my brief remarks I will deal with the part of the Bill--division 7, clause 36--dealing with the proposed assets test and the new special hardship provisions in respect of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. I will refer later to the need--this has been canvassed by my colleague who preceded me, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and by other Opposition speakers--for the magnitude of assets, as specified in the test, to be larger and for the amounts of liquid assets referred to in the special hardship provisions to be interpreted with reference to the requirements of working capital where the families in question are the proprietors of a small business or a farm. I will come back to that.

I want to address a view, a belief, a point of principle, strongly held by a number of my colleagues on this side of the House; that is, family allowances are not social welfare but they are a part, in effect, of the tax system. They are an allowance of income in recognition of the high costs of raising children which should not be subject to means tests of any sort, albeit they are paid through the social security system in order to direct the money to the principal carer, in most cases the wife and mother. The argument is that these payments are assessed and made on the basis of judgments about horizontal equity, the equal treatment of families at comparable income levels, some without children, others with children. The costs of bringing up children are indeed heavy and it is this which is recognised by the family allowance payment and, at the lowest income levels, by the family allowance supplement.

However, that was a view that may have been sustainable in past times when the relative affluence of this country--its place in the income per head scale as one of the top half dozen countries in the world--prevailed, but it is not sustainable, I submit, in the circumstances of this country in more recent times with a world ranking down somewhere in the twenties.

Further, I make the point that in previous legislation this Parliament has collectively accepted the view that, desirable as equal payments in respect of children at all levels of family income may be--that is the principle of horizontal equity, propounded with great conviction by a number of my colleagues, as I have said, and the history of which was so eloquently traced by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) this morning--nevertheless, in terms of priority, where there are limited resources in the public purse, there has to be regard to real need in making such payments. In fact some time back there was concurrence in the application of an income test to the family allowance payment, but if there is concurrence with an income test, by the same logic there should also be an assets test.

The proposal for such a test in a previous Bill was rejected in the Senate. The proposal before the House in this Bill represents the Government's effort to come up with a more reasonable proposal. I believe this proposal is far from perfect, but that is an issue I will return to in a moment.

I want to have recognised publicly that the acceptance of this assets test for the family allowance--as the lesser of two evils in the case of my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and on the part of a number of my colleagues--amounts to overriding a strongly held, long cherished principle that the family allowance is specifically not welfare and should be paid to support all children irrespective of family means. I recognise the strength and sincerity with which that view is held. Nevertheless, in the reduced circumstances of this country, the hard fact is that it is not sound policy to pay this allowance to all, irrespective of income or assets.

We will never turn our backs on compassionate support for those in genuine need, but pursuit of the principle of so-called horizontal equity, in some cases with all but religious fervour, to the point where it is argued that family allowance ought to be paid to families taking the existing limit with incomes in excess of the $62,057 per annum--that is about $1,200 per week--or families with four children where the limit would be about $71,000 per annum, as in effect this Parliament has decided, is pressing the principle beyond a reasonable limit.

There is the opposing principle, or perhaps reality, that at some point priorities in other areas in a situation of limited resources take over--that point in this case being, in the view of the Parliament, at the level of income of $62,057 per annum in the case of one child or up to $71,000 per annum where there are four children. The alternative priority that comes into play, most simply put, is that we can, for instance, help many more people in dire need if we siphon off resources in this admittedly priority area of family allowance at the point referred to.

We have this existing income test; the inevitable complement of that is an assets test. Accordingly, the introduction of this assets test is not opposed, in many cases somewhat reluctantly. I am stressing that in the sadly reduced state of the Australian economy--I am not really referring to the current recession, rather to the falling-living-standards, rising-overseas-debt economy of which the current recession was the inevitable end point, and that is what we have had over recent years leading up to this time-- we cannot afford the largess of assistance not targeted to real need.

I suspect that will long be the case, but the priority now is to rebuild the Australian economy, to turn the economy around. The fact of the matter is that what we have had in Australia is many years of complacency, to put it at its mildest, of gradual slip, from a country in the first half-dozen in the world in terms of GDP per head down the ranking to the order of 20 or so.

The rate of slippage has accelerated in recent years. There is no doubt about that. There has been a refusal to acknowledge the reality of our situation. A recent article in the Business Review Weekly puts it this way: `The easy times have gone'. There is a refusal to acknowledge that.

We need to recognise that there is a vast challenge facing this country to work our way towards a containment of the foreign debt and to reverse the process of decline and regain sustainable prosperity. That requires an across the board reform agenda for fundamental change. That will include a consistent, sound monetary policy with the main target being to reduce inflation and a Budget policy over the medium term for reduced spending in order to give us more national saving. That is absolutely essential if we are to achieve economic growth with rising living standards, and a reducing current account for stabilisation of the debt.

We need labour market reform for enterprise bargaining; infrastructure change for lower costs of power and transport and so on; more competition and privatisation; tax reform--in particular, the goods and services tax; and a streamlining of decision and approval processes for new developments. All of these are main parts of the agenda.

When that is working there will be higher living standards for all, including families with children. When we turn the country around by a process of reform of this nature, indeed there will then be higher living standards for all, including families with children. That is what we need to focus upon. That is what we need to achieve to mobilise as a nation. But on that journey we have to accept limits in providing assistance where the need is not the greatest, even in respect of families and children. The need is to keep our eye on that main game.

I again say that the introduction of this assets test is not opposed. However, as is nearly always the case, the particular parameters of the proposal in my view are not sound. A small business, a corner shop, or a farm at $600,000, which is the proposed limit, generally speaking is not a viable proposition. To say that a family unit which is the proprietor of such a business--it will not be earning much of an income--cannot have the family allowance is ill-judged. There are many other difficulties associated with the $600,000 limit in today's circumstances. The state of today's markets have been strongly set out by other speakers, including my colleagues the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for O'Connor.

There are, in addition, the hardship provisions. In various ways I believe that they are unrealistic. As a number of my colleagues have already argued, the requirement for liquid assets to be less than $10,000 is quite unrealistic. A family farm enterprise, for example, may well need that sort of money by way of working capital to plant a crop. I would argue, as have other speakers from this side of the House, that the proposals in the Bill require some sort of amendment or at least an explicit understanding to the effect that in making an assessment in the case of a small business, farm or non-farm, the assessment take appropriate account of the requirements for working capital.

I stress that the principal point is that in the circumstances of this economy now, as we seek to rebuild the Australian economy, we have to bring an election on for us to be able to undertake that task. Many of the elements that I have mentioned will not and, indeed, cannot be introduced by the present Government, given its constituency. We will have to do it and in that context we have to give priority to the range of programs to effect fundamental change in our economy and in that the acceptance of an assets test in this area must be recognised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will be as brief as I can, but there are a few things I would like to say about the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). To a certain degree I will be repeating what a few of my colleagues have said throughout the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned about the regulations that we have in place today, particularly those relating to social security payments. Very few people within the community appear to understand them. The recipients are the ones who certainly do not understand. They should go and get advice from the Department of Social Security in order to receive their entitlements.

I believe that today we are caught up in a system which has been exacerbated by the Government in many respects. I make it quite clear that I am opposed to an assets test on the family allowance. I cannot support the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) simply because I am directly opposed to an assets test. I do not mind an income test; I think it is essential. I am opposed to an assets and an income test for aged pensioners. Why? The reason is that I believe there are many complications for the aged today. This worries them and they end up suffering from poor health.

I would like to say something about the family assets test of $600,000, excluding the family home. This is ridiculous for the farming community and the business community. This afternoon the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) pointed out very clearly that there has been a general decline of between 20 and 40 per cent in the valuation of property throughout Australia, whether it be farm property, commercial property or even residential property. As he said, we have seen the valuation by AMP and National Mutual decline by approximately 20 per cent. An asset of $600,000 is very meagre indeed. The average farmer today has an asset well in excess of that, but it is an asset that he is unable to sell in most cases simply because of the market and the drought. The Government is not sympathetic towards him or her.

The Government knows that its amendments do not meet the genuine needs of many people around the countryside. I have been sent by my electors to argue that the people in country areas are given a fair deal. I believe that the people involved in primary industry, those involved in agriculture, are the backbone of the country. They are suffering enormously today.

As a result of the policies of this Government over the last eight years, between $3 billion and $4 billion has been taken out of the pockets of the primary producer. The 1988 Kerin plan provided for the elimination of underwriting for wheat, the deregulation of the domestic market, the abolition of the floor price scheme for wool, the reduction in tariffs on imported sugar, and the reduction of dairy assistance. We also have to look at the reduction on the import tariffs for citrus juice and the elimination of the superphosphate bounty. These are all major issues concerning the assistance that was available to farmers. On top of this, as has been stressed today, we have the worst drought for many years. The Government knows this, yet the legislation before this House deprives those vitally affected people of family allowance.

I sometimes wonder who does the valuation on a property. I think it is a person sitting behind a desk. I have a firm conviction that, to get a logical conclusion on something, one must talk to a practical person who often uses his hands, not a person sitting behind a desk who is working to an Act of Parliament. However, he or she is the one to whom people must apply for support and who will make a determination.

I was reminded the other day of an instance of this in my electorate. A farmer who was forced to retire because of his health lost his age pension in 1985 and was forced to go back into dairying. On many occasions, while I have been driving by on the highway, I have seen him cross the road--and he has a job even to cross the road. He has reared eight children and all of them have been successful because he has provided the money for their education. He is a good citizen and he has paid tax throughout his lifetime, yet he has not applied for an age pension because he knows he is not entitled to it simply because of the assets test. He keeps a horse tied up at his back door so that he can ride across the road to inspect the cattle because he is unable to walk that far.

This is the type of person that I and the Opposition parties have sympathy for. There are many others like him within country areas. I have a returned serviceman in my electorate who is living on a run-down dairy farm. He and his wife are over 70 years of age. They are unable to sell any of their property, from which they get very little return. He bought a home in the town nearby for his mother, who is over 90 years of age and is receiving a pension. Because he bought her a home--so she is hardly a liability on the taxpayer--he is unable to receive any pension.

No wonder the people in our electorates complain when they see greenies and other people who do not believe in the cutting down of trees blocking the logging trucks from getting the timber into the local mills for processing. These are basically unemployed people whom the taxpayer is helping to keep. Yet those who have worked hard in their lifetime, for the productive side of Australia, are not entitled to receive assistance. There is nothing in this legislation that will assist the people we are taking about. I sincerely hope that the Minister will consider changing it, even at this late stage, because he knows of the anomalies in it.

I am entirely in favour of the assets test being abolished for the age pension and the family allowance. I have always held this belief firmly. I know that Government members will ask: why should a millionaire receive this assistance? They should look at the inequities of the scheme now before them and the fact that there are only a few people who may be classed as millionaires, and they will pay tax on their incomes. This is the important thing. They may receive the money, but the Government will get most of it back. We do not need an army of public servants to administer the various fractions of the legislation now before us. I am opposed to this legislation because of the principles that I hold. There are some good things in it, and I do not mind there being an assets test for Austudy--although income ought to be the consideration there--but I am opposed to the assets test for the age pension and the family allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to participate in this debate because I want to make it absolutely clear why the Opposition parties are supporting the Government on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and, most importantly--and this has been the focus of the debate in this House--go through the issue of the assets test on family allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise the context in which this decision has been taken. It is a difficult issue, an issue on which one has to strike a sense of balance. It is an issue that involves a number of difficult philosophical positions and concerns. It is an issue in which there have been an unbelievable number of changes in government attitudes and decisions over the last couple of decades, and of course it arises at a time when this country is in its worst crisis since the 1930s.

All of us are very genuinely concerned about the phenomenal pain and hardship that have been inflicted on the people of Australia--deliberately and knowingly--by this Government: `the recession we had to have'. That hardship and that pain are perhaps greatest in our rural communities, which not only have had the recession inflicted upon them but also have suffered the plight of very difficult international market circumstances where what at best could be described as corrupt market practices are squeezing them out of markets that they have traditionally thought of as their own. In many cases they have faced a collapse of their own individual markets and prices. So we are seeing a rural depression, in many cases, and certainly the worst circumstances since the 1930s. Some of my colleagues can go back earlier than that. It is very important, therefore, that we recognise that, despite the intensity of that pain and hardship, we have to keep a sense of rationality, direction and purpose when we face issues as difficult as these.

I am also particularly concerned about families. I know all my colleagues share that concern. We are concerned about families during the worst recession in 60 years and also, in a somewhat broader perspective, about the fact that this generation of Australians, under the policies that have been pursued by the Hawke-Keating-Kerin Government, is about to leave a lower standard of living to its children than the one that we have enjoyed ourselves.

In that context, we must face the issue. Some very tough decisions have to be made and we have to address the issue of the best way to help, and the best way to assist families, while recognising the realities of the economic circumstances in which we find ourselves.

Another element of the debate, of course, has been a lot of concern about how to help farms, and small businesses in particular. A number of speakers have spent quite a lot of time seeking to emphasise the need to help farms and farmers and to help small businesses in these circumstances. We have to ask ourselves some fundamental questions there too. Are family allowances really the most effective way of helping farms and small businesses in current circumstances? Or, is it not true that many of these problems that beset the small business community and the farming community stem from other factors?

They are problems that can be solved by a different approach to policy. They are problems that can be addressed. In many cases, they are problems that have been, as I have said before, deliberately created by a government that has had no sense of direction, no understanding of individual needs and hardships, a government which has devoted itself incessantly to internal factional fights and divisions and has not really shown any genuine concern about the pain and hardship that has been inflicted on average Australians as a consequence of its focus on internal Party differences of opinion, factional fights and so on. We can do a lot for farms and small business, but we will have to fundamentally change the way this country is governed and change policy to a direction different to that taken in recent years.

As my colleagues know, I have spent a lot of time thinking of the best way to assist families. In taking this decision, it would be totally wrong to conclude that, of course, we are not in favour of assisting families. But in the context of the circumstances I have described--of the recession and the prospects for our children that I have described--we have to face some pretty tough decisions about how best to assist families in current circumstances. A lot of the policy package that we will be bringing down in the near term actually addresses the issue of family assistance in, I think, the most fair and equitable way we can.

In current circumstances it is, of course, very much a question of balance. We would ideally like to be able to support all families in Australia. We would ideally like to be able to support all children in Australia. But in the economic circumstances in which we find ourselves--with people already complaining about the extent of debt, the level of real interest rates and the level of taxation--we have to make some pretty tough choices in directing that family assistance to those most in need and ensuring that it is effectively targeted. The alternative should be very clear. There has to be higher taxation, probably higher real interest rates and more debt, more pain and hardship. Maybe there will be short term gain for some families at the expense of long term pain for those same families. Indeed, a very strong argument can be mounted in the present circumstances that one can make it worse for the families one is trying to help, by trying to throw money at them rather than dealing with the problems and the root causes of those problems.

So when we come to the issue of family assistance, as we do in this particular piece of legislation, we have to recognise the fact that there is a need in these circumstances for targeting. When one looks at that, one recognises that, of course, families in different parts of Australia have different needs and that it is very difficult on occasions for governments to effectively target.

This particular measure, this assets test, as it is now brought to us, has gone through several phases in the course of the last several months as the Government has responded to pressure and seen the error of its initial ways. Earlier on we drew to the Government's attention the particular problem we had with the first version of the assets test as it was set up. We drew attention to the fact that we do have some asset wealthy, income poor, groups in our society who are finding it particularly difficult in current circumstances to get by. A significant percentage of that group is, of course, the farming community which is being forced this year to live on very low average incomes of just a few thousand dollars and are unable to do very much about their assets. It is very difficult, of course, to even contemplate the possibility of changing the nature of their asset structure and yet being forced into particular periods of hardship, as circumstances way beyond their control have been inflicted upon them.

In those circumstances, we were very concerned that the initial policy proposal of the Government really did not address the issue. It did not adequately take account of the nature of the farming situation, farmers' income and their assets. It certainly did not understand anything about hardship. We made a very strong play about that; we took a very strong position on it. It is as a result of that that we now have this alternative proposal.

As many colleagues here have debated some of the bits and pieces of that decision, I think we need to recognise that again it is, in the end, a choice on balance. We think the Government has come a long way in cutting the asset level off at $600,000, rather than closer to $300,000 where it started. It has particularly come a long way in defining that to be net of the family home, net of curtilage and net, importantly, of debt, which is a particular aspect of the hardship of a large part of the rural community at the present time.

In those circumstances, the Government has given a lot of ground and has been dragged screaming to reality in terms of recognising the magnitude of the problem, particularly of the farming community. Over and above that, of course, it has now recognised the need, although it initially mocked it, to do something about hardship. There are hardship provisions in here which my colleagues in the House, and those in the Senate as well, will continue to scrutinise very carefully to ensure that hardship is effectively dealt with under this particular piece of legislation. But in the end I say it is a choice. It is a difficult choice. It is a choice that raises for us a lot of our history, a lot of philosophical challenges and a lot of very difficult decisions about the best way to make sure that we are doing the best we can for those we represent in this place.

On balance, we have come down in favour of the view that we should support the Government on this particular assets test, in this particular form. But clearly we will continue to monitor the situation to see whether in practice it actually does what it appears to do on the paper on which it has been written.

The final point is to step back a bit from the particular issue of the assets test and assistance to families as I have discussed it, and raise another issue which I think is raised by a lot of the comments that have been made in this debate and have certainly been a feature of the consideration on my part and the part of a lot of my colleagues in recent days. It goes really to the very issue of what type of country we are trying to build in Australia.

A lot of people pine for the days of Bob Menzies, and why would they not? They were great days. They were days in which this country had very low unemployment, very low inflation, very low debt, and very real opportunity. It was a country of great dynamism. It was a country that was really moving and establishing its place in the world. There is a very sharp contrast between that type of world and the type of world we have today in 1991, the type of world that we have been dragged into by this Government that has absolutely no understanding of the magnitude of the pain and hardship that it has inflicted on average Australians. This Government has incessantly focused, as I said before, on silly leadership contests and games which have preoccupied it now for the 18 months since the last election to the point where it has not done anything to deal with the problems that are confronting the Australian economy and Australian society at this time. Indeed, every single decision it has taken in that 18-month period can be linked back to one deal or another.

We have right before us now the issue of the Fairfax bid. It reeks of a deal. It is being dressed up as if it has nothing to do with deals. We have had television ownership decisions and the Budget itself--a series of deals. But all through that period we have had no genuine attempt to deal with the problems that confront the average Australian. There has been no visible concern for the fact that there are now nearly one million people, even on the fudged data of the Government, unemployed.

The damage that the unemployment of one million people has done to Australian families should never be underestimated. It will stand as a monument, as I have said before, to our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who claims to have a special relationship with the working people of Australia. It will stand as a monument to him and to his administration that, in the centenary year of the ALP, he has created one million unemployed. This Government has seen a system develop where there has not been an effective understanding of how to deal with problems and how to act in the best interests of the people of Australia. If one is a member of the ALP and if a problem arises, one does another deal. The Government does not have any sense of direction, or vision, or understanding of the sort of society that we ought to be building in this country.

To me, it is a very clear cut choice and increasingly, between now and the next election, the people of Australia will be given a very clear cut choice. For the first time in a very long time, when we go to the next election people are going to see us as being fundamentally different from the ALP and they are going to see us as standing for a fundamentally different type of country from that which the ALP has built, one that will be managed in a fundamentally different way from the way the people on the other side of the House have decided to run it.

It is in that context that I get very offended when I hear the suggestion that, because we support in current circumstances something like an assets test on family allowances, we are somehow embracing a socialist ideal. We have no intention of embracing the sort of socialist ideal that those opposite flourish on. Communism may be dead in eastern Europe, where the people may be tearing down the barricades and the walls and may be building market based economies. But socialism is alive and well in Canberra. The main proponents of that socialistic approach to government are sitting here at the table, and I refer in particular to the one with the green folders, who is smirking. They have built the sort of system that has now taken jobs away from average Australians and has built a sense of dependency that is not consistent with the type of world that we want to build.

When we look at allocating assistance in 1991, we look at giving it to those in need. We do not look at using it as a way of building an empire, or as a way of building a whole structure of dependence. We do not look at it as a way of taking away from individuals what should rightfully be theirs. We do not look at it as a source of more compulsion, more control, more regulation and more government determination. We are looking at an alternative society in which the individual plays a much greater part, where individuals are left very much to themselves, beyond those who need genuine assistance from government. We want to create the type of world, in fact, where there is going to be enormous opportunity for individuals to look after themselves.

That goal is not possible under the sort of system that this group of people in government have built. They do not understand the advantages of market based processes. They do not understand the advantages of individual choice. They do not understand the advantages of competition. They think about control, they think about deals, they think about compulsion, and they think about achieving ends by taxation, charges and levies rather than about creating the sort of world in which individuals have a realistic opportunity to look after themselves. At the very beginning of that process in circumstances in which there are one million unemployed, the best thing one can do for families in Australia is make sure that those who want jobs can get jobs.

Those on the other side of the House do not understand even that basic element of what is required to build a new society. They do not particularly care that people get thrown out of the work force, because they go about building a social security and welfare structure that in time locks people into a situation in which they cannot have a job or do not want to have a job. They change people's attitudes, they change their livelihood, and they destroy the things that people really pride most--an opportunity to get a job, the self-respect and decency that go with having a job, and the ability to take home a sufficient amount of money to look after their children.

The fundamentally important point that we have to make in this debate is that, while in the difficult circumstances that exist in Australia today we support the very difficult decision that has to be made on an assets test for family allowances, we in no way embrace the socialist ideal of the other side of the House. As we bring down the detail of our policy package in the next few weeks, it will be quite clear to the people of Australia that we can build an alternative system; we can build a system in which individuals have an elevated position, one in which they are left to make choices for themselves, one in which the role of government is significantly reduced, one in which the reliance on centralised control is gradually broken down, and one in which individuals have a real opportunity to get a job and to look after their families.

That is what the debate is going to be about in the next few months, 18 months or whatever time it takes until the next election. It is going to be focusing on the difference between the centralised, individual deal dominated, regulated, non-market government process that this lot opposite have built and the one which really does try to re-establish the supremacy of the individual and the role of the individual in our society.

So it is for those and a lot of other reasons that we come to this debate willing to support the Government on a particular and difficult decision in relation to the assets test on family allowances which has seen the Government move a long way from the position in which it started. But it should in no way believe that we in any sense embrace the type of society that it has built. I do not want a situation in which, for example, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) determines which books my children read; nor do I particularly like the type of society in which the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) determines whether I can go to the doctor, or how long I am going to sit in a queue, or what my cities are going to look like. We are going to fundamentally change the nature of this country to the betterment of the individual and to the betterment of Australian families. That is what this debate is all about. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) would like to be here to answer the debate on this particular aspect of his portfolio responsibilities, because not too often do we have an opportunity to see such a spectacle as we have seen in the House tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) has concentrated a lot on the hardship provisions within the social security system, particularly as it relates to people in primary industry. But also contained in the Bill, and not touched on by many honourable members, is a wide range of other measures which have certainly made life a lot easier for a lot of people who also deserve that extra support from the Government and from the community simply because they are older, have large families or are unemployed and are suffering from a lack of income because of a variety of factors.

In the Bill, we look at issues such as the special child bereavement payments; the education entry payments; the extension of the hardship provisions for the carers who have been left behind when, perhaps, the person they have been caring for has gone into a nursing home; the extension of the Job Search allowance and sickness allowances; the changes to the rent assistance to give particular support to younger people; the child disability allowance increases; and the extension of the lodgment period for claims for family payments and bereavement payments. All those and more are part of this very important Bill that has come before this House.

But what we have seen, particularly in the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), is an attempt simply to distract the Australian community and certainly to distract his split Party from the real issues that are facing his own Party, the issues that it is attempting to grapple with as it pretends to prepare for coming into government. If his speech and his Budget response were any indication of a preparedness to come into government, then those opposite should not worry about the next election in 18 months time; they should look a few years down the track, closer to the end of this century before they need to be prepared to come to government.

The fact of the matter is that we cannot be blamed by honourable members opposite--particularly the Leader of the Opposition, who was an adviser to the Fraser Government which officiated over double digit inflation, double digit unemployment, a rocketing debt in this country, decaying industry, industrial relations chaos, and only a third of the kids reaching year 12. That was the situation when the Fraser Government, advised by the current Leader of the Opposition, went out of government. That is the world that the Leader of the Opposition claims is great!

Because the Leader of the Opposition cannot deal with that part of his record and the realities of his past life, he has to go back to the Menzies years. What a great period that was! If people from any period should answer for the position that this country is in, or pay for it or justify it, it is people from those years, and also the years of the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government that left this country in the state that it was in in 1983.

Honourable members opposite talked about hardship. I remember well the days when I sat with my grandmother around the radio listening to the Budget and waiting to see whether pensioners would get any increase in the bountiful years of the Menzies Government. Pensioners sat and they sweated. They used to travel up to Canberra with their meagre resources, march or do anything to get a few extra shillings in their pension. Two shillings and sixpence extra in one's pension was a great advance. That was the situation of the pensioners of Australia, in those bountiful years of the Menzies Government, the Liberal and Country Party Government--the same sort of people who would come back here today if they had the chance. That is what honourable members opposite would put people through again--going back to scrimping and saving and begging for money from the social security system.

It is no good the honourable member for Wentworth and Leader of the Opposition coming into this House and claiming to represent all the people of Australia, as he does on many occasions, when he is quite clearly set on disenfranchising a very large proportion of them. His attitude and that of his party room is one of not caring for the unemployed. Otherwise, why would honourable members opposite cut them off after nine months? Honourable members opposite talk about hardship. Nine months of being out of work is hardship. Honourable members opposite think they understand it, but they do not. If they did, they would not contemplate, as part of their policy, cutting people off after nine months on the unemployment benefit. That is the situation that the Opposition would have.

Let us face it, if the Opposition thinks it is really prepared for government, it should let its Leader come to the dispatch box--and let him have the full support of honourable members opposite for once--and tell the people of Australia what he would really do. We will not talk about a consumption tax tonight. We will not talk about all the other lost policies that will probably never surface before this election, the next election or the one after. Let him come into this House when we are talking about social security and explain to the people of Australia his statement of 22 August 1990, a year ago, when he said how much he would slash from social security. He said:
Well, I would have to go through the numbers again but in the last election campaign for example we had identified nearly $3 billion worth of total cuts and there was well over $1 billion--
in the social security area in that package.

Well, where is it? He should let the people know. The Leader of the Opposition cannot come in here from his split party room and talk about issues such as that without identifying how he will cut $1,000m from social security. The Leader of the Opposition has no credibility, and that is what will play against him at the next election.

The reality quite clearly is that the Leader of the Opposition wasted his time completely talking to me, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). He was facing the wrong way. He should have turned around and looked at honourable members opposite. The reason he came in here and had to give that speech again is probably that no-one heard it over the uproar in the party room the other day when he was trying to convince honourable members opposite of the reasons behind his giving this speech. He should have been talking to honourable members opposite. Honourable members opposite put on a great big front about support and all the rest of it. They come in here pretending to be united behind their leader. They are not, and we will see a clear example of that in a very few minutes.

The fact of the matter is that the Opposition has no credibility. That is not simply because honourable members opposite have a fight in their party room. That is bad enough, but the fact of the matter is that they have no credibility because they are not prepared to take the really hard decisions and they are not prepared to deal with real equity in this situation.

Here we see the sectional interests of the Liberal and National parties coming out. Let us deal with people's hardship as hardship. There are people who suffer in rural areas who are primary producers; there are other people in rural areas who suffer just as much, just as there are people in urban areas who suffer at times like this and at other times. Honourable members opposite have not been able tonight to describe for the people of Australia a real solution. All they have done is said that they would like, as would the Government, to do more for many people in various sections, particularly those involving rural interests and primary producers, who are going through very tough times. There are a lot of people going through tough times.

I respect the fact that the Leader of the Opposition has today at least had the guts to take the decision that he did and to front up in the Parliament and say it. It is the job of oppositions and governments to make the right decisions in balance. Quite clearly, I believe that the Government has made the right decision. I respect the Leader of the Opposition for supporting the Government on this matter, but I go back to the point, which I make very clearly once and for all, that the Opposition will not have credibility with the people of this country unless it can demonstrate what it would do with its tax policy, its health policy--whatever policy, but particularly its social security policy. The pensioners of this country will not go back to the days of Menzies--the glorious days of Menzies, as honourable members opposite would have it--and sit around their radios waiting for another two shillings and sixpence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 38, page 14, lines 9 and 10, omit proposed paragraph 838(d), substitute the following paragraph:
"(d) the value of the person's assets does not exceed $2 000 000 plus an additional amount of $100 000 for each additional FA child (after the first)".

The savings proposed in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) are $16.1m in the current financial year and $40.2m in a full financial year, as compared with expenditures of $101,000m and taxes of $96,000m. It is a notable point, which is quite clear in the Hansard, that every honourable member who spoke tonight raised the issue of the level of this assets test. One in particular said that he was opposed to it completely. All the speakers expressed this point of view.

The amendment does not oppose the principle of an assets test on the family allowance, and for me that is a massive shift from a principle which I have adhered to since before I joined the Liberal Party. The amendment purely attempts to set the assets test at a level that recognises the business reality that farm and small business returns on net asset values, particularly as set by bureaucratic valuation, are more like 3 per cent than 10 per cent. As I pointed out, previous information has suggested that the rural community would represent 75 per cent of the people affected by this decision. That, I understand, is NFF information.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has advised me that in 1988-89 the return on total farm assets was 3.7 per cent, in 1989-90 it was 2.5 per cent and in 1990-91 it was 0.3 per cent. In other words, it has never been a good sort of return, even in good years. Somehow or other we have to make an adjustment for the fact that this asset test is after debt. As I also pointed out in my speech in the second reading debate, it is a simple fact that farmers in particular, and other small businessmen, do not have the sort of gearing that was available to the captains of industry a few years ago. They have never been considered particularly good risks by the banks and most would not have debt levels in excess of 30 per cent of some asset valuation.

I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate my situation with a three-quarter acre block that I own, facing a secondary highway, not a major highway, in the Perth metropolitan area--not in the city. The Valuer-General has just decided it is worth $400,000. Someone operating his own small business on that would have a building that costs, say, $300,000, and it would not be unreasonable to suggest that he would have stock and plant worth another $300,000. That is a total of $1m for a tiny corner small business. If he had debts of $200,000, which would still leave him with $200,000 above this asset limit, his interest bill would still be $40,000, because notwithstanding the fact that the Government keeps trumpeting interest rates of 10 and 12 per cent, that little guy does not get them. He is paying 15 to 20 per cent. If he had the loan for five years he would have to find an additional $40,000 to repay it. He does not have much left in the present environment.

Of course, the farmers are even worse off. It is an outrageous situation confronting most of them. They cannot borrow; they cannot sell. They have little cash flow relative to their debt servicing. They cannot be helped by tax deductions, because they have got no income, and in their depressed rural areas they cannot get a job. They are being compared with someone who is eligible for unemployment benefits--the dole. That person can be married with a home in the suburbs and have assets of $157,500, and still get the dole.

What we are talking about here is not what the programs of the future might bring; we are talking about people being denied their last $20 or $30--the only bit of cash that comes into the family. They are not eligible, because of the more restrictive assets tests that apply universally in other areas, for those sorts of benefits. They can only get the family allowance. The person who gets it is the wife of the farmer--the one who feeds the kids. It is no use talking about a grand future, because, to put it simply, the grocery bill has got to be paid this week and next week. In my electorate many people are confronted with just that problem--finding the money to pay the grocery bills.

Others have talked about pulling their kids out of school. That happened at the beginning of the year. They were pulled out of the Government hostels too, because their parents could not afford that. That is what I am talking about. We talk about poverty traps; these people are in a gigantic one. All I am saying in this amendment, and in fact in pleading with the Government, is at least raise it to a level that recognises the values, even in these depressed times, that the bureaucrats are putting upon these properties, and the assets that exist upon them--the buildings, the plant, the stock and the livestock.

Honourable members should think about that and lift it to $2m. I know we can throw bricks at $2m as it sounds like a fortune; but I have just given the simple $1m example of a corner small business. Inflation has had a massive effect on what was a lot of money. The real point I am making to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) is that at $2m it would relieve the problems of most farmers. We would probably go from a situation of 75 per cent of the total being farmers to something below 25 per cent. It is a more realistic figure. We have the income test, which is $62,057, plus sums for additional kids. All that I have done to arrive at $2m is to work back at 3 per cent.

If Government members think that $2m is too high and that I have not made sufficient provision for, say, debt, then please get up and tell me that $1.75m is fair and reasonable. I will accept that. I will accept anything that will get these people a fair deal. If there are new programs coming from either side of politics that give them a better future, I will fight for them when they arrive. I am talking about what the Government is going to do to some people in desperate circumstances.

The Minister talked about his old grandmother or his mother and her pension. She has got one. These people do not have one, and it is probable that their parents do not have one either, because they are asset tested out of it as they are still part owners of the farm. They cannot afford to transfer it, because they do not have the funds to do so. Do not tell us that those hardship provisions will work. They are not the solution. They are grossly demeaning, and I think they will be quite impossible for people to handle. I have got to say that my dealings on the assets test for the pension have never been all that encouraging. It is a matter of scratching and fighting at all times to help old people who also have no resources.

This is what I am talking about. I am talking about one simple thing. I will concede the Government its assets test, but I say to it that on all the evidence available--the ABARE, the Government's company, a Government institution--it has never got 10 per cent on its returns yet, and in the present environment it is not even getting one per cent. I am saying that at $2m the Government would probably strike the average. That is the purpose of the amendment. I repeat that it is one that has been supported by most members in this Parliament. I have found myself in a position of moving the amendment because I am prepared to put my vote where my mouth is. I am not prepared just to talk about this. I am determined to act upon it because I have no choice. My first responsibility, as should be that of those opposite, is to the people in the electorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I participate in the debate at this stage for one main reason. During the second reading debate the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) was asked to respond to several questions, and we had a waste of 15 minutes with his summary, which did not address any of the three points that I brought forward, and that I am sure other members would be interested in, to find out exactly what the Government is going to do in relation to certain things.

SPEECH.PARA: The first matter was in connection with rental assistance. The Minister did not devote any time at all to this. What we were saying was that on the face of it this proposition appears to be nothing more than a back door increase in benefit rates, which appears to be unnecessary to us because the rent assistance is already tax free and indexed and also property prices and rentals are currently in a depressed state. I think everybody has taken that stance in the debate. What I want to ask the Government is this: what evidence is there of an increased need for a reduced waiting period in view of the elements I have mentioned? As I said, it appears to us in the meantime that it is just a back door method of increasing benefits for those who have an eligibility. That was the first point to which the Minister did not respond.
The second point was very closely tied up with the financial hardship provisions of the liquid assets test. We have in the Bill the provision that `liquid assets':
in relation to a person, means:
(a) the person's cash; and
(b) the person's shares and debentures in a public company within the meaning of the Corporations Law; and
(c) any amount deposited with, or lent . a bank, building society, credit union or other financial institution by the person..
(d) any amount due, and able to be paid, to the person by, or on behalf of, a former employer of the person; and
(e) any other readily realisable assets of the person;

I do not think there was an honourable member on our side of the House who did not refer to the fact that there is a need to understand that in any small business or any farm across Australia there are times when farmers and businessmen come into a cash deposit which is set aside specifically as running expenses or working capital in order to plant a crop, pay a debt or something else like that.

We had hoped that, in the absence of any recognition that liquid assets did not include working capital, the Department would not take into account such items as a $20,000 receipt from proceeds of a farm or a business where that amount is specifically held for the time being in order to provide working capital and follow-on funds such as those required, in a farm, for paying the rates, paying for the fertiliser, paying for the seed or paying the wages or, in a small business, paying the debts outstanding at the time. That was not addressed. I listened to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) when he said that we will be closely scrutinising this particular aspect in the Senate to see what the answer is. The answer is not revealed within that definition and the Minister did not respond.

The third matter that has to be addressed is one that again came in for universal comment. How do we value the assets of a business or a farm? Who is going to make the assessment and on what basis is that evaluation being made? I will tell honourable members why it is important. This year we found a major corporation in Australia writing off the value of assets to a nil value and leaving the property in the hands of the bankers. I am referring to Mount Isa Mines, MIM, which has completely written off the value of two coalmines and a port establishment and said to the bankers, `It's all yours'. As far as MIM is concerned, the value of those two mines and the port facilities is nil.

In many cases throughout Australia there are businesses and farms that are in exactly the same situation. I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate that I went out to Charleville a fortnight ago. It was demonstrated clearly that the value of the bankers' security was less than the amount that was being lent. That is happening right across western Queensland and it is happening in the cane farms that I represent in the electorate of Dawson. Twelve months ago the valuation of properties was twice as much as it is at the moment. The banks are keeping people on properties only to maintain them there, because they know that the value of those properties as going concerns is almost zilch. Is this type of thing going to be taken into account as far as the $600,000 value is concerned?

I think one honourable member mentioned that in Western Australia at the moment the Valuer-General has put out a valuation on properties assuming that the 1989 boom is still upon us. I tell the Minister that the boom is not in the rural areas of Australia. The boom is not with small business in Australia. We ask: who is going to make the assessment; will it be a realisable and a realistic assessment; and will it take into account the particular deprivations of people living within the area?

The final question we ask is: is a business asset, that is, that ready cash that I was speaking about, going to be classified separately from the liquid assets--the private cash assets--of an individual, either as a member of a partnership that may have working capital in hand or as a corporation to which he or she is a shareholder? We did not get the answers to those questions. As I said before, I am sure that we will be scrutinising those aspects very carefully in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My reason for supporting this amendment is that I believe that clause 38, proposed paragraph 838(d) of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 is grossly unfair to small businesses, both rural and urban. I might add that the general lack of faith in this Bill is clearly the view of the majority of my coalition colleagues who have spoken in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: A wise man once said, `Never forget the block from which you are hewn'. As a Liberal member, I cannot in all conscience support proposed paragraph 838(d) as it stands, because I am not prepared to forsake the grassroots of the Party to which I have belonged for 18 years and which I have represented in this place for 13 of those years.

Small business is the distinctive element of Liberal philosophy translated into economic terms. I for one will not be part of making the lot of Australian small business men and women more difficult, not only during this `recession that we had to have', according to the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), but at any time. Surely the farmers and small business people of this country have suffered enough during the past decade under the Labor Government. They have been forced to endure crippling interest rates on mortgages, increased taxes and an ever increasing plethora of government regulation.

Six hundred thousand dollars, the figure at which the proposed assets test would apply, might sound like a great deal of money to many people. But, without adequate income, or without any income at all, no asset will put food into the mouths of children.

We only have to watch television, read newspapers or even observe those around us to know that many farmers and business people who are asset rich are finding it very difficult in present circumstances to feed, clothe and educate their children. Probably every person in this place would know of examples similar to the two I now mention. I personally know of a small hire equipment firm and a small manufacturing company, both established Victorian family businesses and both with a sound assets base. In each case their income level is low, due to a prolonged absence of orders; in both cases they have to support families, and they are not finding it easy to feed, clothe and educate their children.

Paragraph 838(d) of the Bill, as it stands, would very directly affect them and many others adversely and in a very unfair manner. Such people have for years provided services or produced and provided employment for Victorians and are entitled to family allowance just as other taxpayers are. Moreover, the extremely limited hardship provisions in the legislation will not resolve their particular problems.

Future policies of a Federal coalition government will work towards resolving our current difficulties. That is very clear and very obvious. However, that is some time away yet. Accordingly, present dilemmas must be faced in the context of present policies and present legislation. That is a reality for us here tonight in this chamber.
Therefore, in conclusion, if I supported paragraph 838(d) as it stands, I would be denying my basic Liberal philosophy and abrogating my responsibilities as a Liberal member of Parliament.
