SPEECH.PARA: I have people in my electorate at the moment who, for the first time since 1930, are making charcoal out of eucalyptus trees and drying eucalyptus and natural bush flowers and selling them in an endeavour to survive. This Government has forced a generation of young people, who are our best skilled and best equipped people to carry on the productive cycle, out of the country areas and into the cities in search of work--and they will never return. It has forced older people with a heritage in farming, a heritage that this country is going to need in the future, into bankruptcy.

Some time ago in this Parliament when the Government suggested that the assets test threshold on family allowance should be $300,000, this Parliament took action. A motion was moved and supported by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and myself and, to their credit, it was also supported by the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I believe that particular debate ultimately brought about the Government decision to recognise that the $300,000 then proposed was insufficient, and so we see tonight this Bill that raises the assets test limit on the family allowance to $600,000.

I believe this has been a major improvement and, under normal circumstances, I would believe that the raising of the limit to $600,000 was reasonably fair. However, we have a crisis in Australia at the present time. As has been said, the crisis is not just in the rural areas; it is also in the cities. But the circumstances in rural Australia are different for farming families and for small business people. They simply have no option to gain any social equity under the existing arrangements.

When I returned home to the Mallee from school, I received #5 from my father at the weekend and was allowed the use of the family car. I was extremely happy because I was well fed and there was a vision that, with a little bit of work, the opportunity existed for me to develop the farm, to take over the farm and ultimately to become a successful farmer. However, that vision does not exist any more. It has been removed from our rural and farming youth and it has been removed from small business youth.

If someone had told me five years ago that two of the cities in my electorate today would be without Toyota or General Motors-Holden's agencies, I would not have believed them. But that is the position. The whole social fabric of our rural communities has been destroyed because of the destruction of economic viability. I say to Government members that, if they wish to preserve the true economic base of this country and create the sort of employment opportunities and standard of living that we should expect in Australia, in these times of hardship an assets test is totally inappropriate. In the administration of family allowances there is only one test that can be applied, and that is an income test.

TALK.START.PARA: —-George Bernard Shaw once said:

SPEECH.PARA: When two people are under the influence of the most violent, most insane, most delusive, and most transient of all passions, they are required to swear that they will remain in that excited, abnormal and exhausting condition, continuously until death do them part.

Some 70 years later we are faced not so much with the trauma to which Shaw alluded but with the personal, social and economic tragedy of family breakdown on an unprecedented scale. As next week is Marriage Education Week in Australia, it is timely to reflect on the size of the problem and our contribution to the education of the community generally.

Each year more than 40,000 marriages end in divorce. In 1990 the number of divorces represented some 36.45 per cent of the number of marriages in Australia and, as distressing as the personal and emotional trauma may be, there are other consequences for our community. It is estimated that some 55 per cent of the divorces in 1990 involved one or more children; that is, 45,000 Australian children were left in single parent homes last year. Since the introduction of the Family Law Act in 1975, more than 700,000 children have been deprived of the care of one parent for some part of their lives. By the end of the decade this figure will have risen to over one million children.

In its report Our Homeless Children the inquiry into youth homelessness pointed to family breakdown as one of the major causes of an estimated 60,000 to 70,000 street kids leaving home. Divorce can be a wrenching experience for children. The debate about the long term effects was touched off with the publication by Judith Wallerstein, a Californian psychologist, of a book in 1989 described as the first ever long term study into the consequences of divorce for children. In the book Second Chances: Men, Women and Children A Decade After Divorce Wallerstein reported that many of the children of 60 middle class divorced families from the San Francisco area studied over a 12-year period experienced difficulties in education, social and interpersonal relationships. She found that 10 years after their parents had divorced, only 34 per cent of the children in the study were doing well; another 37 per cent were depressed, could not concentrate in school, had trouble making friends and suffered a wide range of behavioural problems. In a magazine article drawn from the book, Wallerstein described the 37 per cent figure as `a powerful statistic', and declared:
It would be hard to find any other group of children--except perhaps the victims of a natural disaster--who suffered such a rate of serious psychological problems.
The fact is that 50 per cent of all separations occur within the first seven years of marriage, in many cases leaving a woman struggling to raise a young family on a social security pension.

Finally, there is the major economic burden to the nation. It has been estimated that family breakdown costs this nation some $2.5 billion annually. The Australian Institute of Family Studies has estimated that each separation costs society some $12,000. Yet it has been estimated that only some 10 per cent of Australian couples undertake any form of marriage preparation. Currently, the Federal Government spends some $16.6m on family services, of which $11.7m is expended on marriage counselling and just $500,700 on marriage education; that is, we spend less than $5 per marriage on education programs when the cost of picking up the pieces is $2.5 billion, or over $12,000 per separation. The value of marriage education has been established and reiterated by research studies not only in this country but elsewhere, and a leading American educator showed that when couples undertook a program, some 12 to 15 per cent of those couples either postponed or cancelled their wedding. It is better for us to deal with a cure before a problem arises which afflicts this society so much.

I therefore hope that all honourable members will use the opportunity presented by the fact that next week is Marriage Education Week in Australia to promote measures of education to assist all couples in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Telecom allow its employees to use Telecom vehicles for their private use after 4.30 p.m. on business days, on weekends and while on sick leave, for a payment between $10 and $17 per week.
(2) Does Telecom meet all fuel, oil, tyre and maintenance costs incurred in respect of Telecom vehicles while they are in private use by Telecom employees.
(3) Are Telecom employees permitted unlimited mileage in Telecom vehicles during non-business hours within a radius of 80 kms of their residence in capital cities or 100 kms in country areas.
(4) Is it a fact that Telecom does not require vehicle logbooks to be kept either for business or private use.
(5) Is it a fact that Telecom does not know with any certainty whether or not its vehicles are being used for private journeys beyond the distances referred to in part (3).
(6) Is the net cost to Telecom of private use of its vehicles at least $23 million per annum.
(7) What is the total (a) cost to Telecom of the private use of its vehicles and (b) amount received in payments from employees for private use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from Telecom, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

Telecom first introduced commuter use for a limited number of operational vehicles in the mid-1970s. Telecom considers that it benefited from increased productivity brought about by staff commencing and completing work at the worksite, rather than having to be allotted work each day at a depot. Home garaging also achieved significant savings from the reduced need for secure parking areas to garage and protect vehicles out of work hours. At this time part-private use was not permitted.

The new policy introduced in 1989 was based on recommendations arising out of an independent industry study of vehicle arrangements operating in other Government Business Enterprises and private sector companies. However, as it was not possible to resolve the matter in negotiations with the unions, the subsequent dispute was referred to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) in November 1989. Following the public hearing of the case, the AIRC issued recommendations on the issues in dispute and these were accepted by Telecom and the unions.

Intrinsic to the introduction of part-private use was a range of limitations on the use of vehicles and the requirement for staff to contribute to incremental operating costs. The current contribution rates are $11.70 for `front seat only' vehicles and $20.50 for vehicles with front and rear seats.

Vehicles must be returned to Telecom during leave periods (excluding rostered days off) of more than two days (intervening days at Christmas/New Year and the Easter period excluded, subject to operational requirements).
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes. These radial distances were set by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as part of the proceedings referred to in part (1).

(4) Yes. Rather than requiring staff to maintain log books, Telecom utilises a specialised motor vehicle database, FLEETMIS, which provides local management with appropriate audit and control mechanisms. At present this database is not being fully utilised but, as part of a current review of its motor vehicle fleet, Telecom is aiming to ensure that FLEETMIS is adopted as the Corporate System for total fleet management.

(5) Yes. However, whilst Telecom is unable at present to guarantee that each of its vehicles are used within the terms and conditions of the part-private agreement, including distance constraints, any employee who is found to have breached the terms of the agreement must surrender the vehicle and, depending on the circumstances, may also be subject to further disciplinary action.

(6) The exact net cost is not known by Telecom. Telecom considers that whilst there would be an overall net cost in operating the part-private use scheme, significant savings would have been achieved as a result of improved productivity and reduced vehicle storage and security costs. Telecom considers there have also been considerable savings in containing recruitment and training costs because skilled technical staff are provided with an employment benefit equal to packages offered throughout the telecommunications industry. These staff are, therefore, less likely to be lured by a potential competitor with the offer of use of a company vehicle as part of an employment package.
The cost of the scheme is also offset, to a degree, by the weekly contributions paid by staff for use of a vehicle.

(7) (a) As indicated in the reply to Part (6), Telecom advises that it is not able to give a precise figure of the cost of the scheme as many of the benefits achieved, such as increased productivity and reduced recruitment and training costs, are not quantifiable.
(b) The amount received from employees for part-private use, based on the current contribution rates, is estimated at $8.16 million per annum.
(8) No. Part-private usage is not seen by Telecom as a subsidised private transport scheme.
(a) and (b) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 564 (Hansard, 11 April 1991, page 2542), when will the Australian Government be able to decide whether to make the declaration under Article 14 of the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

(2) Further to the answer to question No. 170 (Hansard, 11 October 1990, page 2795), when will the Australian Government be able to decide whether to make the declaration under Article 41 of the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The declarations under the International Covenant on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights are two procedures for international monitoring of compliance with human rights obligations. The Government has long held the view that the first Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is the most significant of such procedures and has indicated in this place its intention to achieve accession to that Protocol before proceeding to consider the related questions of the declarations under the instruments to which the honourable member refers.

As the honourable member may be aware, Australia acceded to the Protocol on 25 September 1991. The Government will now consider the question of the declarations under the International Covenant on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That consideration will include consultation with the States and Territories in the forum of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: On what basis are funds allocated to the States for health purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Budget Paper Number 4 for 1991-92 identifies 19 specific purpose health payments to the States and Territories in 1991-92 (16 recurrent and 3 capital). The basis for allocating these payments depends on the specific objectives the Commonwealth has established under its various financial assistance programs. The distributional criteria applied to these programs usually reflect the need for equity between States as well as the need to ensure adequate access to services. In some instances the relative differences in health status between States and special needs and conditions are also taken into account.
Some programs have very specific purposes and

may not apply to all States. For example, the basis for allocating funds to Tasmania for the construction of Stage II of Launceston General Hospital was a negotiated agreement between the State and the Commonwealth to cost-share the project against an agreed budget.

Other, more general purpose grants, are allocated on a variety of bases, including per capita distribution, agreed project costs, cost-sharing requirements and arrangements that reflect specific needs and conditions. For example, most of the Hospital Funding Grants are allocated on a per capita basis which is also weighted for age and sex to reflect the relative differences in hospital utilisation due to an ageing population. On the other hand, the AIDS component in the Hospital Funding Grants is determined on the basis of the number of AIDS patients being treated in a particular State during the relevant grant year.
